paragraphs.translated: I didn't think I would ever fight Pompey. He's shown me unusual deference lately, and I must repay his favors or risk a reputation for ingratitude. That done, I can turn against him.

paragraphs.original:
Time calls upon 's.
Of us must Pompey presently be sought,
Or else he seeks out us.
paragraphs.translated: There isn't much time. Either we go after Pompey or he'll come after us.

paragraphs.original: Where lies he?
paragraphs.translated: Where is he now?

paragraphs.original: About the Mount Misena.
paragraphs.translated:
Near
Mt. Misena.
Mt. Misena

paragraphs.original: What is his strength by land?
paragraphs.translated: How large is his land army?

paragraphs.original:
Great and increasing.
But by sea he is an absolute master.
paragraphs.translated: Large and increasing. But his navy rules the sea.

paragraphs.original:
So is the fame.
Would we had spoke together! Haste we for it.
Yet, ere we put ourselves in arms, dispatch we
The business we have talked of.
paragraphs.translated: That's what I hear. I wish we'd had this conversation sooner. Let's get down to business - and yet, before we get ready for war, let's take care of that business we just discussed.

paragraphs.original:
With most gladness,
And do invite you to my sister's view,
Whither straight I'll lead you.
paragraphs.translated: With pleasure. I'll introduce you to my sister. Follow me.

paragraphs.original: Let us, Lepidus, not lack your company.
paragraphs.translated: Come with us, Lepidus.

paragraphs.original: Noble Antony, not sickness should detain me.
paragraphs.translated: Noble Antony, even illness couldn't keep me away.

paragraphs.original: Flourish. Exeunt all but ENOBARBUS, AGRIPPA, and MAECENAS
paragraphs.translated: Trumpets play a fanfare. Everyone exits except ENOBARBUS, AGRIPPA, and MAECENAS.

paragraphs.original: Half the heart of Caesar, worthy Maecenas! My honorable friend, Agrippa.
paragraphs.translated: You've become Caesar's right hand man, Maecenas! It's good to see you too, Agrippa.

paragraphs.original: Good Enobarbus!
paragraphs.translated: Good Enobarbus!

paragraphs.original:
We have cause to be glad that matters are so well digested.
You stayed well by 't in Egypt.
paragraphs.translated: We can be happy that things have been resolved so agreeably. And I see you survived your time in Egypt.

paragraphs.original: Ay, sir, we did sleep day out of countenance and made the night light with drinking.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, sir, it was tough. We confused the daytime by sleeping through it, and made the night merry with our drinking.

paragraphs.original: Eight wild boars roasted whole at a breakfast - and but twelve persons there! Is this true?
paragraphs.translated: We heard that once you were served eight wild boars roasted whole for breakfast - for only twelve people! Is that true?

paragraphs.original: This was but as a fly by an eagle. We had much more monstrous matter of feast, which worthily deserved noting.
paragraphs.translated: That was nothing. There were many even more memorable feasts.

paragraphs.original: She's a most triumphant lady, if report be square to her.
paragraphs.translated: She's a remarkable lady, if the rumors are to be believed.

paragraphs.original: When she first met Mark Antony, she pursed up his heart upon the river of Cydnus.
paragraphs.translated:
From the first time Antony saw her, sailing on her barge on the
Cydnus River, he was hers.
Cydnus River

paragraphs.original: There she appeared indeed, or my reporter devised well for her.
paragraphs.translated: She made quite an appearance there, or else my informant invented a very flattering description of her.

paragraphs.original:
I will tell you.
The barge she sat in, like a burnished throne,
Burned on the water. The poop was beaten gold,
Purple the sails, and so perfumèd that
The winds were lovesick with them. The oars were silver,
Which to the tune of flutes kept stroke, and made
The water which they beat to follow faster,
As amorous of their strokes. For her own person,
It beggared all description: she did lie
In her pavilion - cloth-of-gold, of tissue - 
O'erpicturing that Venus where we see
The fancy outwork nature. On each side her
Stood pretty dimpled boys, like smiling Cupids,
With divers-colored fans, whose wind did seem
To glow the delicate cheeks which they did cool,
And what they undid did.
paragraphs.translated: I'll tell you. Her barge looked like a golden throne upon the waves, burning bright with the sun's reflections. The rear deck was covered with hammered gold. The sails were dyed purple, and they were perfumed so heavily that they made the air seem dizzy with love. The oars were made of silver, and the oarsmen rowed in time to flute music. As the oars beat the water, the waves seemed to speed up as if excited by lust. Cleopatra's appearance was indescribable. As she reclined under a canopy woven from gold thread, she was more beautiful than any artist's idealized portrait of the goddess Venus. Pretty, Cupid-like boys stood on either side of her, smiling and cooling her with multicolored fans, which seemed to fan the flames in her cheeks even as they cooled them, undoing what they did.

paragraphs.original: Oh, rare for Antony!
paragraphs.translated: How excellent for Antony!

paragraphs.original:
Her gentlewomen, like the Nereides,
So many mermaids, tended her i' th' eyes,
And made their bends adornings. At the helm
A seeming mermaid steers. The silken tackle
Swell with the touches of those flower-soft hands
That yarely frame the office. From the barge
A strange invisible perfume hits the sense
Of the adjacent wharfs. The city cast
Her people out upon her, and Antony,
Enthroned i' th' marketplace, did sit alone,
Whistling to th' air, which, but for vacancy,
Had gone to gaze on Cleopatra too
And made a gap in nature.
paragraphs.translated:
Her ladies-in-waiting - like
Nereides, or mermaids - tended to Cleopatra as she watched them, and their graceful movements added to the beauty of the scene. It seemed as if a mermaid were steering. The silken sails and ropes swelled in the wind, expertly handled by the ladies' soft hands. People on the wharves could smell exotic perfume wafting from the barge as it passed them. All the people came out to see her, and Antony, waiting for her in the marketplace, was left alone. Even the air itself would have gone to look at Cleopatra, if that wouldn't have caused an unnatural vacuum in the atmosphere.
Nereides

paragraphs.original: Rare Egyptian!
paragraphs.translated: Extraordinary Egyptian!

paragraphs.original:
Upon her landing, Antony sent to her,
Invited her to supper. She replied
It should be better he became her guest,
Which she entreated. Our courteous Antony,
Whom ne'er the word of "No" woman heard speak,
Being barbered ten times o'er, goes to the feast,
And for his ordinary pays his heart
For what his eyes eat only.
paragraphs.translated: When she landed at the port, Antony sent an invitation for her to come to supper. She replied by saying that it would be better for him to be her guest instead. Our courteous Antony, who has never said "no" to any woman, after spending plenty of time being groomed by the barber, goes to the feast. For that simple meal, he paid with his heart - even though it was only his eyes that were satisfied.

paragraphs.original:
Royal wench!
She made great Caesar lay his sword to bed.
He plowed her, and she cropped.
paragraphs.translated:
Royal seductress! She lured Julius Caesar into her bed, he made love to her, and she bore
his child.
his child

paragraphs.original:
I saw her once
Hop forty paces through the public street,
And having lost her breath, she spoke, and panted,
That she did make defect perfection,
And, breathless, pour breathe forth.
paragraphs.translated: I saw her once hop forty feet down the street. When she stopped she was so out of breath that she was panting. Her beauty made even that weakness seem perfect, and even in her breathlessness she seemed to pour out breath.

paragraphs.original: Now Antony must leave her utterly.
paragraphs.translated: Now Antony has to leave her completely.

paragraphs.original:
Never. He will not.
Age cannot wither her, nor custom stale
Her infinite variety. Other women cloy
The appetites they feed, but she makes hungry
Where most she satisfies, for vilest things
Become themselves in her, that the holy priests
Bless her when she is riggish.
paragraphs.translated: He'll never leave her. Age won't wither her, and her charms are so varied that she never grows boring. With other women, the more familiar you grow with them the less appealing they become. Cleopatra, on the other hand, makes you desire her the more you see her. Even her worst faults are charming, and holy priests bless her even when she acts the slut.

paragraphs.original:
If beauty, wisdom, modesty, can settle
The heart of Antony, Octavia is
A blessèd lottery to him.
paragraphs.translated: If beauty, wisdom, and modesty can settle Antony's restless heart, Octavia will be the best thing that has ever happened to him.

paragraphs.original:
Let us go.
Good Enobarbus, make yourself my guest
Whilst you abide here.
paragraphs.translated: Let's go. Good Enobarbus, consider yourself my guest as long as you're here.

paragraphs.original: Humbly, sir, I thank you.
paragraphs.translated: I humbly thank you.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter ANTONY, CAESAR; OCTAVIA between them
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY and CAESAR enter with OCTAVIA between them.

paragraphs.original:
(to OCTAVIA ) The world and my great office will sometimes
(to

)
Divide me from your bosom.

All which time
Before the gods my knee shall bow my prayers
To them for you.
paragraphs.translated: And I will spend our time apart on my knees, praying for you.

paragraphs.original:
(to CAESAR )     Good night, sir. - My Octavia,
     (to

)     
Read not my blemishes in the world's report.
I have not kept my square, but that to come
Shall all be done by th' rule. Good night, dear lady.
(to CAESAR ) Good night, sir.
(to

)
Good night.
paragraphs.translated: Good night.

paragraphs.original: He exits with OCTAVIA
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR and OCTAVIA exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter SOOTHSAYER
paragraphs.translated: The FORTUNETELLER enters.

paragraphs.original: Now, sirrah, you do wish yourself in Egypt?
paragraphs.translated:
Now,
sirrah, I hear you wish you were back in Egypt.
sirrah

paragraphs.original: Would I had never come from thence, nor you thither.
paragraphs.translated: I wish I had never left Egypt and that you had never come to Egypt.

paragraphs.original: If you can, your reason?
paragraphs.translated: Tell me why, if you can.

paragraphs.original: I see it in my motion, have it not in my tongue. But yet hie you to Egypt again.
paragraphs.translated: It's a feeling, but nothing I can put into words. But you had better get back to Egypt again.

paragraphs.original:
Say to me whose fortunes shall rise higher,
Caesar's or mine?
paragraphs.translated: Tell me who shall have the better luck, Caesar or me?

paragraphs.original:
Caesar's.
Therefore, O Antony, stay not by his side.
Thy dæmon - that thy spirit which keeps thee - is
Noble, courageous, high, unmatchable
Where Caesar's is not. But near him thy angel
Becomes afeard, as being o'erpowered. Therefore
Make space enough between you.
paragraphs.translated: Caesar. So you'd better not stay with him, Antony. Your guardian angel is noble, courageous, significant, and unmatched when Caesar's not around. But when you are with him, your angel is weakened and easily frightened. That's why there must be space between you.

paragraphs.original: Speak this no more.
paragraphs.translated: Don't speak of this again.

paragraphs.original:
To none but thee, no more but when to thee.
If thou dost play with him at any game,
Thou art sure to lose, and of that natural luck
He beats thee 'gainst the odds. Thy luster thickens
When he shines by. I say again, thy spirit
Is all afraid to govern thee near him,
But, he away, 'tis noble.
paragraphs.translated: To none but you, only to you. You will surely lose any game you play with Caesar. With his natural luck, he will beat you even against the odds. Your light dulls when he is near. I repeat: your angel is afraid to inspire you when you're around him, but when he goes away it becomes brilliant again.

paragraphs.original:
Get thee gone.
Say to Ventidius I would speak with him.
paragraphs.translated: Leave now. Tell Ventidius I want to speak with him.

paragraphs.original: Exit SOOTHSAYER
paragraphs.translated: The FORTUNETELLER exits.

paragraphs.original:
(to himself) He shall to Parthia. Be it art or hap,
(to himself)
He hath spoken true. The very dice obey him,
And in our sports my better cunning faints
Under his chance. If we draw lots, he speeds.
His cocks do win the battle still of mine
When it is all to naught, and his quails ever
Beat mine, inhooped, at odds. I will to Egypt.
And though I make this marriage for my peace,
I' th' East my pleasure lies.
paragraphs.translated:
(to himself) I'll send him to Parthia. Whether he's truly gifted or just lucky, what the Fortuneteller said is true. Even the dice obey Caesar. When we compete in sports, my skill is defeated by his luck. If we pick numbers in a lottery, he wins. His roosters always beat mine at the cockfights. His quails beat mine, even against the odds, when mine have the advantage. I'll return to Egypt. Though I've made this marriage to keep peace with Caesar, my pleasure remains in the East, with Cleopatra.
(to himself)

paragraphs.original: Enter VENTIDIUS
paragraphs.translated: VENTIDIUS enters.

paragraphs.original:
O come, Ventidius.
You must to Parthia. Your commission's ready.
Follow me and receive 't.
paragraphs.translated: Come here, Ventidius. You must go to Parthia. Your authorization is ready. Come with me and I'll get it for you.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter LEPIDUS, MECAENAS, and AGRIPPA
paragraphs.translated: LEPIDUS, MAECENAS, and AGRIPPA enter.

paragraphs.original:
Trouble yourselves no further. Pray you, hasten
Your generals after.
paragraphs.translated: Don't spend any more time here. Go tell your generals to hurry their preparations.

paragraphs.original:
Sir, Mark Antony
Will e'en but kiss Octavia, and we'll follow.
paragraphs.translated: Sir, we'll follow as soon as Mark Antony kisses Octavia good-bye.

paragraphs.original:
Till I shall see you in your soldiers' dress,
Which will become you both, farewell.
paragraphs.translated: Good-bye then, until the time I see you dressed in your battle gear, which will suit you both very well.

paragraphs.original:
We shall,
As I conceive the journey, be at the Mount
Before you, Lepidus.
paragraphs.translated: According to my reckoning, we'll get to Mt. Misena before you, Lepidus.

paragraphs.original:
Your way is shorter.
My purposes do draw me much about.
You'll win two days upon me.
paragraphs.translated: You're taking a shorter route. My plans take me a roundabout way. You'll get there two days before me.

paragraphs.original:
MAECENAS, AGRIPPA
                                                         Sir, good success.
paragraphs.translated: Good luck, sir.

paragraphs.original: Farewell.
paragraphs.translated: Farewell.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter CLEOPATRA, CHARMIAN, IRAS, and ALEXAS
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA, CHARMIAN, IRAS, and ALEXAS enter.

paragraphs.original:
Give me some music. Music, moody food
Of us that trade in love.
paragraphs.translated: Play me some music. Music feeds the melancholy moods of us lovers.

paragraphs.original: The music, ho!
paragraphs.translated: Musicians, come in!

paragraphs.original: Enter MARDIAN the eunuch
paragraphs.translated: MADRIAN enters.

paragraphs.original: Let it alone. Let's to billiards. Come, Charmian.
paragraphs.translated: Never mind. Let's play billiards. Play with me, Charmian.

paragraphs.original: My arm is sore. Best play with Mardian.
paragraphs.translated: My arm is sore. You'll have a better game with Mardian.

paragraphs.original:
As well a woman with an eunuch played
As with a woman. - Come, you'll play with me, sir?
paragraphs.translated: Playing with a eunuch is the same as playing with a woman. Will you play with me, sir?

paragraphs.original: As well as I can, madam.
paragraphs.translated: I'll do my best, madam.

paragraphs.original:
And when good will is showed, though 't come too short,
The actor may plead pardon. I'll none now.
Give me mine angle. We'll to th' river. There,
My music playing far off, I will betray
Tawny-finned fishes. My bended hook shall pierce
Their slimy jaws, and as I draw them up
I'll think them every one an Antony
And say, "Aha! You're caught."
paragraphs.translated: When a person tries in good faith, even if he fails he cannot be blamed. I don't want to play now. Give me my fishing rod. We'll go to the river. With my music playing in the background, I'll lure fish. My hook will go through their slimy jaws and as I pull them up I'll imagine each one is Antony. I'll say, "Aha! I caught you!"

paragraphs.original:
'Twas merry when
You wagered on your angling, when your diver
Did hang a salt fish on his hook, which he
With fervency drew up.
paragraphs.translated: It was funny when you and Antony bet on who could catch the first fish. You had a diver put a salted fish on his hook. He was so excited as he hurried to pull it in!

paragraphs.original:
That time - Oh, times! - 
I laughed him out of patience, and that night
I laughed him into patience. And next morn,
Ere the ninth hour, I drunk him to his bed,
Then put my tires and mantles on him, whilst
I wore his sword Philippan.
paragraphs.translated: That time? Oh, there were so many fun times. I would play some trick on him and laugh until he lost his patience. Then, that night, I would laugh with him while we made love until he was patient again. Then by nine in the morning I would have him so drunk I could dress him in my clothes while I wore the sword he used at the famous battle of Philippi.

paragraphs.original: Enter a MESSENGER
paragraphs.translated: A MESSENGER enters.

paragraphs.original:
Oh, from Italy!
Ram thou thy fruitful tidings in mine ears,
That long time have been barren.
paragraphs.translated: Oh! News from Italy! Cram your good news into my ears. It's been so long since I've heard from him.

paragraphs.original: Madam, madam -
paragraphs.translated: Madam, madam -

paragraphs.original:
Antonio's dead! If thou say so, villain,
Thou kill'st thy mistress. But well and free,
If thou so yield him, there is gold, and here
My bluest veins to kiss - a hand that kings
Have lipped, and trembled kissing.
paragraphs.translated: Antony's dead! If you say that, you bastard, you'll kill your Queen. If you say he's healthy and free, I'll give you money and you may kiss my hand. Kings have trembled to kiss this hand.

paragraphs.original: First, madam, he is well.
paragraphs.translated: Let me say first, madam, that he is well.

paragraphs.original:
Why, there's more gold. But, sirrah, mark, we use
To say the dead are well. Bring it to that,
The gold I give thee will I melt and pour
Down thy ill-uttering throat.
paragraphs.translated: Well then, here's more money for you. But you know, sirrah, we customarily say that the dead are well. If that's what you mean, I'll melt this gold and pour it down your throat that speaks these hateful words.

paragraphs.original: Good madam, hear me.
paragraphs.translated: Good madam, let me speak.

paragraphs.original:
Well, go to, I will.
But there's no goodness in thy face - if Antony
Be free and healthful, so tart a favor
To trumpet such good tidings! If not well,
Thou shouldst come like a Fury crowned with snakes,
Not like a formal man.
paragraphs.translated:
All right, I will. But you don't look as if you bring good news. If Antony is free and healthy, you shouldn't wear such a sour face while bringing such good news.
If he's not well, you should arrive like a
Fury with snakes for hair, not in the shape of a normal man.
Fury

paragraphs.original: Will 't please you hear me?
paragraphs.translated: Do you want to hear my news?

paragraphs.original:
I have a mind to strike thee ere thou speak'st.
Yet if thou say Antony lives, is well,
Or friends with Caesar, or not captive to him,
I'll set thee in a shower of gold and hail
Rich pearls upon thee.
paragraphs.translated: I have half a mind to hit you before you speak again. But if Antony is alive, healthy, friendly with Caesar, and not Caesar's prisoner, I'll shower you with gold and pearls.

paragraphs.original: Madam, he's well.
paragraphs.translated: Madam, he's well.

paragraphs.original: Well said.
paragraphs.translated: That's well spoken.

paragraphs.original: And friends with Caesar.
paragraphs.translated: And he's friendly with Caesar.

paragraphs.original: Th' art an honest man.
paragraphs.translated: You are an honest man.

paragraphs.original: Caesar and he are greater friends than ever.
paragraphs.translated: Caesar and he are better friends than ever.

paragraphs.original: Make thee a fortune from me.
paragraphs.translated: I'm going to make you a rich man.

paragraphs.original: But yet, madam -
paragraphs.translated: But yet, madam -

paragraphs.original:
I do not like "But yet." It does allay
The good precedence. Fie upon "But yet."
"But yet" is as a jailer to bring forth
Some monstrous malefactor. Prithee, friend,
Pour out the pack of matter to mine ear,
The good and bad together. He's friends with Caesar,
In state of health, thou say'st, and, thou say'st, free.
paragraphs.translated: I don't like the sound of "but yet." It reverses all the good that came before it. Damn those words, "but yet!" "But yet" is like a jailer about to bring out some horrible criminal. Please, my friend, give me all the news, both good and bad, at the same time. You say he's friendly with Caesar, healthy, and free.

paragraphs.original:
Free, madam, no. I made no such report.
He's bound unto Octavia.
paragraphs.translated: I didn't say free, madam. No, I didn't say that. He's bound to Octavia.

paragraphs.original: For what good turn?
paragraphs.translated: For what favor?

paragraphs.original: For the best turn i' th' bed.
paragraphs.translated: For the favor of sleeping in her bed.

paragraphs.original: I am pale, Charmian.
paragraphs.translated: I'm sick, Charmian.

paragraphs.original: Madam, he's married to Octavia.
paragraphs.translated: He's married to Octavia, madam.

paragraphs.original: The most infectious pestilence upon thee!
paragraphs.translated: May you die of the worst disease!

paragraphs.original: Strikes him down
paragraphs.translated: She knocks him down.

paragraphs.original: Good madam, patience.
paragraphs.translated: Good madam, be patient.

paragraphs.original: What say you?
paragraphs.translated: What did you say to me?

paragraphs.original: Strikes him
paragraphs.translated: She hits him again.

paragraphs.original:
Hence, horrible villain, or I'll spurn thine eyes
Like balls before me! I'll unhair thy head!
paragraphs.translated: Get out, you horrible bastard, or I'll gouge out your eyes. I'll scalp you.

paragraphs.original: She hales him up and down
paragraphs.translated: She drags him across the stage.

paragraphs.original:
Thou shalt be whipped with wire and stewed in brine,
Smarting in ling'ring pickle!
paragraphs.translated: I'll have you whipped with wire and soaked in brine like a pickle, making your pain linger.

paragraphs.original:
Gracious madam,
I that do bring the news made not the match.
paragraphs.translated: Gracious madam, I only brought the news. I didn't make the match.

paragraphs.original:
Say 'tis not so, a province I will give thee
And make thy fortunes proud. The blow thou hadst
Shall make thy peace for moving me to rage,
And I will boot thee with what gift beside
Thy modesty can beg.
paragraphs.translated: If you say it isn't true, I'll give you a province and make you rich. The blows I gave you already will make up for your upsetting me. And on top of that I'll give you whatever you ask for.

paragraphs.original: He's married, madam.
paragraphs.translated: He's married, madam.

paragraphs.original: Rogue, thou hast lived too long.
paragraphs.translated: Rogue, you've lived too long!

paragraphs.original: Draws a knife
paragraphs.translated: She draws a knife.

paragraphs.original:
Nay then, I'll run.
What mean you, madam? I have made no fault.
paragraphs.translated: No way, then, I'll run. What's the matter with you, madam? I haven't done anything to you.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: The MESSENGER exits.

paragraphs.original:
Good madam, keep yourself within yourself.
The man is innocent.
paragraphs.translated: Good madam, restrain yourself. The man hasn't done anything wrong.

paragraphs.original:
Some innocents 'scape not the thunderbolt.
Melt Egypt into Nile, and kindly creatures
Turn all to serpents. Call the slave again.
Though I am mad, I will not bite him. Call!
paragraphs.translated: Even innocents cannot always escape disaster. May Egypt drown in the Nile and all good creatures turn into poisonous snakes. Call that servant back. Even though I'm mad, I won't bite him. Call him!

paragraphs.original: He is afeard to come.
paragraphs.translated: He's afraid to come in.

paragraphs.original:
I will not hurt him.
These hands do lack nobility that they strike
A meaner than myself, since I myself
Have given myself the cause.
paragraphs.translated: I won't hurt him. My hands are tainted if they hit an inferior, especially since I myself am the cause of my own distress.

paragraphs.original: Enter the MESSENGER again
paragraphs.translated: The MESSENGER returns.

paragraphs.original:
Come hither, sir.
Though it be honest, it is never good
To bring bad news. Give to a gracious message
An host of tongues, but let ill tidings tell
Themselves when they be felt.
paragraphs.translated: Come here, sir. It may be honest, but it's never wise to bring bad news. You can give good news in many ways, but let bad news interpret itself as you tell it.

paragraphs.original: I have done my duty.
paragraphs.translated: I've only done my duty.

paragraphs.original:
Is he married?
I cannot hate thee worser than I do
If thou again say "yes."
paragraphs.translated: Is he married? I can't hate you any more than I already do if you repeat that he is.

paragraphs.original: He's married, madam.
paragraphs.translated: He's married, madam.

paragraphs.original: The gods confound thee! Dost thou hold there still?
paragraphs.translated: May the gods destroy you! Do you maintain the same story?

paragraphs.original: Should I lie, madam?
paragraphs.translated: Do you want me to lie, madam?

paragraphs.original:
Oh, I would thou didst,
So half my Egypt were submerged and made
A cistern for scaled snakes! Go, get thee hence.
Hadst thou Narcissus in thy face, to me
Thou wouldst appear most ugly. He is married?
paragraphs.translated:
Oh, I wish you had lied, even if it meant half my kingdom would be submerged and filled with snakes. Go, get out! Even if you were as handsome as
Narcissus, your face would be ugly to me. Is he really married?
Narcissus

paragraphs.original: I crave your highness' pardon.
paragraphs.translated: I beg your highness' pardon.

paragraphs.original: He is married?
paragraphs.translated: Is he really married?

paragraphs.original:
Take no offense that I would not offend you.
To punish me for what you make me do
Seems much unequal. He's married to Octavia.
paragraphs.translated: Please don't be offended that I don't want to offend you any more. It's not fair to punish me for something you make me do. He's married to Octavia.

paragraphs.original:
Oh, that his fault should make a knave of thee,
That art not what th' art sure of! Get thee hence.
The merchandise which thou hast brought from Rome
Are all too dear for me. Lie they upon thy hand
And be undone by 'em!
paragraphs.translated: It's too bad that Antony's fault should make you look like a jerk. You didn't have anything to do with it. Go away. The merchandise you bring from Rome is too expensive for me. Let it stay in your inventory until it bankrupts you.

paragraphs.original: Exit MESSENGER
paragraphs.translated: The MESSENGER exits.

paragraphs.original: Good your highness, patience.
paragraphs.translated: Be patient, your highness.

paragraphs.original: In praising Antony, I have dispraised Caesar.
paragraphs.translated: When I have praised Antony, I've disparaged Caesar.

paragraphs.original: Many times, madam.
paragraphs.translated: Many times, madam.

paragraphs.original:
I am paid for 't now. Lead me from hence.
I faint. O Iras, Charmian! 'Tis no matter. - 
Go to the fellow, good Alexas. Bid him
Report the feature of Octavia: her years,
Her inclination. Let him not leave out
The color of her hair. Bring me word quickly.
paragraphs.translated: I'm being repaid for that now. Help me out of here. I feel faint. Oh, Iras, Charmian! It doesn't matter. Good Alexas, go ask that fellow to describe Octavia. How old is she? What kind of disposition does she have? Don't let him leave out the color of her hair. Bring me his answers quickly.

paragraphs.original: Exit ALEXAS
paragraphs.translated: ALEXAS exits.

paragraphs.original:
Let him forever go! - Let him not, Charmian.
Though he be painted one way like a Gorgon,
The other way's a Mars. (to MARDIAN ) Bid you Alexas
(to

)
Bring me word how tall she is. Pity me, Charmian,
But do not speak to me. Lead me to my chamber.
paragraphs.translated:
Let Antony be purged from my life forever - but no, don't let him, Charmian. Even though half of him is like a
Gorgon, the other half is like Mars. (to MARDIAN ) Ask Alexas to also ask him how tall she is. Feel sorry for me, Charmian, but don't talk to me. Help me get to my bedroom.
Gorgon



(to

)

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: Flourish. Enter POMPEY and MENAS at one door, with drum and trumpet; at another CAESAR, LEPIDUS, ANTONY, ENOBARBUS, MAECENAS, and AGRIPPA, with soldiers marching
paragraphs.translated: A trumpet fanfare sounds. POMPEY and MENAS enter through one stage door to the music of a drum and a trumpet. CAESAR, LEPIDUS, ANTONY, ENOBARBUS, MAECENAS, and AGRIPPA enter through another door, followed by soldiers.

paragraphs.original:
Your hostages I have, so have you mine,
And we shall talk before we fight.
paragraphs.translated:
I have your hostages and you have mine. Let's talk before we fight.
I have your hostages and you have mine. Let's talk before we fight.

paragraphs.original:
Most meet
That first we come to words, and therefore have we
Our written purposes before us sent,
Which, if thou hast considered, let us know
If 'twill tie up thy discontented sword
And carry back to Sicily much tall youth
That else must perish here.
paragraphs.translated: It's proper that we speak first, which is why we sent our proposals ahead of us for your consideration. If you've had time to think over these points, let us know whether they will relieve your frustration. If yes, then a lot of brave young men can return to Sicily who would otherwise die here.

paragraphs.original:
To you all three,
The senators alone of this great world,
Chief factors for the gods: I do not know
Wherefore my father should revengers want,
Having a son and friends, since Julius Caesar,
Who at Philippi the good Brutus ghosted,
There saw you laboring for him. What was 't
That moved pale Cassius to conspire? And what
Made the all-honored, honest Roman Brutus,
With the armed rest, courtiers of beauteous freedom,
To drench the Capitol, but that they would
Have one man but a man? And that is it
Hath made me rig my navy, at whose burden
The angered ocean foams, with which I meant
To scourge th' ingratitude that despiteful Rome
Cast on my noble father.
paragraphs.translated:
I address the three of you, the sole rulers of this world and the main arbiters of the gods' will. I don't know why my father's death shouldn't be avenged, since he has a son and friends to do it. You avenged Julius Caesar's death at Philippi, where his ghost haunted his killer, Brutus. Why did Cassius conspire against Caesar? And why did the honorable, well-intentioned Brutus and the others, men devoted to the ideal of freedom, assassinate Caesar? They didn't want one man to be king in Rome.
And that's why I've built my navy, which is so huge that the weight of the ships makes the sea foam with anger. I will punish Rome for her ingratitude toward my noble father.

paragraphs.original: Take your time.
paragraphs.translated: Take your time.

paragraphs.original:
Thou canst not fear us, Pompey, with thy sails.
We'll speak with thee at sea. At land, thou know'st
How much we do o'ercount thee.
paragraphs.translated: Pompey, you cannot frighten us with your navy. We'll meet you at sea. You know that on land our army is far greater than yours.

paragraphs.original:
At land indeed
Thou dost o'ercount me of my father's house,
But since the cuckoo builds not for himself,
Remain in 't as thou mayst.
paragraphs.translated:
Yes, on land you do outnumber me. Even more since you annexed my father's house and lands. But since,
like the cuckoo, you don't build anything for yourself, live in those lands as long as you can.
like the cuckoo

paragraphs.original:
Be pleased to tell us - 
For this is from the present - how you take
The offers we have sent you.
paragraphs.translated: To get back to the matter at hand, what do you think of our proposal?

paragraphs.original: There's the point.
paragraphs.translated: That's the point.

paragraphs.original:
Which do not be entreated to, but weigh
What it is worth embraced.
paragraphs.translated: Don't let us talk you into anything, but consider carefully the value of our offers.

paragraphs.original:
And what may follow,
To try a larger fortune.
paragraphs.translated: And consider the possible consequences of fighting against us, in the hopes of gaining a greater fortune.

paragraphs.original:
You have made me offer
Of Sicily, Sardinia. And I must
Rid all the sea of pirates, then, to send
Measures of wheat to Rome. This 'greed upon
To part with unhacked edges and bear back
Our targes undinted.
paragraphs.translated: You have offered me the lands of Sicily and Sardinia. In return, I must clear the sea of pirates and send tributes of wheat to Rome. If I agree to this, we may leave unharmed, with our shields undented.

paragraphs.original:
CAESAR, ANTONY, LEPIDUS
                                          That's our offer.
paragraphs.translated:
CAESAR, ANTONY, AND LEPIDUS
That's our offer.

paragraphs.original:
Know then
I came before you here a man prepared
To take this offer, but Mark Antony
Put me to some impatience. (to ANTONY ) - Though I lose
(to

)
The praise of it by telling, you must know,
When Caesar and your brother were at blows,
Your mother came to Sicily and did find
Her welcome friendly.

(to POMPEY )        I have heard it, Pompey,
          (to

)        
And am well studied for a liberal thanks
Which I do owe you.
Let me have your hand.
paragraphs.translated: Let me shake your hand.

paragraphs.original: They clasp hands
paragraphs.translated: They shake hands.

paragraphs.original: I did not think, sir, to have met you here.
paragraphs.translated: I didn't think I would see you here.

paragraphs.original:
The beds i' th' East are soft, and thanks to you,
That called me timelier than my purpose hither,
For I have gained by 't.
paragraphs.translated: The East is very seductive. I have you to thank for my trip here; I wouldn't have left Egypt otherwise, and I have benefited from it.

paragraphs.original:
(to POMPEY )          Since I saw you last
          (to

)          
There's a change upon you.

Well, I know not
What counts harsh Fortune casts upon my face,
But in my bosom shall she never come
To make my heart her vassal.
paragraphs.translated: Well, I cannot tell how my difficult life has weathered my face, but I will never let those difficulties subdue my courage.

paragraphs.original: Well met here.
paragraphs.translated: It's good we had this meeting.

paragraphs.original:
I hope so, Lepidus. Thus we are agreed.
I crave our composition may be written
And sealed between us.
paragraphs.translated: I hope it works out for the best, Lepidus. So we are in agreement. Please have the contract written up so we can all sign it.

paragraphs.original: That's the next to do.
paragraphs.translated: That's the next thing on the agenda.

paragraphs.original:
We'll feast each other ere we part, and let's
Draw lots who shall begin.
paragraphs.translated: We'll have celebration feasts for each other before we go our separate ways. Let's draw lots to see who will host the first one.

paragraphs.original: That will I, Pompey.
paragraphs.translated: I'll give the first one, Pompey.

paragraphs.original:
No, Antony, take the lot. But, first or last,
Your fine Egyptian cookery shall have
The fame. I have heard that Julius Caesar
Grew fat with feasting there.
paragraphs.translated: No, Antony. Pick one of these lots. Whether your banquet is first or last, your Egyptian cooking will make it the best. I heard that Julius Caesar got fat from all the feasting there.

paragraphs.original: You have heard much.
paragraphs.translated: You've heard a lot.

paragraphs.original: I have fair meanings, sir.
paragraphs.translated: I mean well, sir.

paragraphs.original: And fair words to them.
paragraphs.translated: I'm sure you do.

paragraphs.original:
Then so much have I heard.
And I have heard Apollodorus carried -
paragraphs.translated: I've heard a lot more. I heard that Apollodorus carried -

paragraphs.original: What, I pray you?
paragraphs.translated: What did he carry, please?

paragraphs.original: A certain queen to Caesar in a mattress.
paragraphs.translated:
A certain queen to Caesar,
rolled up in a mattress.
rolled up in a mattress

paragraphs.original: I know thee now. How far'st thou, soldier?
paragraphs.translated: Now I know who you are. How are you, soldier?

paragraphs.original:
Well,
And well am like to do, for I perceive,
Four feasts are toward.
paragraphs.translated: I'm well, and probably will be for a while, as I hear that four feasts are being prepared.

paragraphs.original:
Let me shake thy hand.
I never hated thee. I have seen thee fight
When I have envied thy behavior.
paragraphs.translated: Let me shake your hand. I've never been your enemy. I've seen you fight and envied your skill.

paragraphs.original:
Sir,
I never loved you much, but I ha' praised ye
When you have well deserved ten times as much
As I have said you did.
paragraphs.translated: Sir, I wouldn't say I was your friend, but I've praised you when you deserved ten times more praise than I gave.

paragraphs.original:
Enjoy thy plainness.
It nothing ill becomes thee. - 
Aboard my galley I invite you all.
Will you lead, lords?
paragraphs.translated: Enjoy your frankness; it suits you. I invite you all aboard my ship. After you, my lords?

paragraphs.original:
CAESAR, ANTONY, LEPIDUS
                                         Show 's the way, sir.
paragraphs.translated:
CAESAR, ANTONY, AND LEPIDUS
Show us the way, sir.

paragraphs.original: Come.
paragraphs.translated: Come with me.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt all but ENOBARBUS and MENAS
paragraphs.translated: Everyone exits except for ENOBARBUS and MENAS.

paragraphs.original:
(aside) Thy father, Pompey, would ne'er have made this
(aside)
treaty. (to ENOBARBUS ) You and I have known, sir.
(to

)
paragraphs.translated:
(to himself) Your father would never have agreed to this treaty, Pompey. (to ENOBARBUS ) You and I have met, sir.
(to himself)
(to

)

paragraphs.original: At sea, I think.
paragraphs.translated: I think it was at sea.

paragraphs.original: We have, sir.
paragraphs.translated: That it was, sir.

paragraphs.original: You have done well by water.
paragraphs.translated: You've done well at sea.

paragraphs.original: And you by land.
paragraphs.translated: And you've done well on land.

paragraphs.original: I will praise any man that will praise me, though it cannot be denied what I have done by land.
paragraphs.translated: I'll flatter anyone who flatters me - though what I've accomplished on land cannot be denied.

paragraphs.original: Nor what I have done by water.
paragraphs.translated: Neither can my accomplishments at sea.

paragraphs.original: Yes, something you can deny for your own safety: you have been a great thief by sea.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, for your own safety, you should deny one thing: you have been a great thief at sea.

paragraphs.original: And you by land.
paragraphs.translated: As you were on land.

paragraphs.original: There I deny my land service. But give me your hand, Menas.
paragraphs.translated: That's the one part of my service on land I do deny. But let's shake hands, Menas.

paragraphs.original: They clasp hands
paragraphs.translated: They shake.

paragraphs.original: If our eyes had authority, here they might take two thieves kissing.
paragraphs.translated: If our eyes were policemen, they might capture two thieves at once while we're embracing.

paragraphs.original: All men's faces are true, whatsome'er their hands are.
paragraphs.translated: Men's faces are truthful, whatever their hands do.

paragraphs.original: But there is never a fair woman has a true face.
paragraphs.translated: But no beautiful woman has an honest face.

paragraphs.original: No slander. They steal hearts.
paragraphs.translated: That's no lie. They steal hearts.

paragraphs.original: We came hither to fight with you.
paragraphs.translated: We came here to fight against you.

paragraphs.original: For my part, I am sorry it is turned to a drinking. Pompey doth this day laugh away his fortune.
paragraphs.translated: For my part, I'm sorry this battle turned into a drinking match. Today Pompey laughs away his fortune.

paragraphs.original: If he do, sure he cannot weep 't back again.
paragraphs.translated: If that's true, he won't get it back by crying.

paragraphs.original: You've said, sir. We looked not for Mark Antony here. Pray you, is he married to Cleopatra?
paragraphs.translated: That's the truth, sir. We didn't expect Mark Antony to be here. Is he married to Cleopatra?

paragraphs.original: Caesar's sister is called Octavia.
paragraphs.translated: Caesar's sister is named Octavia.

paragraphs.original: True, sir. She was the wife of Caius Marcellus.
paragraphs.translated: That's true, sir. She was previously Caius Marcellus' wife.

paragraphs.original: But she is now the wife of Marcus Antonius.
paragraphs.translated: But she is now Mark Antony's wife.

paragraphs.original: Pray ye, sir?
paragraphs.translated: Excuse me, sir?

paragraphs.original: 'Tis true.
paragraphs.translated: It's true.

paragraphs.original: Then is Caesar and he forever knit together.
paragraphs.translated: Then Caesar and he will always be united.

paragraphs.original: If I were bound to divine of this unity, I would not prophesy so.
paragraphs.translated: If I were to make a prediction regarding this union, I wouldn't say that.

paragraphs.original: I think the policy of that purpose made more in the marriage than the love of the parties.
paragraphs.translated: I think the marriage was made more for political reasons than for love.

paragraphs.original: I think so too. But you shall find the band that seems to tie their friendship together will be the very strangler of their amity. Octavia is of a holy, cold, and still conversation.
paragraphs.translated: I think so too. But you'll see that the very thing that joins them will be the thing that separates them. Octavia has a pious, chaste, meek disposition.

paragraphs.original: Who would not have his wife so?
paragraphs.translated: Doesn't everyone want a wife like that?

paragraphs.original: Not he that himself is not so, which is Mark Antony. He will to his Egyptian dish again. Then shall the sighs of Octavia blow the fire up in Caesar, and, as I said before, that which is the strength of their amity shall prove the immediate author of their variance. Antony will use his affection where it is. He married but his occasion here.
paragraphs.translated: Not someone who doesn't share that disposition, meaning Mark Antony. He'll go back to his Egyptian dish. Then Octavia's complaints will rouse Caesar, and as I said before, the thing that brought them together will part them. Antony will go where his passion is. He only married out of political necessity.

paragraphs.original: And thus it may be. Come, sir, will you aboard? I have a health for you.
paragraphs.translated: Then that's the way it may turn out. Come on, sir, will you come aboard? I want to drink your health.

paragraphs.original: I shall take it, sir. We have used our throats in Egypt.
paragraphs.translated: I'll join you, sir. We did a lot of drinking in Egypt.

paragraphs.original: Come, let's away.
paragraphs.translated: Let's go.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: Music plays. Enter two or three SERVANTS with a banquet
paragraphs.translated: Music plays. Two or three SERVANTS enter with a feast.

paragraphs.original: Here they'll be, man. Some o' their plants are ill-rooted already. The least wind i' th' world will blow them down.
paragraphs.translated: Here's where they'll end up, on the floor. Some of them are leaning already. It won't take much for them to fall over.

paragraphs.original: Lepidus is high-colored.
paragraphs.translated: Lepidus is red in the face.

paragraphs.original: They have made him drink alms-drink.
paragraphs.translated: They made him drink the leftover wine usually given to the poor.

paragraphs.original: As they pinch one another by the disposition, he cries out, "No more," reconciles them to his entreaty and himself to th' drink.
paragraphs.translated: Their various personalities grate on one another. Lepidus cries, "No more arguing!" and then when they agree he resigns himself to drink.

paragraphs.original: But it raises the greater war between him and his discretion.
paragraphs.translated: Which goes on to impede his judgment.

paragraphs.original: Why, this it is to have a name in great men's fellowship. I had as lief have a reed that will do me no service as a partisan I could not heave.
paragraphs.translated: That's what happens when you partner with great men but lack their power. I'd rather carry a reed that obviously can't protect me than a sword I cannot lift.

paragraphs.original: To be called into a huge sphere, and not to be seen to move in 't, are the holes where eyes should be, which pitifully disaster the cheeks.
paragraphs.translated: To be so unimportant in the company of important men is like having a face without any eyes.

paragraphs.original: A sennet sounded. Enter CAESAR, ANTONY, POMPEY, LEPIDUS, AGRIPPA, MAECENAS, ENOBARBUS, and MENAS, with other captains and a BOY
paragraphs.translated: A trumpet call sounds. CAESAR, ANTONY, POMPEY, LEPIDUS, AGRIPPA, MAECENAS, ENOBARBUS, and MENAS enter, along with other captains and a BOY.

paragraphs.original:
Thus do they, sir: they take the flow o' th' Nile
By certain scales i' th' Pyramid. They know
By th' height, the lowness, or the mean, if dearth
Or foison follow. The higher Nilus swells
The more it promises. As it ebbs, the seedsman
Upon the slime and ooze scatters his grain,
And shortly comes to harvest.
paragraphs.translated: This is how they do it, sir: they measure the depth of the Nile, according to certain marks made on the walls of the Pyramid. They know by those measurements if there will be famine or plenty. The higher the Nile flows, the better the harvest. As the river ebbs, the farmer scatters his seeds on the remaining silt. The harvest comes shortly after that.

paragraphs.original: You've strange serpents there?
paragraphs.translated: Do you have unusual snakes there?

paragraphs.original: Ay, Lepidus.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, Lepidus.

paragraphs.original: Your serpent of Egypt is bred now of your mud by the operation of your sun. So is your crocodile.
paragraphs.translated: The Egyptian snake is born when the sun shines on the Nile mud, just like the crocodile.

paragraphs.original: They are so.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, Lepidus.
Let's have a seat and some wine. A toast to Lepidus!

paragraphs.original: They sit and drink
paragraphs.translated: They sit and drink.

paragraphs.original: I am not so well as I should be, but I'll ne'er out.
paragraphs.translated: I don't feel so well, but I won't stop.

paragraphs.original: Not till you have slept. I fear me you'll be in till then.
paragraphs.translated: Not until you pass out. I'm afraid you'll keep going until then.

paragraphs.original: Nay, certainly, I have heard the Ptolemies' pyramises are very goodly things. Without contradiction I have heard that.
paragraphs.translated: No, I certainly won't stop. I've heard that the pyramids build by the Ptolemies are splendid. Without doubt I've heard that.

paragraphs.original:
(aside to POMPEY ) Forsake thy seat, I do beseech thee, captain,
(aside to

)
And hear me speak a word.
paragraphs.translated:
(whispers in POMPEY 's ear) Please, captain, leave the feast and let me speak with you privately.
(whispers in

's ear)

paragraphs.original: What manner o' thing is your crocodile?
paragraphs.translated: What does a crocodile look like?

paragraphs.original: It is shaped, sir, like itself, and it is as broad as it hath breadth. It is just so high as it is, and moves with its own organs. It lives by that which nourisheth it, and, the elements once out of it, it transmigrates.
paragraphs.translated:
Sir, it's shaped like itself and is as wide as it has width. It is only as high as it is and moves with its own legs. It lives on what nourishes it, and when
the four elements leave it, its soul moves into another body.
the four elements

paragraphs.original: What color is it of?
paragraphs.translated: What color is it?

paragraphs.original: Of it own color too.
paragraphs.translated: Its own color.

paragraphs.original: 'Tis a strange serpent.
paragraphs.translated: It's a strange snake.

paragraphs.original: 'Tis so. And the tears of it are wet.
paragraphs.translated: It is that. And its tears are wet.

paragraphs.original: MENAS whispers again
paragraphs.translated: MENAS whispers to POMPEY again.

paragraphs.original:
(aside to MENAS ) Go hang, sir, hang! Tell me of that? Away!
(aside to

)
Do as I bid you. - Where's this cup I called for?

(aside to POMPEY ) If for the sake of merit thou wilt hear me,
(aside to

)
Rise from thy stool.
He rises, and they walk aside
paragraphs.translated: He gets up and walks aside with MENAS.

paragraphs.original: The matter?
paragraphs.translated: What is it?

paragraphs.original: I have ever held my cap off to thy fortunes.
paragraphs.translated: I've always had great respect for your destiny.

paragraphs.original:
Thou hast served me with much faith. What's else to say? - 
(to the others) Be jolly, lords.
(to the others)
paragraphs.translated:
You've served me faithfully. What else can I say? (to the others) Be happy, lords!
(to the others)

paragraphs.original:
These quicksands, Lepidus,
Keep off them, for you sink.
paragraphs.translated: Stay away from the quicksand of drink, Lepidus: you're sinking.

paragraphs.original: What sayst thou?
paragraphs.translated: What are you saying?

paragraphs.original: Wilt thou be lord of the whole world? That's twice.
paragraphs.translated: Would you like to be king of the entire world? Now I've said it twice.

paragraphs.original: How should that be?
paragraphs.translated: How could that happen?

paragraphs.original:
But entertain it,
And, though thou think me poor, I am the man
Will give thee all the world.
paragraphs.translated: Just consider it. Though I seem poor, I am the man who will give you the world.

paragraphs.original: Hast thou drunk well?
paragraphs.translated: Are you drunk?

paragraphs.original:
No, Pompey, I have kept me from the cup.
Thou art, if thou dar'st be, the earthly Jove.
Whate'er the ocean pales or sky inclips
Is thine, if thou wilt ha 't.
paragraphs.translated: No, Pompey, I haven't had anything to drink. You can be the most powerful man on earth if you dare use your power. Both land and sea are yours if you will take them.

paragraphs.original: Show me which way.
paragraphs.translated: Tell me how.

paragraphs.original:
These three world-sharers, these competitors,
Are in thy vessel. Let me cut the cable,
And, when we are put off, fall to their throats.
All there is thine.
paragraphs.translated: The three who share the known world are aboard your boat. Let me cut the anchor cable. When we are away from land, cut their throats. Everything that belongs to them is yours.

paragraphs.original:
Ah, this thou shouldst have done
And not have spoke on 't! In me 'tis villainy,
In thee 't had been good service. Thou must know,
'Tis not my profit that does lead mine honor;
Mine honor, it. Repent that e'er thy tongue
Hath so betrayed thine act. Being done unknown,
I should have found it afterwards well done,
But must condemn it now. Desist, and drink.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, you should have done it without telling me! For me to do such a thing would be dishonorable. For you to do it would be good service. You should know that to me, profit isn't more important than honor, but the other way around. Regret that your mouth betrayed your actions. If you had acted without my knowledge, I would have approved your action later. But now I must condemn it. Give it up and go drink.

paragraphs.original: He returns to the feast
paragraphs.translated: He returns to the feast.

paragraphs.original:
(aside) For this,
(aside)
I'll never follow thy palled fortunes more.
Who seeks and will not take when once 'tis offered
Shall never find it more.
paragraphs.translated:
(to himself) For this, I'll never be faithful to your declining fortunes again. A person who wants something but won't take it when it materializes won't get the opportunity again.
(to himself)

paragraphs.original: This health to Lepidus!
paragraphs.translated: This toast is for Lepidus!

paragraphs.original:
(to a servant) Bear him ashore. - I'll pledge it for him, Pompey.
(to a servant)
paragraphs.translated:
(to a servant) Help Lepidus ashore . . . I'll accept it for him, Pompey.
(to a servant)

paragraphs.original: Here's to thee, Menas!
paragraphs.translated: Here's to you, Menas.

paragraphs.original: They drink
paragraphs.translated: They drink.

paragraphs.original: Enobarbus, welcome.
paragraphs.translated: I accept with thanks, Enobarbus.

paragraphs.original: Fill till the cup be hid.
paragraphs.translated: Fill the cups until they run over.

paragraphs.original: There's a strong fellow, Menas.
paragraphs.translated: There goes a strong fellow, Menas.

paragraphs.original: Pointing to the servant who carries off LEPIDUS
paragraphs.translated: He points to the servant carrying LEPIDUS away.

paragraphs.original: Why?
paragraphs.translated: Why do you say that?

paragraphs.original:
He bears
The third part of the world, man. Seest not?
paragraphs.translated: He carries a third of the world. Can't you see that?

paragraphs.original:
The third part, then, is drunk. Would it were all,
That it might go on wheels!
paragraphs.translated: Then a third of the world is drunk. I wish it were all drunk. Then everything would go more smoothly.

paragraphs.original: Drink thou. Increase the reels.
paragraphs.translated: Drink up. Liven up the party.

paragraphs.original: Come.
paragraphs.translated: All right, then.

paragraphs.original: This is not yet an Alexandrian feast.
paragraphs.translated: This hasn't reached the level of an Egyptian feast yet.

paragraphs.original:
It ripens towards it. Strike the vessels, ho!
Here's to Caesar.
paragraphs.translated: It's getting there. Clink your cups together in a toast! Here's to Caesar.

paragraphs.original:
I could well forbear 't.
It's monstrous labor when I wash my brain
And it grows fouler.
paragraphs.translated: I could do without another toast. It's unnatural. I keep washing my brain with alcohol, and it keeps getting fouler and more muddled.

paragraphs.original: Be a child o' th' time.
paragraphs.translated: Live in the moment.

paragraphs.original:
Possess it, I'll make answer.
But I had rather fast from all four days
Than drink so much in one.
paragraphs.translated: I'd prefer to seize the day. But I would rather abstain from everything for four days than drink so much in one.

paragraphs.original:
(to ANTONY )            Ha! My brave emperor,
              (to

)            
Shall we dance now the Egyptian bacchanals
And celebrate our drink?
paragraphs.translated:
(to ANTONY ) Ha! Shall we dance Egyptian
bacchanals, my noble emperor, and celebrate our wine?
(to

)
bacchanals

paragraphs.original: Let's ha 't, good soldier.
paragraphs.translated: Let's have one, good soldier.

paragraphs.original:
Come, let's all take hands
Till that the conquering wine hath steeped our sense
In soft and delicate Lethe.
paragraphs.translated: Come, let's join our hands until the overpowering wine makes us soft and forgetful.

paragraphs.original:
All take hands.
Make battery to our ears with the loud music,
The while I'll place you; then the boy shall sing.
The holding every man shall beat as loud
As his strong sides can volley.
paragraphs.translated: Everyone join hands. Attack our ears with loud music, and I'll position you for the dance. Then the boy will sing, and every man will sing the chorus at the top of his voice.

paragraphs.original: Music plays. ENOBARBUS places them hand in hand
paragraphs.translated: Music plays. ENOBARBUS places each man in position, hand in hand.

paragraphs.original: The Song.
paragraphs.translated: The Song.

paragraphs.original:
(Sings)     Come, thou monarch of the vine,
(Sings)    
Come, thou monarch of the vine,
               Plumpy Bacchus with pink eyne!
               Plumpy Bacchus with pink eyne!
               In thy vats our cares be drowned,
               In thy vats our cares be drowned,
               With thy grapes our hairs be crowned.
               With thy grapes our hairs be crowned.
paragraphs.translated:
(singing) Come, you king of the vine, plump Bacchus, with your pink eyes. Our troubles are drowned in your vats. We'll crown ourselves with wreathes of grapes.
(singing)

paragraphs.original:
(Singing) Cup us till the world go round,
(Singing) Cup us till the world go round,
                Cup us till the world go round!
                Cup us till the world go round!
paragraphs.translated:
(singing) Give us cups until the world spins! Give us cups until the world spins!
(singing)

paragraphs.original:
What would you more? - Pompey, good night. (to ANTONY ) Good brother,
(to

)
Let me request you off. Our graver business
Frowns at this levity. - Gentle lords, let's part.
You see we have burnt our cheeks. Strong Enobarb
Is weaker than the wine; and mine own tongue
Splits what it speaks. The wild disguise hath almost
Anticked us all. What needs more words? Good night.
Good Antony, your hand.
I'll try you on the shore.
paragraphs.translated: We'll have a rematch at your feast on shore.

paragraphs.original: And shall, sir. Give 's your hand.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, we will. Let's shake on it.

paragraphs.original:
O Antony, You have my father's house.
But what? We are friends. Come, down into the boat.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, Antony, even if you've taken my father's house, what is that to me? We're friends! Come, this way to the rowboat.

paragraphs.original: Take heed you fall not.
paragraphs.translated: Be careful not to fall in.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt all but MENAS and ENOBARBUS
paragraphs.translated: Everyone exits except MENAS and ENOBARBUS.

paragraphs.original: Menas, I'll not on shore.
paragraphs.translated: Menas, I'm not going back on shore.

paragraphs.original:
No, to my cabin. These drums, these trumpets, flutes! What!
Let Neptune hear we bid a loud farewell
To these great fellows. Sound and be hanged, sound out!
paragraphs.translated:
No, come to my cabin. We'll have the musicians play drums, trumpets, flutes. What do you say? We'll make
Neptune hear us bid a loud good night to these great men. Play and be damned. Play loud!
Neptune

paragraphs.original: Sound a flourish, with drums
paragraphs.translated: Trumpets and drums play a fanfare.

paragraphs.original: Hoo! says 'a. There's my cap.
paragraphs.translated: Hooray, I say. There's my hat!

paragraphs.original: He flings it in the air
paragraphs.translated: He throws his hat in the air.

paragraphs.original: Hoo! Noble captain, come.
paragraphs.translated: Hooray! Come on, noble captain.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter VENTIDIUS as it were in triumph, the dead body of Pacorus borne before him, with SILIUS, and other Romans, officers, and soldiers
paragraphs.translated: The dead body of Pacorus is carried in, followed by the triumphant entrance of VENTIDIUS, with SILIUS and soldiers.

paragraphs.original:
Now, darting Parthia, art thou struck, and now
Pleased fortune does of Marcus Crassus' death
Make me revenger. Bear the King's son's body
Before our army. Thy Pacorus, Orodes,
Pays this for Marcus Crassus.
paragraphs.translated:
Now I've paid you back, Parthia, and gotten revenge for Marcus Crassus' death. Carry
King Orodes' son at the front of our army, so all the Parthians will know - Orodes, Pacorus pays for Marcus Crassus!
King Orodes

paragraphs.original:
Noble Ventidius,
Whilst yet with Parthian blood thy sword is warm,
The fugitive Parthians follow. Spur through Media,
Mesopotamia, and the shelters whither
The routed fly. So thy grand captain, Antony,
Shall set thee on triumphant chariots and
Put garlands on thy head.
paragraphs.translated:
Noble Ventidius, while your sword is still warm with the blood of slain Parthians, why not finish the job? The Parthians retreat. Go after them. Chase them down if you have to track them through
Media, Mesopotamia, or any other places they may go to hide. Then our great general, Antony, will commend you.
Media, Mesopotamia

paragraphs.original:
O Silius, Silius,
I have done enough. A lower place, note well,
May make too great an act. For learn this, Silius:
Better to leave undone than by our deed
Acquire too high a fame when him we serve's away.
Caesar and Antony have ever won
More in their officer than person. Sossius,
One of my place in Syria, his lieutenant,
For quick accumulation of renown,
Which he achieved by th' minute, lost his favor.
Who does i' th' wars more than his captain can
Becomes his captain's captain; and ambition,
The soldier's virtue, rather makes choice of loss
Than gain which darkens him.
I could do more to do Antonius good,
But 'twould offend him, and in his offense
Should my performance perish.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, Silius, Silius, I've done enough. A subordinate may exceed his authority. You must understand, Silius, that it's better to leave something undone than achieve too much fame in your superior's absence. Caesar and Antony have always achieved more by delegating authority to their officers than by leading their troops in person. Sossius, an officer that held the same position in Syria as I do here, achieved great distinction very quickly but lost Antony's support as a result. A man who achieves more in war than his captain does becomes his captain's rival. Ambition is a good quality in a soldier, but it proves detrimental rather than beneficial when used to surpass his superiors. I could do more to help Antony, but to do so would insult him. And by insulting him, I would lose credit for the good I have done him already.

paragraphs.original:
Thou hast, Ventidius, that
Without the which a soldier and his sword
Grants scarce distinction. Thou wilt write to Antony?
paragraphs.translated: A soldier is just a tool, like his sword, unless he has your qualities, Ventidius. Are you going to write Antony about this?

paragraphs.original:
I'll humbly signify what in his name,
That magical word of war, we have effected:
How with his banners and his well-paid ranks
The ne'er-yet-beaten horse of Parthia
We have jaded out o' th' field.
paragraphs.translated: I'll modestly tell him what I have done in his name - that's the magical wording these days. I'll write how, under his flag and with his well-paid troops, we have beaten the formerly unvanquished Parthia.

paragraphs.original: Where is he now?
paragraphs.translated: Where's Antony now?

paragraphs.original:
He purposeth to Athens, whither, with what haste
The weight we must convey with's will permit,
We shall appear before him. (to the soliders) On, there. Pass along!
(to the soliders)
paragraphs.translated:
He plans to go to Athens. We must arrive there before him, as quickly as our baggage train will allow us. (to the soldiers) Get a move on!
(to the soldiers)

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter AGRIPPA at one door, ENOBARBUS at another
paragraphs.translated: AGRIPPA enters through one door and ENOBARBUS enters through another.

paragraphs.original: What, are the brothers parted?
paragraphs.translated: Did the brothers-in-law leave?

paragraphs.original:
They have dispatched with Pompey; he is gone.
The other three are sealing. Octavia weeps
To part from Rome. Caesar is sad, and Lepidus,
Since Pompey's feast, as Menas says, is troubled
With the greensickness.
paragraphs.translated: They finished their business with Pompey, and Pompey has left. Now the three triumvirs are putting their official seals on the treaty. Octavia weeps at the thought of leaving Rome. Caesar is in a sober mood. And Menas reports that Lepidus has been hungover since Pompey's party.

paragraphs.original: 'Tis a noble Lepidus.
paragraphs.translated:
That Lepidus is an elegant man.
That Lepidus is an elegant man.

paragraphs.original: A very fine one. Oh, how he loves Caesar!
paragraphs.translated: He's a stylish man. And how he loves Caesar!

paragraphs.original: Nay, but how dearly he adores Mark Antony!
paragraphs.translated: Yes, but how he adores Mark Antony!

paragraphs.original: Caesar? Why, he's the Jupiter of men.
paragraphs.translated:
Caesar?
He's a god of a man.
He's a god of a man.

paragraphs.original: What's Antony? The god of Jupiter.
paragraphs.translated: Then what's Antony? A god of a god?

paragraphs.original: Spake you of Caesar? How, the nonpareil!
paragraphs.translated: Are you talking about Caesar? He's without equal!

paragraphs.original: O Antony, O thou Arabian bird!
paragraphs.translated:
Oh, Antony! Oh, you
phoenix!
phoenix

paragraphs.original: Would you praise Caesar, say "Caesar." Go no further.
paragraphs.translated: If you want to praise Caesar, just say his name - that's all the praise that's necessary.

paragraphs.original: Indeed, he plied them both with excellent praises.
paragraphs.translated: He certainly flattered them both with extravagant compliments.

paragraphs.original:
But he loves Caesar best; yet he loves Antony.
Hoo! Hearts, tongues, figures, scribes, bards, poets, cannot
Think, speak, cast, write, sing, number - hoo! - 
His love to Antony. But as for Caesar,
Kneel down, kneel down, and wonder.
paragraphs.translated: He loves Caesar best, but he also loves Antony. Oh! No one can describe or fathom Lepidus' love for Antony! Hearts cannot think it, tongues cannot speak it, meas-urements cannot calculate it, scribes cannot write it, bards cannot sing it, and poets cannot make verses about it. But when it comes to Caesar, Lepidus' love approaches the awestruck wonder of a worshipper.

paragraphs.original: Both he loves.
paragraphs.translated: He loves them both.

paragraphs.original:
They are his shards, and he
their beetle.
their beetle
paragraphs.translated: They are his dung, and he their beetle.

paragraphs.original: Trumpets within
paragraphs.translated: Trumpets sound.

paragraphs.original:
So,
This is to horse. Adieu, noble Agrippa.
paragraphs.translated: So, there's the signal to ride. Good-bye, noble Agrippa.

paragraphs.original: Good fortune, worthy soldier, and farewell.
paragraphs.translated: Good luck, worthy soldier, and good-bye.

paragraphs.original: Enter CAESAR, ANTONY, LEPIDUS, and OCTAVIA
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR, ANTONY, LEPIDUS, and OCTAVIA enter.

paragraphs.original: No further, sir.
paragraphs.translated: You can't go any further with us, sir.

paragraphs.original:
You take from me a great part of myself;
Use me well in 't. - Sister, prove such a wife
As my thoughts make thee, and as my farthest bond
Shall pass on thy approof. - Most noble Antony,
Let not the piece of virtue, which is set
Betwixt us as the cement of our love,
To keep it builded, be the ram to batter
The fortress of it. For better might we
Have loved without this mean, if on both parts
This be not cherished.
paragraphs.translated:
You take an important part of myself with you. Treat it well . . . . Sister, be the kind of wife I hope you will be, and that this great contract rests upon your being . . . Gracious Antony, don't let my sister, this epitome of virtue that connects us, become the reason we separate.
If you and I don't value her equally, it would be better for us to work out our differences without her.

paragraphs.original:
Make me not offended
In your distrust.
paragraphs.translated: Don't insult me with your distrust.

paragraphs.original: I have said.
paragraphs.translated: I mean what I say.

paragraphs.original:
You shall not find,
Though you be therein curious, the least cause
For what you seem to fear. So the gods keep you
And make the hearts of Romans serve your ends.
We will here part.
paragraphs.translated: You won't find any cause for anxiety, even if you look for one. So, may the gods protect you and change the hearts of the Romans so that they turn and give you their support. We'll leave you here.

paragraphs.original:
Farewell, my dearest sister, fare thee well.
The elements be kind to thee and make
Thy spirits all of comfort! Fare thee well.
paragraphs.translated: Good-bye, my dearest sister, good-bye. I hope you have good weather to set your mind at ease. Farewell.

paragraphs.original: My noble brother!
paragraphs.translated: My noble brother!

paragraphs.original:
She weeps
She weeps
paragraphs.translated: She begins to cry.

paragraphs.original:
The April's in her eyes; it is love's spring,
And these the showers to bring it on. (to OCTAVIA ) Be cheerful.
(to

)
What, Octavia?
paragraphs.translated: What is it, Octavia?

paragraphs.original: I'll tell you in your ear.
paragraphs.translated: I'll tell you privately.

paragraphs.original:
She and CAESAR walk aside
She and

walk aside
paragraphs.translated: She and CAESAR move apart from the group, and she whispers to him.

paragraphs.original:
Her tongue will not obey her heart, nor can
Her heart inform her tongue - the swan's-down feather
That stands upon the swell at the full of tide
And neither way inclines.
paragraphs.translated: She won't say what she's feeling, and she can't understand her feelings. She's balanced uneasily, like a feather on the swell of a great wave - she won't move, even though her situation is about to change.

paragraphs.original:
(aside to ENOBARBUS )  Why, Enobarbus,
  (aside to

)
When Antony found Julius Caesar dead,
He cried almost to roaring, and he wept
When at Philippi he found Brutus slain.

(aside to AGRIPPA ) That year indeed he was troubled with a rheum.
(aside to

)
What willingly he did confound he wailed,
Believe 't, till I wept too.

(coming forward with OCTAVIA ) No, sweet Octavia,
            (coming forward with

)
You shall hear from me still. The time shall not
Outgo my thinking on you.

Come, sir, come,
I'll wrestle with you in my strength of love.
Look, here I have you.
paragraphs.translated: Come here, sir. I'll wrestle with you out of love. See, now I have you.

paragraphs.original: Embraces him
paragraphs.translated: They embrace.

paragraphs.original:
Thus I let you go
And give you to the gods.
paragraphs.translated: And thus I let you go and give you to the gods.

paragraphs.original: Adieu. Be happy.
paragraphs.translated: Good-bye. Be happy.

paragraphs.original:
(to ANTONY ) Let all the number of the stars give light
(to

)
To thy fair way.
Farewell, farewell.
paragraphs.translated: Farewell, farewell.

paragraphs.original: Kisses OCTAVIA
paragraphs.translated: He kisses OCTAVIA.

paragraphs.original: Farewell.
paragraphs.translated: Farewell.

paragraphs.original: Trumpets sound. Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: Trumpets sound a fanfare as they exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter CLEOPATRA, CHARMIAN, IRAS, and ALEXAS
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA, CHARMIAN, IRAS, and ALEXAS enter.

paragraphs.original: Where is the fellow?
paragraphs.translated: Where is that messenger?

paragraphs.original: Half afeard to come.
paragraphs.translated: He's afraid to come in.

paragraphs.original: Go to, go to. - Come hither, sir.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, come on. - Come here, sir.

paragraphs.original: Enter the MESSENGER as before
paragraphs.translated: The MESSENGER enters.

paragraphs.original:
Good majesty,
Herod of Jewry dare not look upon you
But when you are well pleased.
paragraphs.translated: Gracious Queen, even Herod of Judea wouldn't dare look at you unless you were in a good mood.

paragraphs.original:
That Herod's head
I'll have! But how? When Antony is gone,
Through whom I might command it? (to MESSENGER ) Come thou near.
(to

)
Most gracious majesty!
paragraphs.translated: Most formidable Queen!

paragraphs.original: Didst thou behold Octavia?
paragraphs.translated: Did you see Octavia?

paragraphs.original: Ay, dread Queen.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, revered Queen.

paragraphs.original: Where?
paragraphs.translated: Where?

paragraphs.original:
Madam, in Rome.
I looked her in the face, and saw her led
Between her brother and Mark Antony.
paragraphs.translated: In Rome, Madam. I saw her face as she walked with her brother and Mark Antony.

paragraphs.original: Is she as tall as me?
paragraphs.translated: Is she as tall as I am?

paragraphs.original: She is not, madam.
paragraphs.translated: She is not, madam.

paragraphs.original: Didst hear her speak? Is she shrill-tongued or low?
paragraphs.translated: Did you hear her speak? Is her voice pitched high or low?

paragraphs.original: Madam, I heard her speak. She is low-voiced.
paragraphs.translated: Madam, I heard her speak. She has a low-pitched voice.

paragraphs.original: That's not so good. He cannot like her long.
paragraphs.translated: That's not in her favor. He can't like her very long.

paragraphs.original: Like her? O Isis, 'tis impossible.
paragraphs.translated: Like her? Oh, Isis, that's impossible.

paragraphs.original:
I think so, Charmian. Dull of tongue, and dwarfish. - 
What majesty is in her gait? Remember,
If e'er thou looked'st on majesty.
paragraphs.translated: You're right, Charmian. She's both dull-spoken and dwarfishly little. - Did she carry herself with majesty? Compare her to any memory you might have of royalty.

paragraphs.original:
She creeps.
Her motion and her station are as one.
She shows a body rather than a life,
A statue than a breather.
paragraphs.translated: She creeps along. Moving or standing still, her bearing is about the same. She has a body, not a life. She's more like a statue than a living, breathing human being.

paragraphs.original: Is this certain?
paragraphs.translated: Is this true?

paragraphs.original: Or I have no observance.
paragraphs.translated: If not, then I have no powers of observation.

paragraphs.original:
Three in Egypt
Cannot make better note.
paragraphs.translated: There aren't three people in all of Egypt who could do better.

paragraphs.original:
He's very knowing,
I do perceive 't. There's nothing in her yet.
The fellow has good judgment.
paragraphs.translated: He's very observant. I can tell. She doesn't have anything going for her so far. This messenger is wise.

paragraphs.original: Excellent.
paragraphs.translated: Very wise.

paragraphs.original: Madam, she was a widow -
paragraphs.translated: She was a widow previously, madam.

paragraphs.original: Widow? Charmian, hark.
paragraphs.translated: A widow? Do you hear that, Charmian?

paragraphs.original: And I do think she's thirty.
paragraphs.translated: And I think she's at least thirty.

paragraphs.original: Bear'st thou her face in mind? Is 't long or round?
paragraphs.translated: Do you remember her face? Was it long or round?

paragraphs.original: Round, even to faultiness.
paragraphs.translated: Round enough to be unattractive.

paragraphs.original:
For the most part, too, they are foolish that are so.
Her hair, what color?
paragraphs.translated: Usually that means a person is foolish. What color is her hair?

paragraphs.original:
Brown, madam, and her forehead
As low as she would wish it.
paragraphs.translated: Brown, madam, and she wouldn't want her forehead to be any lower.

paragraphs.original:
(giving money)             There's gold for thee.
            (giving money)
Thou must not take my former sharpness ill.
I will employ thee back again; I find thee
Most fit for business. Go make thee ready;
Our letters are prepared.
paragraphs.translated: Here's gold for you. You mustn't hold my earlier outburst against me. I'll hire you again to go back to Rome. I find that you're very good at this kind of work. Go, prepare to travel. My letters are ready to go.

paragraphs.original: Exit MESSENGER
paragraphs.translated: The MESSENGER exits.

paragraphs.original: A proper man.
paragraphs.translated: He's an admirable man.

paragraphs.original:
Indeed, he is so. I repent me much
That so I harried him. Why, methinks, by him,
This creature's no such thing.
paragraphs.translated: He certainly is. I'm very sorry I was so hard on him. Why, from what he says, Octavia isn't worth getting upset over.

paragraphs.original: Nothing, madam.
paragraphs.translated: Not a bit, madam.

paragraphs.original: The man hath seen some majesty and should know.
paragraphs.translated: This man's been around royalty. He should recognize it when he sees it.

paragraphs.original:
Hath he seen majesty? Isis else defend,
And serving you so long!
paragraphs.translated: Been around royalty! Isis forbid it were otherwise, since he's been in your service so long.

paragraphs.original:
I have one thing more to ask him yet, good Charmian - 
But 'tis no matter; thou shalt bring him to me
Where I will write. All may be well enough.
paragraphs.translated: I want to ask him one more thing, Charmian. But it's not important. Bring him to my writing room. Everything may still be all right.

paragraphs.original: I warrant you, madam.
paragraphs.translated: I assure you it is, madam.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter ANTONY and OCTAVIA
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY and OCTAVIA enter.

paragraphs.original:
Nay, nay, Octavia, not only that - 
That were excusable, that and thousands more
Of semblable import - but he hath waged
New wars 'gainst Pompey; made his will, and read it
To public ear;
Spoke scantly of me; when perforce he could not
But pay me terms of honor, cold and sickly
He vented them, most narrow measure lent me.
When the best hint was given him, he not took 't,
Or did it from his teeth.
paragraphs.translated:
