No, no, Octavia, it's not only that. That would be excusable - that and a thousand other offenses like it. But Caesar has gone and waged a new war against Pompey.
He made his will and read it in a public assembly. He hardly refers to me at all, though official decisions are supposed to be made jointly. When he can't avoid mentioning my services to the state, he minimizes them as much as possible. When situations arise when it would be natural to emphasize my due credit, he either ignores them or only pays me lip service. 
He made his will and read it in a public assembly.

paragraphs.original:
O my good lord,
Believe not all, or, if you must believe,
Stomach not all. A more unhappy lady,
If this division chance, ne'er stood between,
Praying for both parts.
The good gods will mock me presently,
When I shall pray "O bless my lord and husband!"
Undo that prayer by crying out as loud
"O bless my brother!" Husband win, win brother
Prays and destroys the prayer; no midway
'Twixt these extremes at all.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, dear husband, don't believe everything you hear - or if you must believe it, don't let it all make you angry. No lady could be more miserable than I if you two disagree. I'll be left in the middle, praying for both sides. The good gods will laugh at me when on the one hand I pray for my husband and on the other for my brother. "Let my husband win!" "Let my brother win!" One prayer cancels out the other. There's no middle ground between these two extremes.

paragraphs.original:
Gentle Octavia,
Let your best love draw to that point which seeks
Best to preserve it. If I lose mine honor,
I lose myself; better I were not yours
Than yours so branchless. But, as you requested,
Yourself shall go between 's. The meantime, lady,
I'll raise the preparation of a war
Shall stain your brother. Make your soonest haste;
So your desires are yours.
paragraphs.translated: Gentle Octavia, support the one that supports you. If I'm defeated, I lose my reputation. If I lose my reputation, I lose myself. It would be better for you to have no husband than a husband who lacks honor. However, as you requested, you may go and try to negotiate with your brother. In the meantime, I'll raise an army that will surpass his. Go as soon as possible, so your prayers may be answered the sooner.

paragraphs.original:
Thanks to my lord.
The Jove of power make me most weak, most weak,
Your reconciler! Wars 'twixt you twain would be
As if the world should cleave, and that slain men
Should solder up the rift.
paragraphs.translated: Thank you, my lord. May the god of power make me, the weakest of the weak, your mediator. A war between you two would split the very world, and the bodies of your slaughtered soldiers would have to fill the chasm between.

paragraphs.original:
When it appears to you where this begins,
Turn your displeasure that way, for our faults
Can never be so equal that your love
Can equally move with them. Provide your going;
Choose your own company and command what cost
Your heart has mind to.
paragraphs.translated: When you find out who started this disagreement, turn your anger upon them. Our faults can't be so alike that you would judge us similarly. Order supplies for your trip and choose your traveling companions. Spend as much as you like.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter ENOBARBUS and EROS
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS and EROS enter.

paragraphs.original: How now, friend Eros!
paragraphs.translated: How goes it, friend Eros?

paragraphs.original: There's strange news come, sir.
paragraphs.translated: Some startling news has just arrived, sir.

paragraphs.original: What, man?
paragraphs.translated: What news, man?

paragraphs.original: Caesar and Lepidus have made wars upon Pompey.
paragraphs.translated: Caesar and Lepidus declared war against Pompey.

paragraphs.original: This is old. What is the success?
paragraphs.translated: That's old news. Who's winning?

paragraphs.original: Caesar, having made use of him in the wars 'gainst Pompey, presently denied him rivality, would not let him partake in the glory of the action, and, not resting here, accuses him of letters he had formerly wrote to Pompey; upon his own appeal seizes him. So the poor third is up, till death enlarge his confine.
paragraphs.translated: Caesar used Lepidus in the war, but as soon as it was over, Lepidus was expelled from the triumvirate. He wasn't allowed any of the glory of the victory, and he was accused of treasonous correspondence with Pompey. On the basis of Caesar's accusation alone, Lepidus was imprisoned. So the weak third of the triumvirate is imprisoned until death frees him.

paragraphs.original:
Then, world, thou hast a pair of chaps, no more,
And throw between them all the food thou hast,
They'll grind the one the other. Where's Antony?
paragraphs.translated: So now the world will only be devoured by two sets of jaws - Caesar's and Antony's. And even if you throw everything you possess to the two of them, they'll battle each other to the death to have it all. Where's Antony?

paragraphs.original:
He's walking in the garden - (imitating anger) thus, and spurns
(imitating anger)
The rush that lies before him; cries, "Fool Lepidus!"
And threats the throat of that his officer
That murdered Pompey.
paragraphs.translated:
He's walking in the garden, like this (imitating anger). And he kicks the leaves on the path, exclaiming, "Lepidus, you fool!"
Then he threatens to kill the officer who murdered Pompey.
(imitating anger).
Then he threatens to kill the officer who murdered Pompey.

paragraphs.original: Our great navy's rigged.
paragraphs.translated: Antony's grand navy is prepared.

paragraphs.original:
For Italy and Caesar. More, Domitius:
My lord desires you presently. My news
I might have told hereafter.
paragraphs.translated: To sail to Italy and Caesar. Another thing, Domitius: Antony wants to see you now. I should have waited to tell you my news.

paragraphs.original:
'Twill be naught,
But let it be. Bring me to Antony.
paragraphs.translated: It won't be that important. But never mind. Take me to Antony.

paragraphs.original: Come, sir.
paragraphs.translated: Come with me, sir.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter AGRIPPA, MECAENAS, and CAESAR
paragraphs.translated: AGRIPPA, MAECENAS, and CAESAR enter.

paragraphs.original:
Contemning Rome, he has done all this and more
In Alexandria. Here's the manner of 't:
I' th' marketplace, on a tribunal silvered,
Cleopatra and himself in chairs of gold
Were publicly enthroned. At the feet sat
Caesarion, whom they call my father's son,
And all the unlawful issue that their lust
Since then hath made between them. Unto her
He gave the stablishment of Egypt, made her
Of lower Syria, Cyprus, Lydia,
Absolute Queen.
paragraphs.translated:
In Alexandria he condemned Rome, and that's not all. This is what happened: he and Cleopatra sat on chairs of gold on a silver-covered stage in the marketplace.
Caesarion - whom they call my father's son - and all their illegitimate children sat at their feet. Antony confirmed her possession of Egypt and made her absolute Queen of lower Syria, Cyprus, and Lydia.
Caesarion - whom they call my father's son -

paragraphs.original: This in the public eye?
paragraphs.translated: He did this in public?

paragraphs.original:
I' th' common showplace, where they exercise.
His sons he there proclaimed the kings of kings:
Great Media, Parthia, and Armenia
He gave to Alexander; to Ptolemy he assigned
Syria, Cilicia, and Phoenicia. She
In th' habiliments of the goddess Isis
That day appeared, and oft before gave audience,
As 'tis reported, so.
paragraphs.translated: In the public arena, where they perform sporting events. He proclaimed his sons to be kings of kings. He gave Media, Parthia, and Armenia to Alexander. He gave Syria, Cilicia, and Phoenicia to Ptolemy. Cleopatra was dressed like the goddess Isis. They say she often attended her public functions like that.

paragraphs.original: Let Rome be thus informed.
paragraphs.translated: Let's send this news to Rome.

paragraphs.original:
Who, queasy with his insolence already,
Will their good thoughts call from him.
paragraphs.translated: The Roman people are fed up with his arrogance already. They'll abandon him completely when they hear this.

paragraphs.original:
The people knows it, and have now received
His accusations.
paragraphs.translated: The people have heard it already, and they've been told of his accusations.

paragraphs.original: Who does he accuse?
paragraphs.translated: Who does he accuse?

paragraphs.original:
Caesar, and that, having in Sicily
Sextus Pompeius spoiled, we had not rated him
His part o' th' isle. Then does he say he lent me
Some shipping, unrestored. Lastly, he frets
That Lepidus of the triumvirate
Should be deposed, and, being, that we detain
All his revenue.
paragraphs.translated: He accuses me of withholding his share of Sextus Pompeius' possessions, which we seized in Sicily. Then he says I didn't return some ships he loaned me. Finally, he criticizes the deposing of Lepidus, and then goes on to accuse me of keeping all of Lepidus' property for myself.

paragraphs.original: Sir, this should be answered.
paragraphs.translated: Sir, these accusations should be answered.

paragraphs.original:
'Tis done already, and the messenger gone.
I have told him, Lepidus was grown too cruel,
That he his high authority abused
And did deserve his change. For what I have conquered,
I grant him part; but then, in his Armenia,
And other of his conquered kingdoms, I
Demand the like.
paragraphs.translated: It has been done already, and the messenger is on his way. I answered that Lepidus had become too brutal and abused his position. For this he deserved to be deposed. As for what I seized in the wars, I granted that Antony should have a share. But I also demanded my share of his acquisitions in Armenia and the other conquered kingdoms.

paragraphs.original: He'll never yield to that.
paragraphs.translated: He'll never agree to that.

paragraphs.original: Nor must not then be yielded to in this.
paragraphs.translated: Then we won't agree to his demands.

paragraphs.original: Enter OCTAVIA with her train
paragraphs.translated: OCTAVIA enters with her attendants.

paragraphs.original: Hail, Caesar, and my lord! Hail, most dear Caesar!
paragraphs.translated: Greetings, Caesar, my lord! Greetings, dearest Caesar!

paragraphs.original: That ever I should call thee castaway!
paragraphs.translated: Oh, to think you've been rejected!

paragraphs.original: You have not called me so, nor have you cause.
paragraphs.translated: You've never thought of me like that, and you have no reason to.

paragraphs.original:
Why have you stol'n upon us thus? You come not
Like Caesar's sister. The wife of Antony
Should have an army for an usher and
The neighs of horse to tell of her approach
Long ere she did appear. The trees by th' way
Should have borne men, and expectation fainted,
Longing for what it had not. Nay, the dust
Should have ascended to the roof of heaven,
Raised by your populous troops. But you are come
A market-maid to Rome and have prevented
The ostentation of our love, which, left unshown,
Is often left unloved. We should have met you
By sea and land, supplying every stage
With an augmented greeting.
paragraphs.translated: Then why did you travel so quietly? You didn't arrive like Caesar's sister. Antony's wife should have an army to escort her, with neighing horses to announce her arrival long before she appears. The trees along the road should have been filled with eager spectators. Crowds should have been faint with excitement waiting to see you. The dust from your attending troops should have risen to heaven. But you've arrived like a common maid bringing goods to a Roman market. You've kept me from displaying my love - and when love is not shown, it's often not felt. I would have met you by sea and again by land. At each stage of your trip there would have been a more spectacular greeting.

paragraphs.original:
Good my lord,
To come thus was I not constrained, but did it
On my free will. My lord, Mark Antony,
Hearing that you prepared for war, acquainted
My grievèd ear withal, whereon I begged
His pardon for return.
paragraphs.translated: My good lord, I wasn't forced to travel like this. It was my choice. Mark Antony heard that you were preparing to wage war on him. When he gave me this news, I begged him to let me visit you.

paragraphs.original:
Which soon he granted,
Being an obstruct 'tween his lust and him.
paragraphs.translated: Which he quickly allowed, given that you're an obstacle to his lust.

paragraphs.original: Do not say so, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: Don't say that, my lord.

paragraphs.original:
I have eyes upon him,
And his affairs come to me on the wind.
Where is he now?
paragraphs.translated: I've kept track of him, and reports of his affairs arrive on every ship. Where do you think he is now?

paragraphs.original: My lord, in Athens.
paragraphs.translated: He's in Athens, my lord.

paragraphs.original:
No, my most wrongèd sister. Cleopatra
Hath nodded him to her. He hath given his empire
Up to a whore; who now are levying
The kings o' th' earth for war. He hath assembled
Bocchus, the King of Libya; Archelaus,
Of Cappadocia; Philadelphos, King
Of Paphlagonia; the Thracian king, Adallas;
King Manchus of Arabia; King of Pont;
Herod of Jewry; Mithridates, King
Of Comagen; Polemon and Amyntas,
The Kings of Mede and Lycaonia,
With a more larger list of scepters.
paragraphs.translated: No, he's not. You've been deceived. Cleopatra summoned him. He's given his empire to a whore, and now they're gathering kings to wage a war. He's recruited Bocchus, the King of Libya; Archelaus of Cappadocia; Philadelphos, King of Paphlagonia; the Thracian king, Adallas; King Manchus of Arabia; the King of Pont; Herod, of Judea; Mithridates, King of Comagen; Polemon and Amyntas, the kings of Mede and Lycaonia, and many more.

paragraphs.original:
Ay me, most wretched,
That have my heart parted betwixt two friends
That does afflict each other!
paragraphs.translated: Oh, I'm heartbroken. I'm divided between two friends who are determined to kill each other.

paragraphs.original:
Welcome hither.
Your letters did withhold our breaking forth
Till we perceived both how you were wrong led
And we in negligent danger. Cheer your heart.
Be you not troubled with the time, which drives
O'er your content these strong necessities,
But let determined things to destiny
Hold unbewailed their way. Welcome to Rome,
Nothing more dear to me. You are abused
Beyond the mark of thought, and the high gods,
To do you justice, makes his ministers
Of us and those that love you. Best of comfort,
And ever welcome to us.
paragraphs.translated: You're welcome here. I didn't write about breaking the alliance with Antony until I saw you were being misled and realized how dangerous it would be to keep postponing preparations. Cheer yourself. Don't be troubled by the present situation, the obligations of which must ruin your happiness. Don't worry about things that have already been decided by fate. Welcome home to Rome. Nothing is more precious to me than you. You have been unbelievably abused, and now the gods make us the dispensers of justice. Be comforted. You will always be welcome to me.

paragraphs.original: Welcome, lady.
paragraphs.translated: Welcome, lady.

paragraphs.original:
Welcome, dear madam.
Each heart in Rome does love and pity you.
Only th' adulterous Antony, most large
In his abominations, turns you off
And gives his potent regiment to a trull
That noises it against us.
paragraphs.translated:
Welcome, dear madam. Every heart in Rome loves and pities you.
Only the adulterous and abominable Antony abandons you, giving his power to a whore who turns that power against us.

paragraphs.original:
Most certain. Sister, welcome. Pray you
Be ever known to patience. My dear'st sister!
paragraphs.translated: It's undeniable. You are welcome here, sister. I beg you to continue to be patient. My dearest sister!

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter CLEOPATRA and ENOBARBUS
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA and ENOBARBUS enter.

paragraphs.original: I will be even with thee, doubt it not.
paragraphs.translated: I'll be straight with you. Do not doubt it.

paragraphs.original: But why, why, why?
paragraphs.translated: But why, why, why?

paragraphs.original:
Thou hast forspoke my being in these wars
And sayst it is not fit.
paragraphs.translated: You opposed my taking part in the war. You said it wasn't proper.

paragraphs.original: Well, is it, is it?
paragraphs.translated: Well, is it? Is it?

paragraphs.original:
Is 't not denounced against us? Why should not we
Be there in person?
paragraphs.translated: Isn't this war against me? Why shouldn't I be there in person?

paragraphs.original:
Well, I could reply,
If we should serve with horse and mares together,
The horse were merely lost. The mares would bear
A soldier and his horse.
paragraphs.translated: Well, I could answer that if we went to war on male and female horses alike - the male horses would be totally distracted and useless. The mares would be ridden by their riders and the male horses.

paragraphs.original: What is 't you say?
paragraphs.translated: What do you mean?

paragraphs.original:
Your presence needs must puzzle Antony,
Take from his heart, take from his brain, from 's time
What should not then be spared. He is already
Traduced for levity, and 'tis said in Rome
That Photinus, an eunuch, and your maids
Manage this war.
paragraphs.translated: Antony will necessarily be distracted by your presence. You will affect his heart and his head. You'll take up time he can't afford to lose. He's already criticized for frivolous behavior. In Rome they say that your eunuch Photinus and your maids run the war.

paragraphs.original:
Sink Rome! And their tongues rot
That speak against us! A charge we bear i' th' war,
And as the president of my kingdom will
Appear there for a man. Speak not against it.
I will not stay behind.
paragraphs.translated: Let Rome fall! May the tongues of our critics rot! I have responsibilities in this war, and as the absolute ruler of my kingdom I will carry out my duties as if I were a man. Don't argue against it. I won't stay behind.

paragraphs.original:
Enter ANTONY and CANIDIUS
Enter

and
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY and CANIDIUS enter.

paragraphs.original:
Nay, I have done.
Here comes the Emperor.
paragraphs.translated: No, I've had my say. Here comes the Emperor.

paragraphs.original:
Is it not strange, Canidius,
That from Tarentum and Brundusium
He could so quickly cut the Ionian sea
And take in Toryne? - You have heard on 't, sweet?
paragraphs.translated: Isn't it strange, Canidius, that he could cross the Ionian Sea so quickly from Tarentum and Brundusium and take Toryne? - Have you heard about this, sweet?

paragraphs.original:
Celerity is never more admired
Than by the negligent.
paragraphs.translated: No one admires speed more than the lazy.

paragraphs.original:
A good rebuke,
Which might have well becomed the best of men,
To taunt at slackness. - Canidius, we will fight
With him by sea.
paragraphs.translated: That's a good reprimand, suitable for reminding even the best of men to guard against negligence. Canidius, we'll fight him at sea.

paragraphs.original: By sea, what else?
paragraphs.translated: Of course we'll fight him by sea. What else?

paragraphs.original:
Why will
My lord do so?
paragraphs.translated: Why do you want to do that, my lord?

paragraphs.original: For that he dares us to 't.
paragraphs.translated: Because he's daring us to do it.

paragraphs.original: So hath my lord dared him to single fight.
paragraphs.translated: So you've dared him to single combat.

paragraphs.original:
Ay, and to wage this battle at Pharsalia,
Where Caesar fought with Pompey. But these offers,
Which serve not for his vantage, he shakes off,
And so should you.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, and you dared Caesar to fight the battle at Pharsalia, where he fought against Pompey. But Caesar ignores offers that don't give him an advantage, and so should you.

paragraphs.original:
Your ships are not well manned,
Your mariners are muleteers, reapers, people
Engrossed by swift impress. In Caesar's fleet
Are those that often have 'gainst Pompey fought.
Their ships are yare, yours, heavy. No disgrace
Shall fall you for refusing him at sea,
Being prepared for land.
paragraphs.translated: Your ships are not well crewed. Your sailors are mule drivers, harvesters - men who were drafted quickly and have little training. Caesar's fleet is manned by mariners who already have experience battling Pompey. His ships are maneuverable. Yours are slow and awkward. Refusing to fight him at sea won't disgrace you. You've prepared for a land war.

paragraphs.original: By sea, by sea.
paragraphs.translated: I will fight by sea. By sea.

paragraphs.original:
Most worthy sir, you therein throw away
The absolute soldiership you have by land,
Distract your army, which doth most consist
Of war-marked footmen, leave unexecuted
Your own renownèd knowledge, quite forego
The way which promises assurance, and
Give up yourself merely to chance and hazard
From firm security.
paragraphs.translated: Most worthy sir, if you do that you throw away all the advantages you have on land. You will have to divide your army, which mostly consists of battle-hardened foot soldiers. You will be unable to use your legendary battle knowledge. You'll be abandoning proven methods that promise victory, and instead you'll put yourself at the mercy of haphazard chance.

paragraphs.original: I'll fight at sea.
paragraphs.translated: I'll fight at sea.

paragraphs.original: I have sixty sails, Caesar none better.
paragraphs.translated: I have sixty ships. Caesar doesn't have any that are better.

paragraphs.original:
Our overplus of shipping will we burn,
And with the rest full-manned, from th' head of Actium
Beat th' approaching Caesar. But if we fail,
We then can do 't at land.
paragraphs.translated: We'll burn our surplus ships and fully man the rest. We'll sail from Actium and beat Caesar as he approaches. Even if we fail at that, we can still fight him on land.

paragraphs.original: Enter a MESSENGER
paragraphs.translated: A MESSENGER enters.

paragraphs.original: Thy business?
paragraphs.translated: What's your business?

paragraphs.original:
The news is true, my lord. He is descried.
Caesar has taken Toryne.
paragraphs.translated: The news is true, my lord. Caesar has been seen. He has captured Toryne.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original:
Can he be there in person? 'Tis impossible,
Strange that his power should be. Canidius,
Our nineteen legions thou shalt hold by land,
And our twelve thousand horse. We'll to our ship.
Away, my Thetis!
paragraphs.translated:
Can Caesar be there in person? No, that's impossible. It's strange enough that his army should be there. Canidius, take our nineteen
legions and twelve thousand horse soldiers. You must hold them on land. We'll go to our ship. Come away, Cleopatra.
legions

paragraphs.original: Enter a SOLDIER
paragraphs.translated: A SOLDIER enters.

paragraphs.original: How now, worthy soldier?
paragraphs.translated: What's the news, brave soldier?

paragraphs.original:
O noble Emperor, do not fight by sea!
Trust not to rotten planks. Do you misdoubt
This sword and these my wounds? Let th' Egyptians
And the Phoenicians go a-ducking. We
Have used to conquer standing on the earth
And fighting foot to foot.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, don't fight by sea, noble Emperor! Don't trust rotten planks. Don't you trust my sword and these wounds? Let the Egyptians and Phoenicians go swimming. We are used to winning by standing on the earth and fighting toe to toe.

paragraphs.original: Well, well, away.
paragraphs.translated: Well, well, let's go.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt ANTONY, CLEOPATRA, and ENOBARBUS
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY, CLEOPATRA, and ENOBARBUS exit.

paragraphs.original: By Hercules, I think I am i' th' right.
paragraphs.translated: By Hercules, I think I'm right.

paragraphs.original:
Soldier, thou art; but his whole action grows
Not in the power on 't. So our leader's led,
And we are women's men.
paragraphs.translated: Soldier, you are. But Antony's decisions aren't coming from his extensive experience. Our leader is being led. We are following a woman.

paragraphs.original:
You keep by land
The legions and the horse whole, do you not?
paragraphs.translated: On land you keep the legions and cavalry together, don't you?

paragraphs.original:
Marcus Octavius, Marcus Justeius,
Publicola, and Caelius, are for sea;
But we keep whole by land. This speed of Caesar's
Carries beyond belief.
paragraphs.translated: Marcus Octavius, Marcus Justeius, Publicola, and Caelius will go by sea, but we'll keep the bulk on land. Caesar's speed defies belief.

paragraphs.original:
While he was yet in Rome
His power went out in such distractions as
Beguiled all spies.
paragraphs.translated: While he was still in Rome, he deployed his forces in so many different disguises that all our spies were fooled.

paragraphs.original: Who's his lieutenant, hear you?
paragraphs.translated: Who's his lieutenant, do you know?

paragraphs.original: They say, one Taurus.
paragraphs.translated: A man named Taurus, they say.

paragraphs.original: Well I know the man.
paragraphs.translated: I know the man well.

paragraphs.original: Enter a MESSENGER
paragraphs.translated: A MESSENGER enters.

paragraphs.original: The Emperor calls Canidius.
paragraphs.translated: The Emperor is calling for Canidius.

paragraphs.original:
With news the time's with labor, and throws forth
Each minute some.
paragraphs.translated: The present time is like a woman in labor, each minute giving birth to some piece of news.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter CAESAR with his army, and TAURUS, marching
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR enters with TAURUS and his army.

paragraphs.original: Taurus!
paragraphs.translated: Taurus!

paragraphs.original: My lord?
paragraphs.translated: My lord?

paragraphs.original:
Strike not by land; keep whole. Provoke not battle
Till we have done at sea. Do not exceed
The prescript of this scroll.
paragraphs.translated: Don't attack by land. Keep the army together. Don't provoke them to battle until we have finished at sea. Don't exceed your orders as written here.

paragraphs.original: He gives a scroll
paragraphs.translated: He hands TAURUS a scroll.

paragraphs.original:
Our fortune lies
Upon this jump.
paragraphs.translated: Our fate depends on this chance.

paragraphs.original: Exit with army
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter ANTONY and ENOBARBUS
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY and ENOBARBUS enter.

paragraphs.original:
Set we our squadrons on yond side o' th' hill,
In eye of Caesar's battle, from which place
We may the number of the ships behold
And so proceed accordingly.
paragraphs.translated: Assemble our squadrons on the other side of the hill, in sight of Caesar's navy. From there we'll be able to see how many ships he has and plan accordingly.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: CANIDIUS marcheth with his land army one way over the stage, and TAURUS, the lieutenant of CAESAR, the other way. After their going in is heard the noise of a sea fight
paragraphs.translated: CANIDIUS and his army marches one way across the stage while CAESAR's lieutenant, TAURUS, marches across the other way. After the two armies march off stage, the noise of a battle at sea is heard.

paragraphs.original: Alarum. Enter ENOBARBUS
paragraphs.translated: Trumpets sound a retreat. ENOBARBUS enters.

paragraphs.original:
Naught, naught, all naught! I can behold no longer.
Th' Antoniad, the Egyptian admiral,
Antoniad
With all their sixty, fly and turn the rudder.
To see 't mine eyes are blasted.
paragraphs.translated:
We're ruined, ruined, ruined! I can't watch any more. The Egyptian flagship, the Antoniad, followed by all sixty Egyptian ships, has turned and fled. It destroyed my eyes to look upon it.
Antoniad,

paragraphs.original: Enter SCARUS
paragraphs.translated: SCARUS enters.

paragraphs.original:
Gods and goddesses,
All the whole synod of them!
paragraphs.translated: Gods and goddesses - the whole congregation of them!

paragraphs.original: What's thy passion?
paragraphs.translated: What's wrong with you?

paragraphs.original:
The greater cantle of the world is lost
With very ignorance. We have kissed away
Kingdoms and provinces.
paragraphs.translated: We have lost a major portion of the world through utter foolishness. We have kissed away entire kingdoms and provinces.

paragraphs.original: How appears the fight?
paragraphs.translated: How goes the battle?

paragraphs.original:
On our side like the tokened pestilence,
Where death is sure. Yon ribaudred nag of Egypt - 
Whom leprosy o'ertake! - i' th' midst o' th' fight,
When vantage like a pair of twins appeared
Both as the same, or rather ours the elder,
The breeze upon her, like a cow in June,
Hoists sails and flies.
paragraphs.translated: Our side shows all the signs of certain defeat, which appear like the symptomatic sores of the plague. Right in the middle of the fight, just when the battle could have gone either way - actually we had a slight advantage - that immoral Egyptian nag - May she die of leprosy! - suddenly became frightened, and turned her ships around and fled.

paragraphs.original:
That I beheld.
Mine eyes did sicken at the sight and could not
Endure a further view.
paragraphs.translated: I saw that. The sight made me so sick I couldn't watch any more.

paragraphs.original:
She once being loofed,
The noble ruin of her magic, Antony,
Claps on his sea-wing and, like a doting mallard
Leaving the fight in height, flies after her.
I never saw an action of such shame.
Experience, manhood, honor, ne'er before
Did violate so itself.
paragraphs.translated: Once she had turned around, the noble Antony, ruined by love, hoisted his own sails and followed her like a lovesick duck. He left the battle at the most crucial point. I never saw such a shameful act. He betrayed his own experience, manhood, and honor.

paragraphs.original: Alack, alack!
paragraphs.translated: Terrible. Terrible.

paragraphs.original: Enter CANIDIUS
paragraphs.translated: CANIDIUS enters.

paragraphs.original:
Our fortune on the sea is out of breath
And sinks most lamentably. Had our general
Been what he knew himself, it had gone well.
Oh, he has given example for our flight
Most grossly by his own!
paragraphs.translated: The battle on the sea is almost lost. If our general had been his old self, we would have won. Oh, with his sordid desertion, he sets the example for our own.

paragraphs.original: Ay, are you thereabouts? Why then, good night indeed.
paragraphs.translated: Are you considering desertion, as well? Then everything must really be finished.

paragraphs.original: Toward Peloponnesus are they fled.
paragraphs.translated: They fled toward Peloponnesus.

paragraphs.original:
'Tis easy to 't, and there I will attend
What further comes.
paragraphs.translated: It's easy to get there. I'll go there and ascertain their next move.

paragraphs.original: He exits
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original:
To Caesar will I render
My legions and my horse. Six kings already
Show me the way of yielding.
paragraphs.translated: I'll yield my legions and cavalry to Caesar. In this, I follow the examples of the six kings who have already surrendered.

paragraphs.original: He exits
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original:
I'll yet follow
The wounded chance of Antony, though my reason
Sits in the wind against me.
paragraphs.translated: I'll still follow Antony, even though the odds are against him and good sense tells me I should go the other way.

paragraphs.original: He exits
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: Enter ANTONY with attendants
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY enters with attendants.

paragraphs.original:
Hark. The land bids me tread no more upon 't.
It is ashamed to bear me. Friends, come hither.
I am so lated in the world that I
Have lost my way forever. I have a ship
Laden with gold. Take that, divide it. Fly
And make your peace with Caesar.
paragraphs.translated: Listen. The earth tells me to stop walking upon it, as it's ashamed to carry me. Friends, come here. I'm completely lost. I have a ship full of treasure. Take that. Divide it. Escape and make peace with Caesar.

paragraphs.original: Fly? Not we.
paragraphs.translated: Flee? Not us.

paragraphs.original:
I have fled myself, and have instructed cowards
To run and show their shoulders. Friends, begone.
I have myself resolved upon a course
Which has no need of you. Begone.
My treasure's in the harbor. Take it. Oh,
I followed that I blush to look upon!
My very hairs do mutiny, for the white
Reprove the brown for rashness, and they them
For fear and doting. Friends, begone. You shall
Have letters from me to some friends that will
Sweep your way for you. Pray you, look not sad,
Nor make replies of loathness. Take the hint
Which my despair proclaims. Let that be left
Which leaves itself. To the seaside straightway!
I will possess you of that ship and treasure.
Leave me, I pray, a little. Pray you now,
Nay, do so, for indeed I have lost command.
Therefore I pray you. I'll see you by and by.
paragraphs.translated: I have already fled from my true self. I've told cowards to turn their backs on me and run. Friends, go. I've decided on a plan that doesn't require your assistance. Leave. My treasure's in the harbor; take it. Oh, I followed something I'm ashamed to look at now! Even my hair revolts. The white hairs blame the brown hairs for being irresponsible, and the brown ones blame the white ones for being spineless and foolish. Friends, go. I'll give you letters of introduction to some friends of mine who will help you. Please, don't be sad, and don't tell me how reluctant you are. Take your cues from my own despair. Abandon the person that has abandoned himself. Go to the harbor immediately! I'll give you the title to that ship and its treasure. Just give me a moment, please - only a moment. I've relinquished my authority, so please - I'll see you all before long.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt attendants. ANTONY sits down
paragraphs.translated: The attendants exit. ANTONY sits.

paragraphs.original: Enter CLEOPATRA, led by CHARMIAN, IRAS, and EROS
paragraphs.translated: CHARMIAN, IRAS, and EROS enter, supporting CLEOPATRA.

paragraphs.original: Nay, gentle madam, to him, comfort him.
paragraphs.translated: No, gentle madam, go. Comfort him.

paragraphs.original: Do, most dear Queen.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, do, dearest Queen.

paragraphs.original: Do. Why, what else?
paragraphs.translated: Of course you must comfort him! What else?

paragraphs.original: Let me sit down. O Juno!
paragraphs.translated:
Let me sit down. Oh,
Juno!
Juno

paragraphs.original: She sits
paragraphs.translated: She sits.

paragraphs.original: See you here, sir?
paragraphs.translated: Do you see her, sir?

paragraphs.original: Oh, fie, fie, fie!
paragraphs.translated: Oh, damn, damn, damn!

paragraphs.original: Madam!
paragraphs.translated: Madam!

paragraphs.original: Madam, O good Empress!
paragraphs.translated: Madam, oh, good Empress!

paragraphs.original: Sir, sir -
paragraphs.translated: Sir . . . sir . . .

paragraphs.original:
(aside) Yes, my lord, yes. He at Philippi kept
(aside)
His sword e'en like a dancer, while I struck
The lean and wrinkled Cassius, and 'twas I
That the mad Brutus ended. He alone
Dealt on lieutenantry, and no practice had
In the brave squares of war, yet now - no matter.
paragraphs.translated:
(to himself) Yes, my lord, that's true. At Philippi, Caesar kept his sword in its sheath, like a dancer, while I commanded the armies that conquered Cassius and Brutus. Caesar fought only through lieutenants. He had no experience with the brave contests of war. But now . . . never mind.
(to himself)

paragraphs.original: Ah, stand by.
paragraphs.translated: Ah, give us some privacy.

paragraphs.original: The Queen, my lord, the Queen.
paragraphs.translated: The Queen is here, my lord.

paragraphs.original:
Go to him, madam, speak to him.
He is unqualitied with very shame.
paragraphs.translated: Go to him, madam, speak to him. He's not himself because he feels so ashamed.

paragraphs.original: Well then, sustain me. Oh!
paragraphs.translated: Well, then, help me.

paragraphs.original: She rises
paragraphs.translated: Her attendants help her to stand.

paragraphs.original:
Most noble sir, arise. The Queen approaches.
Her head's declined, and death will seize her but
Your comfort makes the rescue.
paragraphs.translated: Most noble sir, stand up. The Queen is coming. She's weak and will die unless you comfort her.

paragraphs.original:
I have offended reputation,
A most unnoble swerving.
paragraphs.translated: I've destroyed my reputation, a most shameful error.

paragraphs.original: Sir, the Queen.
paragraphs.translated: Sir, here's the Queen.

paragraphs.original:
Oh, whither hast thou led me, Egypt? See
How I convey my shame out of thine eyes
By looking back what I have left behind
'Stroyed in dishonor.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, where have you led me, Egypt? See how I hide my shame from you by turning around? I look behind me to see my past, destroyed by dishonor.

paragraphs.original:
O my lord, my lord,
Forgive my fearful sails! I little thought
You would have followed.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, my lord, my lord, forgive my panic! I didn't think you would follow me.

paragraphs.original:
Egypt, thou knew'st too well
My heart was to thy rudder tied by th' strings,
And thou shouldst tow me after. O'er my spirit
Thy full supremacy thou knew'st, and that
Thy beck might from the bidding of the gods
Command me.
paragraphs.translated: Queen, you knew very well that my heart was tied to your ship and that you would pull me along with you. You knew that my spirit was completely under your control and that I would ignore the gods' orders in favor of yours.

paragraphs.original: Oh, my pardon!
paragraphs.translated: Oh, forgive me!

paragraphs.original:
Now I must
To the young man send humble treaties, dodge
And palter in the shifts of lowness, who
With half the bulk o' th' world played as I pleased,
Making and marring fortunes. You did know
How much you were my conqueror, and that
My sword, made weak by my affection, would
Obey it on all cause.
paragraphs.translated: Now I will have to send my humble proposal of peace to that young man. I've done as I pleased with half the world, making and losing fortunes, but now I negotiate from a position of weakness. You knew how far you had conquered my spirit. You knew that my sword, weakened by my love for you, would obey that love no matter what.

paragraphs.original: Pardon, pardon!
paragraphs.translated: Forgive me! Forgive me!

paragraphs.original:
Fall not a tear, I say. One of them rates
All that is won and lost. Give me a kiss.
paragraphs.translated: Don't shed even one tear. One of your tears is worth everything that was won and lost. Give me a kiss.

paragraphs.original: They kiss
paragraphs.translated: They kiss.

paragraphs.original:
Even this repays me. - 
We sent our schoolmaster. Is he come back? - 
Love, I am full of lead. - (calling) Some wine,
(calling)
Within there, and our viands! Fortune knows
We scorn her most when most she offers blows.
paragraphs.translated:
This repays me. I sent our children's schoolmaster to Caesar with our offer. Has he returned? Love, I am full of heaviness. (calling) Servants, bring some wine and food! We have the most contempt for fortune when it goes against us.
(calling)

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter CAESAR, AGRIPPA, THIDIAS, and DOLABELLA, with others
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR, AGRIPPA, THIDIAS, and DOLABELLA enter, with others of the court.

paragraphs.original:
Let him appear that's come from Antony.
Know you him?
paragraphs.translated: Let the envoy from Antony come in. Do you know him?

paragraphs.original:
Caesar, 'tis his schoolmaster - 
An argument that he is plucked, when hither
He sends so poor a pinion of his wing,
Which had superfluous kings for messengers
Not many moons gone by.
paragraphs.translated: It's Antony's schoolmaster. By sending such an insignificant emissary, Antony shows us how low he has sunk. Not so long ago, he had so many royal supporters that he sent along extra kings as messengers.

paragraphs.original: Enter AMBASSADOR from Antony
paragraphs.translated: Antony's AMBASSADOR enters.

paragraphs.original: Approach and speak.
paragraphs.translated: Come forward and speak.

paragraphs.original:
Such as I am, I come from Antony.
I was of late as petty to his ends
As is the morn-dew on the myrtle leaf
To his grand sea.
paragraphs.translated: Humble as I am, I represent Antony. Until recently, I was as unimportant to his affairs as the morning dew is to the wide ocean.

paragraphs.original: Be 't so. Declare thine office.
paragraphs.translated: So be it. Say what you're here for.

paragraphs.original:
Lord of his fortunes he salutes thee, and
Requires to live in Egypt; which not granted,
He lessens his requests, and to thee sues
To let him breathe between the heavens and earth
A private man in Athens. This for him.
Next, Cleopatra does confess thy greatness,
Submits her to thy might, and of thee craves
The circle of the Ptolemies for her heirs,
Now hazarded to thy grace.
paragraphs.translated: He acknowledges that you are the master of his fate, and he requests to be allowed to live in Egypt. If that is not granted, he reduces his requests and asks only that he be allowed to live as a private man in Athens. That's all he asks for himself. Cleopatra recognizes your greatness and accepts your authority. She only asks that the crown of Egypt pass to her heirs, who are now at your mercy.

paragraphs.original:
For Antony,
I have no ears to his request. The Queen
Of audience nor desire shall fail, so she
From Egypt drive her all-disgracèd friend
Or take his life there. This if she perform,
She shall not sue unheard. So to them both.
paragraphs.translated: As for Antony, I'm not interested in his requests. I'll give the Queen a hearing and grant her requests if she either throws her dishonored friend out of Egypt or kills him. Then I'll listen to her. Give my answer to them both.

paragraphs.original: Fortune pursue thee!
paragraphs.translated: May good luck follow you!

paragraphs.original: Bring him through the bands.
paragraphs.translated: Take him safely through the lines.

paragraphs.original: Exit AMBASSADOR, attended
paragraphs.translated: The AMBASSADOR exits.

paragraphs.original:
(to THIDIAS ) To try thy eloquence now 'tis time. Dispatch.
(to

)
From Antony win Cleopatra. Promise,
And in our name, what she requires. Add more,
From thine invention, offers. Women are not
In their best fortunes strong, but want will perjure
The ne'er-touched vestal. Try thy cunning, Thidias.
Make thine own edict for thy pains, which we
Will answer as a law.
paragraphs.translated:
(to THIDIAS ) Now it's time to test your eloquence. On your way. Separate Cleopatra from Antony. In my name, promise to fulfill her petitions. You can make up additional offers, if necessary. Women aren't strong, even at their best. Hardship will make even a
vestal abandon her vows. Use your ingenuity, Thidias. You can make your own conditions, which I will authorize as law.
(to

)
vestal

paragraphs.original: Caesar, I go.
paragraphs.translated: I go, Caesar.

paragraphs.original:
Observe how Antony becomes his flaw,
And what thou think'st his very action speaks
In every power that moves.
paragraphs.translated: Observe how Antony takes his defeat and how his attitude influences his actions.

paragraphs.original: Caesar, I shall.
paragraphs.translated: I will, Caesar.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter CLEOPATRA, ENOBARBUS, CHARMIAN, and IRAS
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA, ENOBARBUS, CHARMIAN, and IRAS enter.

paragraphs.original: What shall we do, Enobarbus?
paragraphs.translated: What are we going to do, Enobarbus?

paragraphs.original: Think and die.
paragraphs.translated: Think about our situation, then die.

paragraphs.original: Is Antony or we in fault for this?
paragraphs.translated: Who is to blame for this: Antony or I?

paragraphs.original:
Antony only, that would make his will
Lord of his reason. What though you fled
From that great face of war, whose several ranges
Frighted each other? Why should he follow?
The itch of his affection should not then
Have nicked his captainship at such a point
When half to half the world opposed, he being
The merèd question. 'Twas a shame no less
Than was his loss, to course your flying flags
And leave his navy gazing.
paragraphs.translated: Only Antony was at fault. He put his desire in charge of his reason. So what if you ran from the battle, terrified, as ranks of ships threatened one another? Why should he have followed you? With half the world opposing the other half, it wasn't the time for Antony, the pivotal player, to let love distract him. To race after your departing ships, leaving his navy to watch, was a shame as great as the resulting loss.

paragraphs.original: Prithee, peace.
paragraphs.translated: Please, let's not talk about it.

paragraphs.original: Enter AMBASSADOR with ANTONY
paragraphs.translated: The AMBASSADOR and ANTONY enter.

paragraphs.original: Is that his answer?
paragraphs.translated: Is that his answer?

paragraphs.original: Ay, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, my lord.

paragraphs.original:
The Queen shall then have courtesy, so she
Will yield us up?
paragraphs.translated: The Queen will be treated fairly if she gives me up?

paragraphs.original: He says so.
paragraphs.translated: That's what he says.

paragraphs.original:
Let her know 't. - 
(to CLEOPATRA ) To the boy Caesar send this grizzled head,
(to

)
And he will fill thy wishes to the brim
With principalities.
That head, my lord?
paragraphs.translated: Your head, my lord?

paragraphs.original:
(to the AMBASSADOR ) To him again. Tell him he wears the rose
(to the

)
Of youth upon him, from which the world should note
Something particular. His coin, ships, legions,
May be a coward's, whose ministers would prevail
Under the service of a child as soon
As i' th' command of Caesar. I dare him therefore
To lay his gay caparisons apart
And answer me declined, sword against sword,
Ourselves alone. I'll write it. Follow me.
Exeunt ANTONY and AMBASSADOR
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY and the AMBASSADOR exit.

paragraphs.original:
(aside) Yes, like enough, high-battled Caesar will
(aside)
Unstate his happiness and be staged to th' show
Against a sworder! I see men's judgments are
A parcel of their fortunes, and things outward
Do draw the inward quality after them
To suffer all alike. That he should dream,
Knowing all measures, the full Caesar will
Answer his emptiness! Caesar, thou hast subdued
His judgment too.
paragraphs.translated:
(aside) Oh, that's likely! Caesar, the great commander of troops, will surely risk all he has gained in order to fight this gladiator in the public square! I see that men's judgments are tied to their fortunes, and that external factors influence a man's internal qualities, making everything suffer. How could Antony, knowing how luck stood on either side, still imagine that Caesar would respond to his nonsense! Caesar, you've conquered his judgment too.
(aside)

paragraphs.original: Enter a SERVANT
paragraphs.translated: A SERVANT enters.

paragraphs.original: A messenger from Caesar.
paragraphs.translated: A messenger has arrived from Caesar.

paragraphs.original:
What, no more ceremony? See, my women,
Against the blown rose may they stop their nose,
That kneeled unto the buds. - Admit him, sir.
paragraphs.translated: With no more ceremony than that? See, ladies, how they scorn me now. They pinch their noses to avoid smelling the dying rose whose scent, as a bud, they happily inhaled. Show him in, sir.

paragraphs.original: Exit SERVANT
paragraphs.translated: The SERVANT exits.

paragraphs.original:
(aside) Mine honesty and I begin to square.
(aside)
The loyalty well held to fools does make
Our faith mere folly. Yet he that can endure
To follow with allegiance a fall'n lord
Does conquer him that did his master conquer
And earns a place i' th' story.
paragraphs.translated:
(aside) My integrity and I begin to contradict each other. Being loyal to a fool makes loyalty foolish. But a person who can bear to keep his allegiance to a defeated lord defeats his lord's conqueror and earns a place in history.
(aside)

paragraphs.original: Enter THIDIAS
paragraphs.translated: THIDIAS enters.

paragraphs.original: Caesar's will?
paragraphs.translated: What does Caesar want?

paragraphs.original: Hear it apart.
paragraphs.translated: It is for your ears only.

paragraphs.original: None but friends. Say boldly.
paragraphs.translated: There are only friends here. Speak confidently.

paragraphs.original: So haply are they friends to Antony.
paragraphs.translated: So they are possibly Antony's friends.

paragraphs.original:
He needs as many, sir, as Caesar has,
Or needs not us. If Caesar please, our master
Will leap to be his friend. For us, you know
Whose he is we are, and that is Caesar's.
paragraphs.translated: Sir, he should have as many as Caesar has. If he had that many friends, then he wouldn't need us. If Caesar chose, Antony would jump at the chance to be his friend. As for us, you know we are Antony's, and he is Caesar's.

paragraphs.original:
So. - 
Thus then, thou most renowned: Caesar entreats
Not to consider in what case thou stand'st,
Further than he is Caesar.
paragraphs.translated: So be it. This, then, this is the message Caesar sends to you, famous Queen: he implores you not to be concerned about your situation. Just remember that he is Caesar.

paragraphs.original: Go on. Right royal.
paragraphs.translated: Respectfully put. Go on.

paragraphs.original:
He knows that you embrace not Antony
As you did love, but as you feared him.
paragraphs.translated: He knows that you didn't embrace Antony because you loved him, but because you feared him.

paragraphs.original: Oh!
paragraphs.translated: Oh!

paragraphs.original:
The scars upon your honor therefore he
Does pity as constrainèd blemishes,
Not as deserved.
paragraphs.translated: So he regrets that any dishonorable acts were forced on you, not being performed of your own free will.

paragraphs.original:
He is a god and knows
What is most right. Mine honor was not yielded,
But conquered merely.
paragraphs.translated: He is like a god and knows the truth. My honor wasn't given; it was only dominated.

paragraphs.original:
(aside) To be sure of that,
(aside)
I will ask Antony. Sir, sir, thou art so leaky
That we must leave thee to thy sinking, for
Thy dearest quit thee.
paragraphs.translated:
(aside) I'll go get the truth of this from Antony. Sir, sir, are you so badly off that we must abandon you to your fate? Even your dearest friend has abandoned you.
(aside)

paragraphs.original: Exit ENOBARBUS
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS exits.

paragraphs.original:
Shall I say to Caesar
What you require of him? For he partly begs
To be desired to give. It much would please him
That of his fortunes you should make a staff
To lean upon. But it would warm his spirits
To hear from me you had left Antony
And put yourself under his shroud,
The universal landlord.
paragraphs.translated: Shall I tell Caesar what you request from him? He almost begs for the opportunity to help you. It would please him very much if you would rely on his wealth and success to support you. But he would feel even better if I could tell him that you had left Antony and put yourself under his protection.

paragraphs.original: What's your name?
paragraphs.translated: What's your name?

paragraphs.original: My name is Thidias.
paragraphs.translated: My name is Thidias.

paragraphs.original:
Most kind messenger,
Say to great Caesar this in deputation:
I kiss his conqu'ring hand. Tell him I am prompt
To lay my crown at 's feet, and there to kneel.
Tell him, from his all-obeying breath I hear
The doom of Egypt.
paragraphs.translated: Most kind messenger, tell great Caesar that through his deputy I kiss his conquering hand. Tell him I am ready to lay my crown at his feet and kneel before him. Tell him - whose decrees are obeyed by the whole world - that I will accept the fate he chooses for Egypt.

paragraphs.original:
'Tis your noblest course.
Wisdom and fortune combating together,
If that the former dare but what it can,
No chance may shake it. Give me grace to lay
My duty on your hand.
paragraphs.translated: That's your most dignified course of action. When confronted with the choice between a prudent action and a risky one, a wise man should dare to do only what he can practically accomplish - if he follows this course, he will never be subjected to unpredictable chance. Allow me to pay my respects by kissing your hand.

paragraphs.original: He kisses her hand
paragraphs.translated: He kisses her hand.

paragraphs.original:
Your Caesar's father oft,
When he hath mused of taking kingdoms in,
Bestowed his lips on that unworthy place
As it rained kisses.
paragraphs.translated: When Octavius Caesar's father thought about conquering kingdoms, he rained kisses on my unworthy hand.

paragraphs.original: Enter ANTONY and ENOBARBUS
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY and ENOBARBUS enter.

paragraphs.original:
Favors? By Jove that thunders!
What art thou, fellow?
paragraphs.translated: Promising favors? By Jove that thunders! Who are you, slave?

paragraphs.original:
One that but performs
The bidding of the fullest man, and worthiest
To have command obeyed.
paragraphs.translated: A person who merely follows the orders of the best man, the man most worthy of service.

paragraphs.original: You will be whipped.
paragraphs.translated: You will be whipped.

paragraphs.original:
(calling for servants) Approach, there! (to THIDIAS ) Ah, you kite! - Now, gods and devils!
(calling for servants)
(to

)
Authority melts from me. Of late, when I cried "Ho!"
Like boys unto a muss kings would start forth
And cry, "Your will?" (calling to servants) Have you no ears? I am
(calling to servants)
Antony yet.
paragraphs.translated:
(calling for servants) Come here! (to THIDIAS ) Ah, you bird of prey! Now by all the gods and devils, my authority weakens. Not long ago, when I cried, "Ho!" kings would jump up and cry, "What's your pleasure?" (calling to servants) Are you deaf? I'm still Antony.
(calling for servants)
(to

)
(calling to servants)

paragraphs.original: Enter a SERVANT, followed by others
paragraphs.translated: A SERVANT enters, followed by others.

paragraphs.original: Take hence this jack and whip him.
paragraphs.translated: Take away this lout and whip him.

paragraphs.original:
(aside) 'Tis better playing with a lion's whelp
(aside)
Than with an old one dying.
paragraphs.translated:
(aside) It's safer to toy with a lion cub than an old, dying lion.
(aside)

paragraphs.original:
Moon and stars!
Whip him. Were 't twenty of the greatest tributaries
That do acknowledge Caesar, should I find them
So saucy with the hand of she here - what's her name
Since she was Cleopatra? Whip him, fellows,
Till like a boy, you see him cringe his face
And whine aloud for mercy. Take him hence.
paragraphs.translated: By the moon and stars! Whip him! If I saw twenty of the greatest powers that pay tribute to Caesar taking such liberties with her hand - what's her name now? This woman who once was Cleopatra, but now has become something different? Whip him, fellows, until he screws up his face like a baby and cries aloud for mercy! Take him away.

paragraphs.original: Mark Antony -
paragraphs.translated: Mark Antony -

paragraphs.original:
Tug him away! Being whipped,
Bring him again. This jack of Caesar's shall
Bear us an errand to him.
paragraphs.translated: Pull him away, and once he has been whipped, bring him back. Caesar's knave will bring him a message for us.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt SERVANTS with THIDIAS
paragraphs.translated: The SERVANTS exit with THIDIAS.

paragraphs.original:
(to CLEOPATRA ) You were half blasted ere I knew you. Ha!
(to

)
Have I my pillow left unpressed in Rome,
Forborne the getting of a lawful race,
And by a gem of women, to be abused
By one that looks on feeders?
Good my lord -
paragraphs.translated: My good lord -

paragraphs.original:
You have been a boggler ever.
But when we in our viciousness grow hard - 
Oh, misery on 't! - the wise gods seel our eyes,
In our own filth drop our clear judgments, make us
Adore our errors, laugh at 's while we strut
To our confusion.
paragraphs.translated: You've always been a liar. But when our vices become habits - Oh, the sadness of it! - the wise gods blind us, shade our better judgment, make us love our mistakes, and laugh as we strut to our ruin.

paragraphs.original: Oh, is 't come to this?
paragraphs.translated: Oh, has it come to this?

paragraphs.original:
I found you as a morsel cold upon
Dead Caesar's trencher. Nay, you were a fragment
Of Gneius Pompey's, besides what hotter hours,
Unregistered in vulgar fame, you have
Luxuriously picked out. For I am sure,
Though you can guess what temperance should be,
You know not what it is.
paragraphs.translated: You were a cold crumb on dead Julius Caesar's plate when I met you. No, you were one of Gneius Pompey's leftovers - not to mention your other, more depraved affairs, which have somehow managed to avoid becoming the subject of vulgar gossip. For I'm sure that although you may know what temperance is, you've never experienced it firsthand.

paragraphs.original: Wherefore is this?
paragraphs.translated: Why are you doing this?

paragraphs.original:
To let a fellow that will take rewards
And say "God quit you!" be familiar with
My playfellow, your hand, this kingly seal
And plighter of high hearts! Oh, that I were
Upon the hill of Basan, to outroar
The hornèd herd! For I have savage cause,
And to proclaim it civilly were like
A haltered neck which does the hangman thank
For being yare about him.
paragraphs.translated:
To let a servant be familiar with my little toy, your hand - a hand that has signed royal treaties and pledged your love to me - oh, if only I were standing on the hill of
Basan, so that I could roar louder than that horned herd! For I have been savagely abused, and to state my grievances politely would be as absurd as a condemned criminal thanking the hangman for doing his job quickly.
Basan

paragraphs.original: Enter a SERVANT with THIDIAS
paragraphs.translated: A SERVANT enters with THIDIAS.

paragraphs.original: Is he whipped?
paragraphs.translated: Has he been whipped?

paragraphs.original: Soundly, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: Soundly, my lord.

paragraphs.original: Cried he? And begged he pardon?
paragraphs.translated: Did he cry? Did he beg my pardon?

paragraphs.original: He did ask favor.
paragraphs.translated: He did ask for mercy.

paragraphs.original:
(to THIDIAS ) If that thy father live, let him repent
(to

)
Thou wast not made his daughter, and be thou sorry
To follow Caesar in his triumph, since
Thou hast been whipped for following him. Henceforth
The white hand of a lady fever thee;
Shake thou to look on 't. Get thee back to Caesar.
Tell him thy entertainment. Look thou say
He makes me angry with him, for he seems
Proud and disdainful, harping on what I am,
Not what he knew I was. He makes me angry,
And at this time most easy 'tis to do 't,
When my good stars, that were my former guides,
Have empty left their orbs and shot their fires
Into th' abysm of hell. If he mislike
My speech and what is done, tell him he has
Hipparchus, my enfranchèd bondman, whom
He may at pleasure whip, or hang, or torture,
As he shall like, to quit me. Urge it thou.
Hence with thy stripes, begone!
Exit THIDIAS
paragraphs.translated: THIDIAS exits.

paragraphs.original: Have you done yet?
paragraphs.translated: Are you done yet?

paragraphs.original:
Alack, our terrene moon is now eclipsed,
And it portends alone the fall of Antony.
paragraphs.translated: You, my earthly moon, are now eclipsed, and that alone foretells my ruin.

paragraphs.original:
(aside) I must stay his time.
(aside)
paragraphs.translated:
(aside) I must wait for him to finish his tirade.
(aside)

paragraphs.original:
To flatter Caesar, would you mingle eyes
With one that ties his points?
paragraphs.translated: In order to flatter Caesar, would you flirt with the servant who laces up his pants?

paragraphs.original: Not know me yet?
paragraphs.translated: Don't you know me still?

paragraphs.original: Coldhearted toward me?
paragraphs.translated: Has your heart cooled toward me?

paragraphs.original:
Ah, dear, if I be so,
From my cold heart let heaven engender hail,
And poison it in the source, and the first stone
Drop in my neck. As it determines, so
Dissolve my life! The next Caesarion smite,
Till by degrees the memory of my womb,
Together with my brave Egyptians all,
By the discandying of this pelleted storm
Lie graveless till the flies and gnats of Nile
Have buried them for prey!
paragraphs.translated: Ah, dear, if that is true, let heaven make poisonous hail grow from my heart, and let the first hailstone drop down my throat. As it dissolves, so shall my life. The next hailstone should hit Caesarion, until one by one all my children, and every one of my brave Egyptians, are killed by the dissolving of this pellet storm and lie unburied, covered by gnats and flies.

paragraphs.original:
I am satisfied.
Caesar sits down in Alexandria, where
I will oppose his fate. Our force by land
Hath nobly held. Our severed navy too
Have knit again, and fleet, threat'ning most sealike.
Where hast thou been, my heart? Dost thou hear, lady?
If from the field I shall return once more
To kiss these lips, I will appear in blood.
I and my sword will earn our chronicle.
There's hope in 't yet.
paragraphs.translated: I am satisfied. Caesar has made camp in Alexandria. I will fight him there. Our land forces have bravely stood firm. Our tattered navy has reassembled and set sail, as formidable as the sea itself. Where have you been, my bravery? Do you hear what I say, lady? If I come back from the battlefield again to kiss those lips, I'll be covered in blood. My sword and I will earn our place in history. We still have hope.

paragraphs.original: That's my brave lord!
paragraphs.translated: That's my brave lord!

paragraphs.original:
I will be treble-sinewed, -hearted, -breathed,
And fight maliciously. For when mine hours
Were nice and lucky, men did ransom lives
Of me for jests; but now I'll set my teeth
And send to darkness all that stop me. Come,
Let's have one other gaudy night. Call to me
All my sad captains. Fill our bowls once more.
Let's mock the midnight bell.
paragraphs.translated: I'll be triple the soldier I was in strength, bravery, and stamina. I'll fight brutally. In the days when I had better luck, prisoners of war could buy their freedoms from me with simple trinkets. But now I'll grit my teeth and kill anyone who tries to stop me. Come, let's have one more extravagant night. Invite all my sad captains. Fill our wine bowls again. Let's drink through midnight.

paragraphs.original:
It is my birthday.
I had thought t' have held it poor; but since my lord
Is Antony again, I will be Cleopatra.
paragraphs.translated: It's my birthday. I had planned to celebrate it quietly, but since my lord is once more himself, I will be Cleopatra again.

paragraphs.original: We will yet do well.
paragraphs.translated: We'll win yet.

paragraphs.original:
Do so. We'll speak to them, and tonight I'll force
The wine peep through their scars. - Come on, my Queen,
There's sap in 't yet. The next time I do fight
I'll make Death love me, for I will contend
Even with his pestilent scythe.
paragraphs.translated: Do so. I'll speak to them, and then tonight I'll get them all so drunk that the wine seeps out of their old war wounds. Come on, my Queen. There's still life in our cause. The next time I fight, I'll make Death love me. I'll compete even with his fatal scythe.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt all but ENOBARBUS
paragraphs.translated: Everyone except ENOBARBUS exits.

paragraphs.original:
Now he'll outstare the lightning. To be furious
Is to be frighted out of fear, and in that mood
The dove will peck the estridge; and I see still
A diminution in our captain's brain
Restores his heart. When valor preys on reason,
It eats the sword it fights with. I will seek
Some way to leave him.
paragraphs.translated: Now he'll work himself up to a fury. Rage scares away a man's fear. In that state, a dove will attack an ostrich. I have always noticed that when my captain's reason is diminished, his bravery increases. When courage consumes reason, it destroys its only weapon. I'll look for some way to leave his service.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: Enter CAESAR, AGRIPPA, and MAECENAS, with his army, CAESAR reading a letter
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR enters, reading a letter, with AGRIPPA, MAECENAS, and his army.

paragraphs.original:
He calls me "boy" and chides as he had power
To beat me out of Egypt. My messenger
He hath whipped with rods, dares me to personal combat,
Caesar to Antony. Let the old ruffian know
I have many other ways to die, meantime
Laugh at his challenge.
paragraphs.translated: He calls me "boy" and scolds me as if he had the power to whip me out of Egypt. He whipped my messenger with rods. He dares me to personal combat, Caesar against Antony. Let the old ruffian discover that I have many other ways to die, and in the meantime, we'll laugh at his challenge.

paragraphs.original:
Caesar must think
When one so great begins to rage, he's hunted
Even to falling. Give him no breath, but now
Make boot of his distraction. Never anger
Made good guard for itself.
paragraphs.translated: Caesar must realize that when a man as powerful as Antony begins to rage, he has been pursued to the point of collapse. Don't give him time to catch his breath. Take advantage of his unreasonable rage. Anger does not protect the angry well.

paragraphs.original:
Let our best heads
Know that tomorrow the last of many battles
We mean to fight. Within our files there are,
Of those that served Mark Antony but late,
Enough to fetch him in. See it done
And feast the army. We have store to do 't,
And they have earned the waste. Poor Antony!
paragraphs.translated: Tell our top commanders that I want tomorrow's battle to be the last we fight. Our army has recently acquired many of Mark Antony's former soldiers - enough to capture him. See that it is done, and prepare a feast for the soldiers. We have enough supplies for it, and they've earned it. Poor Antony!

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter ANTONY, CLEOPATRA, ENOBARBUS, CHARMIAN, and IRAS, with others
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY, CLEOPATRA, ENOBARBUS, CHARMIAN, and IRAS enter, with attendants.

paragraphs.original: He will not fight with me, Domitius?
paragraphs.translated: He won't fight with me, Domitius?

paragraphs.original: No.
paragraphs.translated: No.

paragraphs.original: Why should he not?
paragraphs.translated: Why won't he?

paragraphs.original:
He thinks, being twenty times of better fortune,
He is twenty men to one.
paragraphs.translated: He thinks that since his fortune is twenty times better than yours, it would be like pitting twenty men against one.

paragraphs.original:
Tomorrow, soldier,
By sea and land I'll fight. Or I will live
Or bathe my dying honor in the blood
Shall make it live again. Woo't thou fight well?
paragraphs.translated: Tomorrow, soldier, I'll fight by sea and land. By the end I will either live, or else I'll restore my honor by shedding my blood. Will you fight well?

paragraphs.original: I'll strike and cry, "Take all."
paragraphs.translated: When I strike, I'll cry, "All or nothing!"

paragraphs.original:
Well said. Come on!
Call forth my household servants.
paragraphs.translated: Well put. Come on. Call out my household servants.

paragraphs.original: Enter three or four SERVITORS
paragraphs.translated: Three or four SERVANTS enter.

paragraphs.original:
Let's tonight
Be bounteous at our meal.
paragraphs.translated: Tonight let's have plenty to eat.

paragraphs.original: Greeting them one by one
paragraphs.translated: He greets the SERVANTS one by one.

paragraphs.original:
Give me thy hand.
Thou hast been rightly honest. - So hast thou, - 
Thou, - and thou, - and thou. You have served me well,
And kings have been your fellows.
paragraphs.translated:
Give me your hand; you've been truly honest - so have you and you - and you - you too.
You have all served me well, and kings are your peers.

paragraphs.original:
(aside to CLEOPATRA ) 'Tis one of those odd tricks which sorrow shoots
(aside to

)
Out of the mind.

(to another SERVITOR ) And thou art honest too.
(to another

)
I wish I could be made so many men,
And all of you clapped up together in
An Antony, that I might do you service
So good as you have done.
The gods forbid!
paragraphs.translated: The gods forbid!

paragraphs.original:
Well, my good fellows, wait on me tonight.
Scant not my cups, and make as much of me
As when mine empire was your fellow too,
And suffered my command.
paragraphs.translated: Well, my good fellows, wait on me tonight. Keep my cups full and treat me as you did when my empire was one of your fellow servants, obeying my commands.

paragraphs.original:
(to the SERVITORS ) Tend me tonight.
(to the

)
May be it is the period of your duty.
Haply you shall not see me more, or if,
A mangled shadow. Perchance tomorrow
You'll serve another master. I look on you
As one that takes his leave. Mine honest friends,
I turn you not away, but, like a master
Married to your good service, stay till death.
Tend me tonight two hours, I ask no more,
And the gods yield you for 't!

What mean you, sir,
To give them this discomfort? Look, they weep,
And I, an ass, am onion-eyed. For shame,
Transform us not to women.
paragraphs.translated: What are you doing, sir? You're making them uncomfortable. Look - they're crying. And I'm just foolish enough to tear up myself. It's embarrassing. Don't turn us into women.

paragraphs.original:
Ho, ho, ho!
Now the witch take me if I meant it thus!
Grace grow where those drops fall! My hearty friends,
You take me in too dolorous a sense,
For I spake to you for your comfort, did desire you
To burn this night with torches. Know, my hearts,
I hope well of tomorrow, and will lead you
Where rather I'll expect victorious life
Than death and honor. Let's to supper, come,
And drown consideration.
paragraphs.translated: Ha, ha, ha! May the evil one take me if I meant it like that! Those tears will bring blessings to you. You interpret my words in a melancholy sense, my hearty friends. I spoke to encourage you, asking that you help me make this night a brilliant one. You should know, my friends, that I have good hopes for tomorrow, and that I will lead you as if I expect victory rather than an honorable death. Let's go to supper. Come, and let's drown our worries.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter a company of SOLDIERS
paragraphs.translated: A company of SOLDIERS enters.

paragraphs.original: Brother, good night. Tomorrow is the day.
paragraphs.translated: Good night, brother. Tomorrow is the day.

paragraphs.original:
It will determine one way. Fare you well.
Heard you of nothing strange about the streets?
paragraphs.translated: This battle will determine who wins the war. Take care of yourself. Have you heard about anything unusual happening in the city?

paragraphs.original: Nothing. What news?
paragraphs.translated: No. What was it?

paragraphs.original: Belike 'tis but a rumor. Good night to you.
paragraphs.translated: It was probably just a rumor. Good night.

paragraphs.original: Well, sir, good night.
paragraphs.translated: Well sir, good night.

paragraphs.original: They meet other SOLDIERS
paragraphs.translated: Two other SOLDIERS enter.

paragraphs.original: Soldiers, have careful watch.
paragraphs.translated: Soldiers, watch carefully.

paragraphs.original: And you. Good night, good night.
paragraphs.translated: You too. Good night. Good night.

paragraphs.original: The four SOLDIERS place themselves in every corner of the stage
paragraphs.translated: Each SOLDIER takes a post at a corner of the stage.

paragraphs.original:
Here we. And if tomorrow
Our navy thrive, I have an absolute hope
Our landmen will stand up.
paragraphs.translated: This is our station. And if our navy wins tomorrow, no doubt our army will do their part.

paragraphs.original: 'Tis a brave army, and full of purpose.
paragraphs.translated: It's an outstanding army and highly motivated.

paragraphs.original: Music of the hautboys is under the stage
paragraphs.translated: Oboe music comes from underneath the stage.

paragraphs.original: Peace! What noise?
paragraphs.translated: Quiet! What's that sound?

paragraphs.original: List, list!
paragraphs.translated: Listen! Listen!

paragraphs.original: Hark!
paragraphs.translated: Listen!

paragraphs.original: Music i' th' air.
paragraphs.translated: There's music coming out of thin air.

paragraphs.original: Under the earth.
paragraphs.translated: From under the earth.

paragraphs.original: It signs well, does it not?
paragraphs.translated: It's a lucky sign, isn't it?

paragraphs.original: No.
paragraphs.translated: No.

paragraphs.original: Peace, I say! What should this mean?
paragraphs.translated: Quiet, I say. What does this mean?

paragraphs.original:
'Tis the god Hercules, whom Antony loved,
Now leaves him.
paragraphs.translated:
It means that
Antony's patron god, Hercules, is leaving him.
Antony's patron god, Hercules

paragraphs.original:
Walk. Let's see if other watchmen
Do hear what we do.
paragraphs.translated: Let's walk over and see if the other soldiers heard the same thing.

paragraphs.original: They advance toward the other SOLDIERS
paragraphs.translated: They go to speak with the other SOLDIERS.

paragraphs.original: How now, masters?
paragraphs.translated: Hello there, good sirs.

paragraphs.original:
(speak together) How now? How now? Do you hear this?
(speak together)
paragraphs.translated:
(speaking at the same time) What now? What now? Do you hear that?
(speaking at the same time)

paragraphs.original: Ay. Is 't not strange?
paragraphs.translated: Yes. Isn't it strange?

paragraphs.original: Do you hear, masters? Do you hear?
paragraphs.translated: Do you hear that, men? Do you?

paragraphs.original:
Follow the noise so far as we have quarter;
Let's see how it will give off.
paragraphs.translated: Let's follow the music as far as we can without leaving our station and see if it stops.

paragraphs.original: Content. 'Tis strange.
paragraphs.translated: Good idea. It's very strange.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter ANTONY and CLEOPATRA, with CHARMIAN and others attending
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY and CLEOPATRA enter with CHARMIAN and others of the court.

paragraphs.original:
(calling) Eros! Mine armor, Eros!
(calling)
paragraphs.translated:
(calling) Eros! Bring my armor, Eros.
(calling)

paragraphs.original: Sleep a little.
paragraphs.translated: Get a little sleep.

paragraphs.original: No, my chuck. - Eros, come, mine armor, Eros!
paragraphs.translated: No, my dear . . . Eros, come on, bring my armor, Eros.

paragraphs.original: Enter EROS with armor
paragraphs.translated: EROS enters, carrying ANTONY's armor.

paragraphs.original:
Come, good fellow, put thine iron on.
If fortune be not ours today, it is
Because we brave her. Come.
paragraphs.translated: Come on, good fellow, help me into that armor you're carrying. If luck deserts us today, it's because we defy it. Come on.

paragraphs.original:
Nay, I'll help too.
What's this for?
paragraphs.translated: No, I'll help too. What's this part for?

paragraphs.original: She helps to arm him
paragraphs.translated: She picks up a piece of the armor.

paragraphs.original:
Ah, let be, let be! Thou art
The armorer of my heart. False, false. This, this.
paragraphs.translated: Ah, leave it alone. Leave it alone! You armor my heart. No! No! That part goes there.

paragraphs.original: Sooth, la, I'll help. Thus it must be.
paragraphs.translated: Really, I'll help. It must go like this.

paragraphs.original:
Well, well,
We shall thrive now. - Seest thou, my good fellow?
Go put on thy defenses.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, well done. We've got it now. - Do you see this, my good fellow? Go and put on your own armor.

paragraphs.original: Briefly, sir.
paragraphs.translated: In a minute, sir.

paragraphs.original: Is not this buckled well?
paragraphs.translated: Didn't I buckle this well?

paragraphs.original:
Rarely, rarely.
He that unbuckles this, till we do please
To doff 't for our repose, shall hear a storm. - 
Thou fumblest, Eros, and my Queen's a squire
More tight at this than thou. Dispatch. - O love,
That thou couldst see my wars today, and knew'st
The royal occupation! Thou shouldst see
A workman in 't.
paragraphs.translated: Excellently, excellently. Anyone who unbuckles this before I want to take it off to rest will be sorry. - You're fumbling, Eros. My Queen's a better squire than you are. Hurry. - Oh, love, if you could only watch the battle today and see how expert I am at my craft.

paragraphs.original: Enter an armed SOLDIER
paragraphs.translated: An armed SOLDIER enters.

paragraphs.original:
Good morrow to thee. Welcome.
Thou look'st like him that knows a warlike charge.
To business that we love we rise betimes
And go to 't with delight.
paragraphs.translated: Good morning to you. Welcome. You look like a person who knows the business of war. When we love our job we get up early and go to it joyfully.

paragraphs.original:
A thousand, sir,
Early though 't be, have on their riveted trim
And at the port expect you.
paragraphs.translated: Even though it's early, there are already a thousand armored soldiers waiting for you at the harbor.

paragraphs.original: Shout. Trumpets flourish
paragraphs.translated: A shout is heard, then a trumpet fanfare.

paragraphs.original: Enter CAPTAINS and SOLDIERS
paragraphs.translated: CAPTAINS and SOLDIERS enter.

paragraphs.original: The morn is fair. Good morrow, General.
paragraphs.translated: The weather is fair. Good morning, General.

paragraphs.original: Good morrow, General.
paragraphs.translated: Good morning, General.

paragraphs.original:
'Tis well blown, lads.
This morning, like the spirit of a youth
That means to be of note, begins betimes.
So, so. (to CLEOPATRA ) Come, give me that. This way. Well said.
(to

)
Fare thee well, dame.
paragraphs.translated:
That was a fine fanfare, boys. Like a young man who wants to amount to something, this morning begins early. (to CLEOPATRA ) So, so. Here, give me that. This is how it goes on. Well done.
(to

)
Farewell, lady.

paragraphs.original: He kisses her
paragraphs.translated: He kisses her.

paragraphs.original:
