Whate'er becomes of me,
This is a soldier's kiss. Rebukable
And worthy shameful check it were to stand
On more mechanic compliment. I'll leave thee
Now like a man of steel. (to others) You that will fight,
(to others)
Follow me close. I'll bring you to 't. (to CLEOPATRA ) Adieu.
(to

)
paragraphs.translated:
Whatever happens to me, this is a soldier's kiss. It would be shameful to draw out our good-byes. I'll leave you without revealing any emotion, like a man of steel. (to the others) Anyone who wants to fight, follow me now, and I'll see you get your wish. (to CLEOPATRA ) Good-bye.
(to the others)
(to

)

paragraphs.original: Exeunt ANTONY, EROS, CAPTAINS, and SOLDIERS
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY and EROS exit with the CAPTAINS and SOLDIERS.

paragraphs.original: Please you retire to your chamber?
paragraphs.translated: If it pleases you, let's go to your room.

paragraphs.original:
Lead me.
He goes forth gallantly. That he and Caesar might
Determine this great war in single fight!
Then Antony - but now - . Well, on.
paragraphs.translated: Lead the way. He goes forth to war bravely. If only he and Caesar could determine the outcome of this war by single combat! Then Antony would - but, with circumstances as they are - well, let's go.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: Trumpets sound. Enter ANTONY and EROS, and a SOLDIER meeting them
paragraphs.translated: Trumpets sound. ANTONY and EROS enter and are met by a SOLDIER entering from another direction.

paragraphs.original: The gods make this a happy day to Antony!
paragraphs.translated: May the gods bless Antony today!

paragraphs.original:
Would thou and those thy scars had once prevailed
To make me fight at land!
paragraphs.translated: I wish you and your scarred self had convinced me to wage our last battle on land.

paragraphs.original:
Hadst thou done so,
The kings that have revolted, and the soldier
That has this morning left thee, would have still
Followed thy heels.
paragraphs.translated: If you had, the kings that have revolted and the soldier that deserted this morning would still be behind you.

paragraphs.original: Who's gone this morning?
paragraphs.translated: Who deserted this morning?

paragraphs.original:
Who?
One ever near thee. Call for Enobarbus
He shall not hear thee, or from Caesar's camp
Say "I am none of thine."
paragraphs.translated: You don't know? Someone who was always near you. If you call for Enobarbus, he won't hear you. Or if he can hear you from Caesar's camp, he'll reply, "I'm no longer on your side."

paragraphs.original: What sayest thou?
paragraphs.translated: What are you saying?

paragraphs.original:
Sir,
He is with Caesar.
paragraphs.translated: Sir, he's with Caesar.

paragraphs.original:
Sir, his chests and treasure
He has not with him.
paragraphs.translated: Sir, he left his belongings and treasure.

paragraphs.original: Is he gone?
paragraphs.translated: He's gone?

paragraphs.original: Most certain.
paragraphs.translated: It's certain.

paragraphs.original:
Go, Eros, send his treasure after. Do it.
Detain no jot, I charge thee. Write to him - 
I will subscribe - gentle adieus and greetings.
Say that I wish he never find more cause
To change a master. Oh, my fortunes have
Corrupted honest men! Dispatch. - Enobarbus!
paragraphs.translated: Eros, send his treasure to him. Do it now. Don't keep anything back, I insist. Write to him from me - I'll sign it - sending greetings and gentle good-byes. Say that I hope he never has cause to look for a new master. Oh, my bad luck has forced honest men to become traitors. Hurry. Enobarbus!

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: Flourish. Enter AGRIPPA, and CAESAR, with ENOBARBUS and DOLABELLA
paragraphs.translated: Trumpet fanfare. AGRIPPA and CAESAR enter with ENOBARBUS and DOLABELLA.

paragraphs.original:
Go forth, Agrippa, and begin the fight.
Our will is Antony be took alive.
Make it so known.
paragraphs.translated: Agrippa, go start the battle. We want Antony taken alive. Make sure everyone knows that.

paragraphs.original: Caesar, I shall.
paragraphs.translated: I will, Caesar.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original:
The time of universal peace is near.
Prove this a prosp'rous day, the three-nooked world
Shall bear the olive freely.
paragraphs.translated:
An era of universal peace is about to start. If this battle goes well for us, there will be peace in all
three corners of the world.
three corners of the world

paragraphs.original: Enter a MESSENGER
paragraphs.translated: A MESSENGER enters.

paragraphs.original:
Antony
Is come into the field.
paragraphs.translated: Antony has come onto the battlefield.

paragraphs.original:
Go charge Agrippa
Plant those that have revolted in the vant,
That Antony may seem to spend his fury
Upon himself.
paragraphs.translated: Go order Agrippa to put the men who deserted Antony's army at the front. That way Antony will feel like he's fighting his own men.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt all but ENOBARBUS
paragraphs.translated: Everyone exits except ENOBARBUS.

paragraphs.original:
Alexas did revolt and went to Jewry on
Affairs of Antony, there did dissuade
Great Herod to incline himself to Caesar
And leave his master Antony. For this pains
Caesar hath hanged him. Canidius and the rest
That fell away have entertainment but
No honorable trust. I have done ill,
Of which I do accuse myself so sorely
That I will joy no more.
paragraphs.translated: Alexas deserted. He went to Judea as if on Antony's business, but he persuaded Herod to support Caesar instead. Caesar hanged him for this service. Canidius and the others that left Antony are given hospitality here but no positions of trust. I've done a bad thing, for which I will blame myself so much that I'll never be happy again.

paragraphs.original: Enter a SOLDIER of Caesar's
paragraphs.translated: A SOLDIER of Caesar's enters.

paragraphs.original:
Enobarbus, Antony
Hath after thee sent all thy treasure, with
His bounty overplus. The messenger
Came on my guard, and at thy tent is now
Unloading of his mules.
paragraphs.translated: Enobarbus, Antony has sent you all your treasure, with generous gifts besides. The messenger arrived on my watch and is unloading his mules at your tent.

paragraphs.original: I give it you.
paragraphs.translated: It's yours.

paragraphs.original:
Mock not, Enobarbus.
I tell you true. Best you safed the bringer
Out of the host. I must attend mine office,
Or would have done 't myself. Your Emperor
Continues still a Jove.
paragraphs.translated: Don't joke about this, Enobarbus. I'm telling you the truth. You'd better bring the messenger safely through the lines so he can return. I'd do it myself, but I can't leave my post. Your Emperor is still a king among gods.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original:
I am alone the villain of the earth,
And feel I am so most. O Antony,
Thou mine of bounty, how wouldst thou have paid
My better service, when my turpitude
Thou dost so crown with gold! This blows my heart.
If swift thought break it not, a swifter mean
Shall outstrike thought, but thought will do 't, I feel.
I fight against thee? No, I will go seek
Some ditch wherein to die. The foul'st best fits
My latter part of life.
paragraphs.translated: I am the worst person alive, and I know it the best. Oh, Antony, you extravagantly generous man, how would you have rewarded me for serving you faithfully when you reward my badness with all of this gold! My heart feels like it's about to explode. If grief doesn't kill me, I'll find a quicker way to kill myself - even though I think grief will do the job just as well. I, fight against you, Antony? No, I'll go find some ditch to die in. The foulest fate would be most appropriate for me now in this latest phase of my life.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: Alarum. Drums and trumpets. Enter AGRIPPA and others
paragraphs.translated: A call to battle is sounded. Drums and trumpets sound. AGRIPPA and other soldiers of Caesar's enter.

paragraphs.original:
Retire! We have engaged ourselves too far.
Caesar himself has work, and our oppression
Exceeds what we expected.
paragraphs.translated: Retreat! We've advanced too far. Caesar himself is in trouble and there are more adversaries than we expected.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: Alarums. Enter ANTONY, and SCARUS, wounded
paragraphs.translated: A battle call. ANTONY enters with SCARUS, who is wounded.

paragraphs.original:
O my brave Emperor, this is fought indeed!
Had we done so at first, we had droven them home
With clouts about their heads.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, my brave Emperor, this is what I call a fight! If we'd fought like this before, we'd have driven them home with bandaged heads.

paragraphs.original: Thou bleed'st apace.
paragraphs.translated: You're bleeding a lot.

paragraphs.original:
I had a wound here that was like a "T,"
But now 'tis made an "H."
paragraphs.translated: I had a scar here that looked like a "T"; now it's an "H."

paragraphs.original: Sound retreat far off
paragraphs.translated: Distant trumpets sound the retreat.

paragraphs.original: They do retire.
paragraphs.translated: They're retreating.

paragraphs.original:
We'll beat 'em into bench-holes. I have yet
Room for six scotches more.
paragraphs.translated: We'll chase 'em into their latrines. I still have room for six more wounds.

paragraphs.original: Enter EROS
paragraphs.translated: EROS enters.

paragraphs.original:
They are beaten, sir, and our advantage serves
For a fair victory.
paragraphs.translated: They're retreating, sir, and our superiority indicates a clear victory.

paragraphs.original:
Let us score their backs
And snatch 'em up, as we take hares, behind!
'Tis sport to maul a runner.
paragraphs.translated: Let's slash their backs and grab 'em like we do rabbits, from behind. It's fair game to mark a coward.

paragraphs.original:
I will reward thee
Once for thy sprightly comfort and tenfold
For thy good valor. Come thee on.
paragraphs.translated: I'll reward you once for your cheerfulness and ten times for your courage. Come on.

paragraphs.original: I'll halt after.
paragraphs.translated: I'll limp after you.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: Alarum. Enter ANTONY again in a march; SCARUS, with others
paragraphs.translated: A battle call. ANTONY marches in, followed by SCARUS and others.

paragraphs.original:
We have beat him to his camp. Run one before
And let the Queen know of our gests.
paragraphs.translated: We've driven him all the way back to his camp. One of you run to the Queen with the news.

paragraphs.original: Exit a soldier
paragraphs.translated: A soldier exits.

paragraphs.original:
Tomorrow,
Before the sun shall see 's, we'll spill the blood
That has today escaped. I thank you all,
For doughty-handed are you, and have fought
Not as you served the cause, but as 't had been
Each man's like mine. You have shown all Hectors.
Enter the city. Clip your wives, your friends.
Tell them your feats, whilst they with joyful tears
Wash the congealment from your wounds and kiss
The honored gashes whole.
paragraphs.translated:
Before sunrise tomorrow, we'll kill anyone who escaped today. I want to thank all of you. You're formidable. You fought not as if you served the cause but as though it were as much your personal fight as mine. You are all
Hectors. Go on into the city. Embrace your wives and your friends. Describe your feats for them while they cry for joy. Their tears will wash the congealed blood from your wounds, and they will kiss those honorable cuts until they heal.
Hectors

paragraphs.original: Enter CLEOPATRA
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA enters.

paragraphs.original:
(to SCARUS )                Give me thy hand.
            (to

)                
To this great fairy I'll commend thy acts,
Make her thanks bless thee. O thou day o' the world,
(to CLEOPATRA ) Chain mine armed neck. Leap thou, attire and all,
(to

)
Through proof of harness to my heart, and there
Ride on the pants triumphing!

Lord of lords!
O infinite virtue, com'st thou smiling from
The world's great snare uncaught?
paragraphs.translated: Lord of lords! Your courage is infinite. Have you returned smiling from the great battle for the world?

paragraphs.original:
Mine nightingale,
We have beat them to their beds. What, girl, though gray
Do something mingle with our younger brown, yet ha' we
A brain that nourishes our nerves and can
Get goal for goal of youth. Behold this man.
Commend unto his lips thy favoring hand.
(to SCARUS ) Kiss it, my warrior.
(to

)
paragraphs.translated:
My songbird, we have beaten them to their beds. What do you think, girl!
Even though there are some gray hairs among the brown, I still have a brain and muscles that will let me compete with younger men. Look at this man. Show him favor by letting him kiss your hand. (to SCARUS ) Kiss it, my warrior.
(to

)

paragraphs.original: SCARUS kisses CLEOPATRA's hand
paragraphs.translated: SCARUS kisses CLEOPATRA's hand

paragraphs.original:
He hath fought today
As if a god, in hate of mankind, had
Destroyed in such a shape.
paragraphs.translated: Today he fought as though he were a god who hated mankind.

paragraphs.original:
(to SCARUS )              I'll give thee, friend,
            (to

)              
An armor all of gold. It was a king's.

He has deserved it, were it carbuncled
Like holy Phoebus' car. Give me thy hand.
Through Alexandria make a jolly march.
Bear our hacked targets like the men that owe them.
Had our great palace the capacity
To camp this host, we all would sup together
And drink carouses to the next day's fate,
Which promises royal peril. - Trumpeters,
With brazen din blast you the city's ear;
Make mingle with our rattling taborins,
That heaven and earth may strike their sounds together,
Applauding our approach.
paragraphs.translated:
He deserves it, even if it were covered with jewels like holy
Phoebus' car. Give me your hand. Let's have a cheerful march through Alexandria, proudly carrying our dented shields. If we had enough room in the palace to house this army, we'd all eat together and toast tomorrow, which promises to be full of danger. Trumpeters, blast the city's ears. Mix your fanfares with our drums, so that sounds from both heaven and earth will herald our approach.
Phoebus' car

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: Everyone exits.

paragraphs.original: Enter a SENTRY and his company. ENOBARBUS follows
paragraphs.translated: A SENTRY and his company enter, followed by ENOBARBUS.

paragraphs.original:
If we be not relieved within this hour,
We must return to th' court of guard. The night
Is shiny, and they say we shall embattle
By th' second hour i' th' morn.
paragraphs.translated: If we aren't relieved in an hour, we have to return to our barracks. The night is bright, and they say we'll be forming for battle by two a.m.

paragraphs.original: This last day was a shrewd one to 's.
paragraphs.translated: That last day was a hard one for us.

paragraphs.original: O bear me witness, night -
paragraphs.translated: Oh, listen to me, night -

paragraphs.original: What man is this?
paragraphs.translated: Who is this?

paragraphs.original: Stand close and list him.
paragraphs.translated: Stay hidden and listen.

paragraphs.original:
Be witness to me, O thou blessèd moon,
When men revolted shall upon record
Bear hateful memory, poor Enobarbus did
Before thy face repent.
paragraphs.translated: Be my witness, oh you blessed moon. The men who revolted against Antony will be remembered scornfully in the history books. But poor Enobarbus repented.

paragraphs.original: Enobarbus?
paragraphs.translated: That's Enobarbus?

paragraphs.original: Peace! Hark further.
paragraphs.translated: Quiet! Keep listening.

paragraphs.original:
O sovereign mistress of true melancholy,
The poisonous damp of night disponge upon me,
That life, a very rebel to my will,
May hang no longer on me. Throw my heart
Against the flint and hardness of my fault,
Which, being dried with grief, will break to powder
And finish all foul thoughts. O Antony,
Nobler than my revolt is infamous,
Forgive me in thine own particular,
But let the world rank me in register
A master-leaver and a fugitive.
O Antony! O Antony!
paragraphs.translated: Oh, moon, you queen of sadness, drop poisonous dew on me so that my life, which continues against my wishes, will end. Take my heart and throw it against my hard, stony sin. My heart, which dried out with grief, will surely break apart into a powder, and that will be the end of my disgusting mind. Oh, Antony! You are more noble than my revolt is dishonorable. Forgive my crimes against you, but let history record me as a fugitive traitor. Oh, Antony! Oh, Antony!

paragraphs.original: He dies
paragraphs.translated: He dies.

paragraphs.original: Let's speak to him.
paragraphs.translated: Let's speak to him.

paragraphs.original: Let's hear him, for the things he speaks may concern Caesar.
paragraphs.translated: Let's listen to him. He may say something concerning Caesar.

paragraphs.original: Let's do so. But he sleeps.
paragraphs.translated: Good idea. But he's sleeping.

paragraphs.original:
Swoons rather, for so bad a prayer as his
Was never yet for sleep.
paragraphs.translated: It looks more like he fainted. No one ever gave a prayer like that before going to sleep.

paragraphs.original: Go we to him.
paragraphs.translated: Let's go to him.

paragraphs.original: Awake, sir, awake. Speak to us.
paragraphs.translated: Wake up, sir, wake up. Speak to us.

paragraphs.original: Hear you, sir?
paragraphs.translated: Do you hear us, sir?

paragraphs.original: The hand of death hath raught him.
paragraphs.translated: The hand of death has taken him.

paragraphs.original: Drums afar off
paragraphs.translated: Drums are heard in the distance.

paragraphs.original:
Hark, the drums
Demurely wake the sleepers. Let us bear him
To th' court of guard. He is of note. Our hour
Is fully out.
paragraphs.translated: Listen. The drums softly wake the sleepers. Let's carry him to the barracks. He's an important person. Our hour is up.

paragraphs.original: Come on, then. He may recover yet.
paragraphs.translated: Come on, then. He may recover yet.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt with the body
paragraphs.translated: They exit, carrying ENOBARBUS's body.

paragraphs.original: Enter ANTONY and SCARUS, with their army
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY and SCARUS enter, with the army.

paragraphs.original:
Their preparation is today by sea.
We please them not by land.
paragraphs.translated: They've switched their operation to the sea today. We didn't please them on land.

paragraphs.original: For both, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: We're ready for both, my lord.

paragraphs.original:
I would they'd fight i' th' fire or i' th' air,
We'd fight there too. But this it is: our foot
Upon the hills adjoining to the city
Shall stay with us. Order for sea is given;
They have put forth the haven,
Where their appointment we may best discover
And look on their endeavor.
paragraphs.translated: I wish they'd fight in fire or in the air. We'd meet them there too. But here's the plan: our army will stay with us on the hills by the city. Orders have been given to the navy and they've left port. We'll be able to analyze and direct the battle better from the hills.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter CAESAR and his army
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR and his army enter.

paragraphs.original:
But being charged, we will be still by land - 
Which, as I take 't, we shall, for his best force
Is forth to man his galleys. To the vales,
And hold our best advantage.
paragraphs.translated: We won't move our land forces unless we're attacked. And I doubt that will happen, since most of Antony's men are with his navy. Let's take up the best positions we can in the valleys.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter ANTONY and SCARUS
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY and SCARUS enter.

paragraphs.original:
Yet they are not joined. Where yond pine does stand
I shall discover all. I'll bring thee word
Straight how 'tis like to go.
paragraphs.translated: They still haven't joined the battle. I'll be able to see better from that pine tree over there. I'll let you know right away how it's going.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: Alarum afar off, as at a sea fight
paragraphs.translated: Noises like a sea battle are heard in the distance.

paragraphs.original:
Swallows have built
In Cleopatra's sails their nests. The auguries
Say they know not, they cannot tell, look grimly,
And dare not speak their knowledge. Antony
Is valiant and dejected, and by starts
His fretted fortunes give him hope and fear
Of what he has and has not.
paragraphs.translated: Swallows have built nests in Cleopatra's sails. The fortunetellers won't say whether that's a good sign or a bad one, but they don't look happy. Antony is valiant and dejected. His mood changes by fits and starts; his checkered luck vacillates between hope and fear, winning and losing.

paragraphs.original: Enter ANTONY
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY enters.

paragraphs.original:
All is lost!
This foul Egyptian hath betrayèd me.
My fleet hath yielded to the foe, and yonder
They cast their caps up and carouse together
Like friends long lost. Triple-turned whore! 'Tis thou
Hast sold me to this novice, and my heart
Makes only wars on thee. Bid them all fly,
For when I am revenged upon my charm,
I have done all. Bid them all fly. Begone!
paragraphs.translated: All is lost! This treacherous Egyptian has betrayed me. My fleet has surrendered to the enemy. You can see them over there throwing their hats up in the air and drinking together like long lost friends. Three-time traitor and whore! It's you who have sold me to this youth, Caesar. Now my war is only with you. Tell the army to flee. Revenge on Cleopatra will be my last act. Order them to escape. Go!

paragraphs.original: Exit SCARUS
paragraphs.translated: SCARUS exits.

paragraphs.original:
O sun, thy uprise shall I see no more.
Fortune and Antony part here. Even here
Do we shake hands. All come to this? The hearts
That spanieled me at heels, to whom I gave
Their wishes, do discandy, melt their sweets
On blossoming Caesar, and this pine is barked
That overtopped them all. Betrayed I am.
Oh, this false soul of Egypt! This grave charm,
Whose eye becked forth my wars and called them home,
Whose bosom was my crownet, my chief end,
Like a right gypsy hath at fast and loose
Beguiled me to the very heart of loss.
(calling out) What, Eros, Eros!
(calling out)
paragraphs.translated:
Oh, sun, I will never see another one of your sunrises. Luck and Antony separate here and now. Here we'll shake hands good-bye. Is it all come to this? The brave men who followed me like little dogs, whom I rewarded, have left me to follow Caesar. I've been stripped of everything, betrayed. Oh, that devious Egyptian spirit! Her charms launched my wars and called them back again. Pleasing her was my main goal, and she lured me to total defeat. (calling out) Where are you, Eros! Eros!
(calling out)

paragraphs.original: Enter CLEOPATRA
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA enters.

paragraphs.original: Ah, thou spell! Avaunt!
paragraphs.translated: Ah, you sorceress! Be gone!

paragraphs.original: Why is my lord enraged against his love?
paragraphs.translated: Why is my lord enraged against his love?

paragraphs.original:
Vanish, or I shall give thee thy deserving,
And blemish Caesar's triumph. Let him take thee
And hoist thee up to the shouting plebeians!
Follow his chariot, like the greatest spot
Of all thy sex. Most monsterlike be shown
For poor'st diminutives, for dolts, and let
Patient Octavia plow thy visage up
With her preparèd nails!
paragraphs.translated: Get out of my sight, or I'll give you what you deserve and spoil Caesar's victory. Let him hoist you up in front of the shouting crowds! Follow his chariot, like the greatest disgrace to your whole gender. Let them exhibit you to the public for meager coins, like a monstrosity. Then let Octavia dig up your face with her nails.

paragraphs.original: Exit CLEOPATRA
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA exits.

paragraphs.original:
'Tis well th'art gone,
If it be well to live, but better 'twere
Thou fell'st into my fury, for one death
Might have prevented many. - Eros, ho! - 
The shirt of Nessus is upon me. Teach me,
Alcides, thou mine ancestor, thy rage.
Let me lodge Lichas on the horns o' th' moon,
And with those hands that grasped the heaviest club
Subdue my worthiest self. The witch shall die.
To the young Roman boy she hath sold me, and I fall
Under this plot. She dies for 't. - Eros, ho!
paragraphs.translated:
If you wish to live, you had better get out of here. But I think it would have been better if you'd let me kill you. One death would have prevented the deaths of many others. - Eros, ho! - 
I'm wearing the shirt of Nessus. Hercules, my ancestor, teach me how to feel your rage. I'll toss Lichas to the moon and use my mighty hands to kill my better self. The witch shall die.
I'm wearing the shirt of Nessus.



She sold me to that young Roman boy and now I'm ruined. She'll die for it. - Eros, ho!

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: Enter CLEOPATRA, CHARMIAN, IRAS, and MARDIAN
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA, CHARMIAN, IRAS, and MARDIAN enter.

paragraphs.original:
Help me, my women! Oh, he's more mad
Than Telamon for his shield. The boar of Thessaly
Was never so embossed.
paragraphs.translated: Help me, ladies! Oh, Antony is more furious than Telamon, who killed himself in a jealous rage. The wild boar of Thessaly, which the goddess Diana sent to punish King Caledon for neglecting her sacrifices, didn't foam at the mouth as much as Antony does now.

paragraphs.original:
To th' monument!
There lock yourself and send him word you are dead.
The soul and body rive not more in parting
Than greatness going off.
paragraphs.translated: Go to your tomb! Lock yourself in and send him word that you're dead. When a great person departs, it causes more pain than when the soul leaves the body.

paragraphs.original:
To th' monument! - 
Mardian, go tell him I have slain myself.
Say that the last I spoke was "Antony,"
And word it, prithee, piteously. Hence, Mardian,
And bring me how he takes my death. (to the others) To th' monument!
(to the others)
paragraphs.translated:
To my tomb! Mardian, go tell him I've killed myself. Say the last word I spoke was "Antony," and please word it pathetically. Go, Mardian, and let me know how he reacts to my death. (to the others) To the tomb!
(to the others)

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter ANTONY and EROS
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY and EROS enter.

paragraphs.original: Eros, thou yet behold'st me?
paragraphs.translated: Eros, can you still see me?

paragraphs.original: Ay, noble lord.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, noble lord.

paragraphs.original:
Sometimes we see a cloud that's dragonish,
A vapor sometime like a bear or lion,
A towered citadel, a pendant rock,
A forkèd mountain, or blue promontory
With trees upon 't that nod unto the world
And mock our eyes with air. Thou hast seen these signs.
They are black vesper's pageants.
paragraphs.translated: Sometimes we see a cloud that looks like a dragon. Sometimes there's a cloud like a bear or a lion, a castle, a floating rock, a craggy mountain. Or it might look like a blue cliff with trees on it that bow to the ground. These things fool our eyes by seeming solid, when they are actually only air. You've seen these illusions. They're spectacles that appear at sunset.

paragraphs.original: Ay, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, my lord.

paragraphs.original:
That which is now a horse, even with a thought
The rack dislimns and makes it indistinct
As water is in water.
paragraphs.translated: What looks like a horse is quick as thought disfigured by the wind, made as difficult to distinguish as water poured into water.

paragraphs.original: It does, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: That's true, my lord.

paragraphs.original:
My good knave Eros, now thy captain is
Even such a body. Here I am Antony,
Yet cannot hold this visible shape, my knave.
I made these wars for Egypt, and the Queen,
Whose heart I thought I had, for she had mine - 
Which whilst it was mine had annexed unto 't
A million more, now lost - she, Eros, has
Packed cards with Caesar and false-played my glory
Unto an enemy's triumph.
Nay, weep not, gentle Eros. There is left us
Ourselves to end ourselves.
paragraphs.translated: Eros, my young friend, your captain is now just like that cloud. Here and now I seem like Antony, but I can't keep myself in this form, my boy. I went to war to save Cleopatra, whose love I thought I had, since she had mine - and mine carried with it a million others, those of my soldiers, now lost. The Queen conspired with Caesar to undermine my success and assure his victory. No, don't cry, kind Eros. We still have the option of killing ourselves.

paragraphs.original: Enter MARDIAN
paragraphs.translated: MARDIAN enters.

paragraphs.original:
Oh, thy vile lady!
She has robbed me of my sword.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, your contemptible lady! She has disarmed me.

paragraphs.original:
No, Antony,
My mistress loved thee, and her fortunes mingled
With thine entirely.
paragraphs.translated: No, Antony. My mistress loved you, and her destiny was completely joined with yours.

paragraphs.original:
Hence, saucy eunuch! Peace!
She hath betrayed me and shall die the death.
paragraphs.translated: Get out, insolent eunuch! Silence! She has betrayed me and shall die.

paragraphs.original:
Death of one person can be paid but once,
And that she has discharged. What thou wouldst do
Is done unto thy hand. The last she spake
Was "Antony, most noble Antony!"
Then in the midst a tearing groan did break
The name of Antony. It was divided
Between her heart and lips. She rendered life,
Thy name so buried in her.
paragraphs.translated: A person can only pay with their life once, and she has paid in full. What you wanted is yours. Her last words were "Antony! Most noble Antony!" Then, as she was speaking your name, a strangled groan split her words. "Antony" was divided between her heart and lips. She gave up her life with your name still within her.

paragraphs.original: Dead, then?
paragraphs.translated: Is she dead, then?

paragraphs.original: Dead.
paragraphs.translated: Dead.

paragraphs.original:
Unarm, Eros. The long day's task is done,
And we must sleep. (to MARDIAN ) That thou depart'st hence safe
(to

)
Does pay thy labor richly. Go.
Exit MARDIAN
paragraphs.translated: MARDIAN exits.

paragraphs.original:
Off, pluck off!
The sevenfold shield of Ajax cannot keep
The battery from my heart. O, cleave, my sides!
Heart, once be stronger than thy continent.
Crack thy frail case! - Apace, Eros, apace.
No more a soldier. Bruisèd pieces, go.
You have been nobly borne. (to EROS ) From me awhile.
(to

)
Exit EROS
paragraphs.translated: EROS exits.

paragraphs.original:
I will o'ertake thee, Cleopatra, and
Weep for my pardon. So it must be, for now
All length is torture. Since the torch is out,
Lie down and stray no farther. Now all labor
Mars what it does. Yea, very force entangles
Itself with strength. Seal then, and all is done. - 
Eros! - I come, my Queen. - Eros! - Stay for me.
Where souls do couch on flowers, we'll hand in hand,
And with our sprightly port make the ghosts gaze.
Dido and her Aeneas shall want troops,
And all the haunt be ours. - Come, Eros, Eros!
paragraphs.translated: I will catch up with you, Cleopatra, and weep for your forgiveness. It's the only way left, because now any extension of my life would be torture. Since the light of my life has gone out, I'll stop here. Now any effort ruins what it attempts. Yes, even power gets in its own way. End it, then, and everything is over. - Eros! - I'm coming, my Queen! - Eros! - Wait for me. In the place where souls recline on beds of flowers we'll walk hand in hand and amaze the other ghosts with our spirited demeanor. Those famous lovers, Dido and Aeneas, will lose their admirers, and the whole place will be devoted to us. - Come, Eros. Eros!

paragraphs.original: Enter EROS
paragraphs.translated: EROS enters.

paragraphs.original: What would my lord?
paragraphs.translated: What can I do for my lord?

paragraphs.original:
Since Cleopatra died
I have lived in such dishonor that the gods
Detest my baseness. I, that with my sword
Quartered the world, and o'er green Neptune's back
With ships made cities, condemn myself to lack
The courage of a woman - less noble mind
Than she which by her death our Caesar tells
"I am conqueror of myself." Thou art sworn, Eros,
That when the exigent should come which now
Is come indeed, when I should see behind me
Th' inevitable prosecution of
Disgrace and horror, that on my command,
Thou then wouldst kill me. Do 't. The time is come.
Thou strik'st not me, 'tis Caesar thou defeat'st.
Put color in thy cheek.
paragraphs.translated: Since Cleopatra died, I have lived in such dishonor that the gods despise my disgrace. Though I have made conquests throughout the four corners of the world and sailed with fleets so large they looked like floating cities, I don't have as much courage as a woman. I have less nobility than the lady who, by killing herself, says to Caesar, "Only Cleopatra can defeat Cleopatra." You promised me, Eros, that should the ultimate moment arrive - which it has - when dishonor and disgust are inevitable, that upon my command, you would kill me. Do it. This is that time. You won't be striking me down, but defeating Caesar. Call up your courage.

paragraphs.original:
The gods withhold me!
Shall I do that which all the Parthian darts,
Though enemy, lost aim and could not?
paragraphs.translated: The gods forbid! Can I do what all the Parthian arrows, though shot by enemies, could not?

paragraphs.original:
Eros,
Wouldst thou be windowed in great Rome and see
Thy master thus with pleached arms, bending down
His corrigible neck, his face subdued
To penetrative shame, whilst the wheeled seat
Of fortunate Caesar, drawn before him, branded
His baseness that ensued?
paragraphs.translated: Eros, would you like to look through a window in Rome and watch your master marching in Caesar's victory parade, his arms crossed and tied, his head bowed in submission, his face red from shame, while the chariot of triumphant Caesar precedes him, putting the final stamp to his humiliation?

paragraphs.original: I would not see 't.
paragraphs.translated: I would not.

paragraphs.original:
Come, then, for with a wound I must be cured.
Draw that thy honest sword, which thou hast worn
Most useful for thy country.
paragraphs.translated: Then come on. I must be restored to health by an injury. Draw your trustworthy sword, which you have used in such service to your country.

paragraphs.original: O sir, pardon me!
paragraphs.translated: Oh, sir, pardon me!

paragraphs.original:
When I did make thee free, swor'st thou not then
To do this when I bade thee? Do it at once,
Or thy precedent services are all
But accidents unpurposed. Draw and come.
paragraphs.translated: When I freed you from slavery, didn't you swear to do this when I asked you? Do it immediately, or all your previous services to me were accidental, without purpose. Take out your sword and come on.

paragraphs.original:
Turn from me then that noble countenance
Wherein the worship of the whole world lies.
paragraphs.translated: Then turn your noble face away from me, that face that the whole world adores.

paragraphs.original: Lo thee!
paragraphs.translated: Look!

paragraphs.original: He turns away
paragraphs.translated: He turns away.

paragraphs.original: My sword is drawn.
paragraphs.translated: I have drawn my sword.

paragraphs.original:
Then let it do at once
The thing why thou hast drawn it.
paragraphs.translated: Now let it carry out its purpose immediately.

paragraphs.original:
My dear master,
My captain, and my emperor, let me say,
Before I strike this bloody stroke, farewell.
paragraphs.translated: My dear master, my captain, my sovereign, let me say before I strike this fatal blow: farewell.

paragraphs.original: 'Tis said, man, and farewell.
paragraphs.translated: You've said it, friend, and farewell to you.

paragraphs.original: Farewell, great chief. Shall I strike now?
paragraphs.translated: Good-bye, great commander. Should I do it now?

paragraphs.original: Now, Eros.
paragraphs.translated: Now, Eros.

paragraphs.original: Why, there then!
paragraphs.translated: Well, then, there!

paragraphs.original: Stabs himself
paragraphs.translated: He stabs himself.

paragraphs.original:
Thus I do escape the sorrow
Of Antony's death.
paragraphs.translated: With this I avoid the grief of Antony's death.

paragraphs.original: He dies
paragraphs.translated: He dies.

paragraphs.original:
Thrice nobler than myself,
Thou teachest me, O valiant Eros, what
I should and thou couldst not. My Queen and Eros
Have by their brave instruction got upon me
A nobleness in record. But I will be
A bridegroom in my death, and run into 't
As to a lover's bed. Come then, and Eros,
Thy master dies thy scholar. To do thus
I learned of thee.
paragraphs.translated: Brave Eros, three times more honorable than I am! You teach me what I should do but could not. My Queen and Eros have by their brave examples beaten me to the history books. But I will embrace death as a bridegroom does his bride, and rush to it as to a lover's bed. Come then. Eros, your master dies your student. I learned to do this from you.

paragraphs.original: He falls on his sword
paragraphs.translated: He falls on his sword.

paragraphs.original:
How! Not dead? Not dead?
The guard, ho! Oh, dispatch me!
paragraphs.translated: What! I'm not dead? Not dead? - Guard, here! Oh, kill me!

paragraphs.original: Enter DERCETUS and others of a GUARD
paragraphs.translated: DERCETUS enters with three GUARDS.

paragraphs.original: What's the noise?
paragraphs.translated: What's the trouble?

paragraphs.original:
I have done my work ill, friends. Oh, make an end
Of what I have begun!
paragraphs.translated: I've botched the job, friends. Oh, finish what I've begun.

paragraphs.original: The star is fall'n.
paragraphs.translated: Our guiding light is out.

paragraphs.original: And time is at his period.
paragraphs.translated: And time itself is ended.

paragraphs.original: Alas, and woe!
paragraphs.translated: Sadness and despair!

paragraphs.original: Let him that loves me strike me dead.
paragraphs.translated: Whoever's a real friend should strike me dead.

paragraphs.original: Not I.
paragraphs.translated: Not me.

paragraphs.original: Nor I.
paragraphs.translated: Me neither.

paragraphs.original: Nor anyone.
paragraphs.translated: None of us.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt GUARD
paragraphs.translated: The GUARDS exit.

paragraphs.original: Thy death and fortunes bid thy followers fly.
paragraphs.translated: Your death and destiny advise your followers to escape.

paragraphs.original: He takes up ANTONY's sword
paragraphs.translated: He takes up ANTONY's sword

paragraphs.original:
This sword but shown to Caesar, with this tidings,
Shall enter me with him.
paragraphs.translated: I only need to show your sword to Caesar and tell him about your death to get into his good favor.

paragraphs.original: Enter DIOMEDES
paragraphs.translated: DIOMEDES enters.

paragraphs.original: Where's Antony?
paragraphs.translated: Where's Antony?

paragraphs.original: There, Diomed, there.
paragraphs.translated: There, Diomedes, there.

paragraphs.original: Lives he? Wilt thou not answer, man?
paragraphs.translated: Is he still alive? Why don't you answer me, man?

paragraphs.original: Exit DERCETUS
paragraphs.translated: DERCETAS exits.

paragraphs.original:
Art thou there, Diomed? Draw thy sword and give me
Sufficing strokes for death.
paragraphs.translated: Is that you, Diomedes? Draw your sword and give me enough blows to kill me.

paragraphs.original:
Most absolute lord,
My mistress Cleopatra sent me to thee.
paragraphs.translated: Most powerful lord, my mistress Cleopatra sent me to you.

paragraphs.original: When did she send thee?
paragraphs.translated: When did she send you?

paragraphs.original: Now, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: Just now, my lord.

paragraphs.original: Where is she?
paragraphs.translated: Where is she?

paragraphs.original:
Locked in her monument. She had a prophesying fear
Of what hath come to pass. For when she saw - 
Which never shall be found - you did suspect
She had disposed with Caesar, and that your rage
Would not be purged, she sent you word she was dead.
But fearing since how it might work, hath sent
Me to proclaim the truth, and I am come,
I dread, too late.
paragraphs.translated: Locked in her tomb. She had a premonition of what has actually happened. She saw that you suspected her of negotiating a treaty with Caesar - which never will be true. Afraid that your anger would not subside, she sent you word she was dead. But later, fearing how that news might affect you, she sent me to tell you the truth. I'm afraid I've come too late.

paragraphs.original: Too late, good Diomed. Call my guard, I prithee.
paragraphs.translated: Too late, good Diomedes. Call my guard, please.

paragraphs.original:
What ho, the Emperor's guard! The guard, what ho!
Come, your lord calls!
paragraphs.translated: Hey out there! Emperor's guards! Guards, hey! Come! Your lord calls for you!

paragraphs.original: Enter four or five of the GUARD of Antony
paragraphs.translated: Four or five of Antony's GUARDS enter.

paragraphs.original:
Bear me, good friends, where Cleopatra bides.
'Tis the last service that I shall command you.
paragraphs.translated: Carry me, good friends, to where Cleopatra is. It's the last command I shall ever give you.

paragraphs.original:
Woe, woe are we, sir, you may not live to wear
All your true followers out.
paragraphs.translated: We're very sorry, sir, that you may not live to wear us out with your commands.

paragraphs.original: Most heavy day!
paragraphs.translated: It's a very sad day.

paragraphs.original:
Nay, good my fellows, do not please sharp fate
To grace it with your sorrows. Bid that welcome
Which comes to punish us, and we punish it,
Seeming to bear it lightly. Take me up.
I have led you oft; carry me now, good friends,
And have my thanks for all.
paragraphs.translated: No, my friends, don't please fate by giving it your sorrow as well. If we welcome our punishment, we punish it right back by seeming to take it lightly. Pick me up. I have often led you, now you must carry me, my good friends - and take my thanks for everything.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt, bearing ANTONY and the body of EROS
paragraphs.translated: They exit, carrying ANTONY and EROS' body.

paragraphs.original: Enter CLEOPATRA and her maids aloft, with CHARMIAN and IRAS
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA, CHARMIAN, and IRAS enter with Cleopatra's maids in the upper gallery.

paragraphs.original: O Charmian, I will never go from hence.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, Charmian, I will never leave this tomb!

paragraphs.original: Be comforted, dear madam.
paragraphs.translated: Be calm, dear lady.

paragraphs.original:
No, I will not.
All strange and terrible events are welcome,
But comforts we despise. Our size of sorrow,
Proportioned to our cause, must be as great
As that which makes it.
paragraphs.translated: No, I won't. Strange and terrible events are all welcome, but I despise comforts. The size of my sorrow must be as great as its source.

paragraphs.original: Enter below DIOMEDES
paragraphs.translated: DIOMEDES enters below.

paragraphs.original: How now? Is he dead?
paragraphs.translated: What's the news! Is he dead?

paragraphs.original:
His death's upon him, but not dead.
Look out o' th' other side your monument.
His guard have brought him thither.
paragraphs.translated: He is close to death, but not dead yet. Look out the other window; his guard has brought him here.

paragraphs.original: Enter below ANTONY, and the guard bearing him
paragraphs.translated: Guards enter, carrying ANTONY.

paragraphs.original:
O sun,
Burn the great sphere thou mov'st in. Darkling stand
The varying shore o' th' world! O Antony,
Antony, Antony! Help, Charmian, help, Iras, help!
Help, friends below! Let's draw him hither.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, sun, burn up the orbit in which you move, so that the world may be dark forever! Oh, Antony, Antony, Antony! Help, Charmian, help, Iras, help! Help, friends below; lift him up here.

paragraphs.original:
Peace!
Not Caesar's valor hath o'erthrown Antony,
But Antony's hath triumphed on itself.
paragraphs.translated: Be calm! It was not Caesar's bravery that conquered Antony but Antony's that has triumphed over himself.

paragraphs.original:
So it should be, that none but Antony
Should conquer Antony, but woe 'tis so!
paragraphs.translated: That's the way it should be - only Antony should conquer Antony. But how terrible that it has happened!

paragraphs.original:
I am dying, Egypt, dying. Only
I here importune death awhile, until
Of many thousand kisses the poor last
I lay upon thy lips.
paragraphs.translated: I am dying, Cleopatra, dying. I just beg death to wait awhile, until I place the last of our many thousands of kisses on your lips.

paragraphs.original:
I dare not, dear,
Dear my lord, pardon, I dare not,
Lest I be taken. Not th' imperious show
Of the full-fortuned Caesar ever shall
Be brooched with me. If knife, drugs, serpents, have
Edge, sting, or operation, I am safe.
Your wife Octavia, with her modest eyes
And still conclusion, shall acquire no honor
Demuring upon me. But come, come, Antony - 
Help me, my women - We must draw thee up.
Assist, good friends.
paragraphs.translated: I don't dare come down - forgive me, my lord - I don't dare, for fear of capture. I will never be exhibited as lucky Caesar's prize. If knives, poison, or snakes have edge, effect, or venom, I am safe from that fate. Your wife Octavia, with her self-effacing eyes and self-righteous assumptions, won't get any praise from patronizing me. But come. Come up here, Antony - help me, ladies - we must carry you up. Help us, good friends.

paragraphs.original: They begin lifting him
paragraphs.translated: They lift him.

paragraphs.original: Oh, quick, or I am gone.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, quick, before I'm gone.

paragraphs.original:
Here's sport indeed! How heavy weighs my lord!
Our strength is all gone into heaviness,
That makes the weight. Had I great Juno's power,
The strong-winged Mercury should fetch thee up
And set thee by Jove's side. Yet come a little.
Wishers were ever fools. Oh, come, come, come!
paragraphs.translated: Such exercise! My lord is so heavy! Our strength has all turned into sadness. That's what makes the weight. If I had the goddess Juno's power, I would make the strong-winged messenger, Mercury, pick you up and seat you beside Jove. Up just a little more - wishes are always foolish - oh, come on, come on, come on!

paragraphs.original: They heave ANTONY aloft to CLEOPATRA
paragraphs.translated:
They lift ANTONY up to CLEOPATRA.

CLEOPATRA.

paragraphs.original:
And welcome, welcome! Die when thou hast lived.
Quicken with kissing. Had my lips that power,
Thus would I wear them out.
paragraphs.translated: And welcome, welcome! Die where you have lived, in my arms. Let me revive you with my kisses. If my lips had the power to give life, I would wear them out like this.

paragraphs.original: She kisses him
paragraphs.translated: She kisses him.

paragraphs.original: A heavy sight!
paragraphs.translated: What a sad sight!

paragraphs.original:
I am dying, Egypt, dying.
Give me some wine and let me speak a little.
paragraphs.translated: I am dying, Cleopatra, dying. Give me some wine and let me say a few words.

paragraphs.original:
No, let me speak, and let me rail so high
That the false huswife Fortune break her wheel,
Provoked by my offense.
paragraphs.translated:
No, let me talk, and let me scold to the heavens, so that
Fortune, that deceitful hussy, will become so upset that she breaks her wheel.
Fortune, that deceitful hussy, will become so upset that she breaks her wheel.

paragraphs.original:
One word, sweet Queen:
Of Caesar seek your honor, with your safety - Oh!
paragraphs.translated: One thing, dear Queen: request honor, as well as safety, from Caesar. Oh!

paragraphs.original: They do not go together.
paragraphs.translated: Honor and safety do not go together.

paragraphs.original:
Gentle, hear me.
None about Caesar trust but Proculeius.
paragraphs.translated: Dear, listen to me: don't trust any of Caesar's men besides Proculeius.

paragraphs.original:
My resolution and my hands I'll trust,
None about Caesar.
paragraphs.translated: I'll trust my determination and my hands, but none of Caesar's men.

paragraphs.original:
The miserable change now at my end
Lament nor sorrow at, but please your thoughts
In feeding them with those my former fortunes,
Wherein I lived the greatest prince o' th' world,
The noblest, and do now not basely die,
Not cowardly put off my helmet to
My countryman - a Roman by a Roman
Valiantly vanquished. Now my spirit is going.
I can no more.
paragraphs.translated: Don't mourn over this unhappy reversal of fortune at the end of my life. Remember my earlier lot, when I lived as the greatest, most noble prince in the world. I'm not dying shamefully, doffing my helmet to my countryman like a coward, but as a Roman, honorably conquered by another Roman. Now I feel my soul leaving. I can't speak any more.

paragraphs.original:
Noblest of men, woo't die?
Hast thou no care of me? Shall I abide
In this dull world, which in thy absence is
No better than a sty? O see, my women,
The crown o' th' earth doth melt. My lord!
paragraphs.translated: Most noble man, will you die? Don't you care about me? Shall I stay in this dreary world, which is no better than a pigsty without you? Oh, look, ladies. The best of the world disappears. My lord!

paragraphs.original: ANTONY dies
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY dies.

paragraphs.original:
Oh, withered is the garland of the war.
The soldier's pole is fall'n! Young boys and girls
Are level now with men. The odds is gone,
And there is nothing left remarkable
Beneath the visiting moon.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, the glory of war has faded. The flags have fallen. Young boys and girls are equal to men. There is nothing distinctive, nothing remarkable left in the world.

paragraphs.original: Oh, quietness, lady!
paragraphs.translated: Oh, stay calm, lady!

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA swoons
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA faints.

paragraphs.original: She's dead too, our sovereign.
paragraphs.translated: Our Queen is dead too.

paragraphs.original: Lady!
paragraphs.translated: Lady!

paragraphs.original: Madam!
paragraphs.translated: Madam!

paragraphs.original: O madam, madam, madam!
paragraphs.translated: Oh, madam, madam, madam!

paragraphs.original: Royal Egypt, Empress!
paragraphs.translated: Royal Egypt, Empress!

paragraphs.original:
CLEOPATRA stirs

stirs
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA wakes up.

paragraphs.original: Peace, peace, Iras.
paragraphs.translated: Quiet, quiet, Iras.

paragraphs.original:
No more but e'en a woman, and commanded
By such poor passion as the maid that milks
And does the meanest chares. It were for me
To throw my scepter at the injurious gods,
To tell them that this world did equal theirs
Till they had stolen our jewel. All's but naught.
Patience is sottish, and impatience does
Become a dog that's mad. Then is it sin
To rush into the secret house of death
Ere death dare come to us? How do you, women?
What, what, good cheer! Why, how now, Charmian?
My noble girls! Ah, women, women! Look,
Our lamp is spent, it's out. Good sirs, take heart.
We'll bury him, and then, what's brave, what's noble,
Let's do 't after the high Roman fashion
And make death proud to take us. Come, away.
This case of that huge spirit now is cold.
Ah, women, women! Come. We have no friend
But resolution, and the briefest end.
paragraphs.translated: Now I am no more than a woman, ruled by the same lowly passion as the maid who milks and does the humblest chores. I might now hurl my scepter at the destructive gods and tell them that this earthly world was as good as their heavenly one, until they stole away its jewel, Antony. Now all is for nothing. Patience is foolish. Impatience suits a mad dog. So why should it be a sin to rush toward death, to seek it out in its hiding place before it dares to come to find me? How are you, my ladies? Tell me! Cheer up! How are you, Charmian? My gallant girls! Ah, ladies, look: the light of our lives has gone out. Good noble ladies, be brave. We'll bury him, and then we'll commit acts as brave and fine as any Romans, and make death proud to take us. Come on, you can go. The container of that great soul is now cold. Ah, ladies, ladies! Let's go. We have no friends but determination and the quickest death.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt, those above bearing off ANTONY's body
paragraphs.translated: They exit, carrying ANTONY's body.

paragraphs.original: Enter CAESAR, with AGRIPPA, DOLABELLA, MAECENAS, GALLUS, and PROCULEIUS, and his council of war
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR enters with his war council: AGRIPPA, DOLABELLA, MAECENAS, GALLUS, and PROCULEIUS.

paragraphs.original:
Go to him, Dolabella, bid him yield.
Being so frustrate, tell him, he mocks
The pauses that he makes.
paragraphs.translated: Dolabella, go see Antony. Tell him to surrender. His position is hopeless. This delay makes him look ridiculous.

paragraphs.original: Caesar, I shall.
paragraphs.translated: Right away, Caesar.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: DOLABELLA exits.

paragraphs.original: Enter DERCETUS, with the sword of ANTONY
paragraphs.translated: DECRETUS enters carrying ANTONY's sword.

paragraphs.original:
Wherefore is that? And what art thou that dar'st
Appear thus to us?
paragraphs.translated: What are you doing with a sword? Who do you think you are coming in here armed?

paragraphs.original:
I am called Dercetus.
Mark Antony I served, who best was worthy
Best to be served. Whilst he stood up and spoke,
He was my master, and I wore my life
To spend upon his haters. If thou please
To take me to thee, as I was to him
I'll be to Caesar. If thou pleasest not,
I yield thee up my life.
paragraphs.translated: My name is Decretus. I served Mark Antony, who was the commander most worthy of my services. While he was alive, I lived only to serve him and oppose his enemies. If you accept my service, I'll serve you the same way. If not, you can kill me.

paragraphs.original: What is 't thou say'st?
paragraphs.translated: What are you saying?

paragraphs.original: I say, O Caesar, Antony is dead.
paragraphs.translated: Caesar, I'm telling you that Antony is dead.

paragraphs.original:
The breaking of so great a thing should make
A greater crack. The round world
Should have shook lions into civil streets
And citizens to their dens. The death of Antony
Is not a single doom. In the name lay
A moiety of the world.
paragraphs.translated: When such a great man dies there should be a thunderclap. The fractured world, in its confusion, should send lions into the city streets and humans into the wilderness to live in lions' dens. This isn't the death of one man. It's the death of half the world.

paragraphs.original:
He is dead, Caesar,
Not by a public minister of justice,
Nor by a hirèd knife, but that self hand
Which writ his honor in the acts it did
Hath, with the courage which the heart did lend it,
Splitted the heart. This is his sword.
I robbed his wound of it. Behold it stained
With his most noble blood.
paragraphs.translated: He's dead, Caesar. Not by public execution or an assassin's knife. He killed himself with the same hand that performed such brave acts. With the courage his heart lent his hand, his hand in turn split his heart. This is his sword. I pulled it from his wound. Look - his noble blood is still on it.

paragraphs.original:
Look you, sad friends,
The gods rebuke me, but it is tidings
To wash the eyes of kings.
paragraphs.translated: Listen, sad friends, though the gods may rebuke me, this news would make kings cry.

paragraphs.original:
And strange it is
That nature must compel us to lament
Our most persisted deeds.
paragraphs.translated: It's strange that human nature makes us grieve for the very thing we've been trying to achieve.

paragraphs.original:
His taints and honors
Waged equal with him.
paragraphs.translated: His faults were equally matched by his virtues.

paragraphs.original:
A rarer spirit never
Did steer humanity, but you gods will give us
Some faults to make us men. Caesar is touched.
paragraphs.translated: There was never a ruler as excellent as he. But gods, you give us faults so we'll be human. Caesar is upset.

paragraphs.original:
When such a spacious mirror's set before him,
He needs must see himself.
paragraphs.translated: It's impossible for him not to see himself in Antony.

paragraphs.original:
O Antony,
I have followed thee to this, but we do launch
Diseases in our bodies. I must perforce
Have shown to thee such a declining day,
Or look on thine. We could not stall together
In the whole world. But yet let me lament
With tears as sovereign as the blood of hearts
That thou, my brother, my competitor
In top of all design, my mate in empire,
Friend and companion in the front of war,
The arm of mine own body, and the heart
Where mine his thoughts did kindle - that our stars,
Unreconcilable, should divide
Our equalness to this. Hear me, good friends -
paragraphs.translated:
Oh, Antony. I drove you to this. But we have to get rid of a disease if it threatens our body. Either I had to ruin you, or you would have ruined me.
There wasn't enough room in the world for both of us. Even so, let me mourn, with tears that heal like a bloodletting, that you - my brother, my greatest competitor, my partner in rule, my friend and companion on the battlefield, the very arm of my body, and the heart in which mine own heart's thoughts lived - that our fates could not be reconciled, which caused us to divide ourselves from one another.
Let me tell you, friends -

paragraphs.original: Enter an EGYPTIAN
paragraphs.translated: An EGYPTIAN enters.

paragraphs.original:
But I will tell you at some meeter season.
The business of this man looks out of him.
We'll hear him what he says. (to EGYPTIAN ) Whence are you?
(to

)

A poor Egyptian yet, the Queen my mistress,
Confined in all she has, her monument,
Of thy intents desires instruction,
That she preparedly may frame herself
To th' way she's forced to.
paragraphs.translated: A poor Egyptian, but my mistress, the Queen, sent me to find out what your intentions are concerning her. She's locked up in her tomb and wants to prepare herself for her fate.

paragraphs.original:
Bid her have good heart.
She soon shall know of us, by some of ours,
How honorable and how kindly we
Determine for her, for Caesar cannot live
To be ungentle.
paragraphs.translated: Tell her to put her mind at rest. She'll find out soon enough by one of our messengers how respectfully and kindly we plan to treat her. I cannot be taught how to be cruel.

paragraphs.original: So the gods preserve thee!
paragraphs.translated: May the gods bless you.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original:
Come hither, Proculeius. Go and say
We purpose her no shame. Give her what comforts
The quality of her passion shall require,
Lest, in her greatness, by some mortal stroke
She do defeat us, for her life in Rome
Would be eternal in our triumph. Go,
And with your speediest bring us what she says
And how you find of her.
paragraphs.translated: Come here, Proculeius. Tell her we mean her no disrespect. Give her whatever assurances you feel she needs to keep her from killing herself. I need her alive, so that I can exhibit her in my triumphal procession and gain eternal fame. Go, and hurry back to bring us her reply and news of her state of mind.

paragraphs.original: Caesar, I shall.
paragraphs.translated: I will, Caesar.

paragraphs.original: Exit PROCULEIUS
paragraphs.translated: PROCULEIUS exits.

paragraphs.original: Gallus, go you along.
paragraphs.translated: Gallus, you go with him.

paragraphs.original: Exit GALLUS
paragraphs.translated: GALLUS exits.

paragraphs.original:
Where's Dolabella,
To second Proculeius?
paragraphs.translated: Where's Dolabella? He's supposed to support Proculeius.

paragraphs.original: Dolabella!
paragraphs.translated: Dolabella!

paragraphs.original:
Let him alone, for I remember now
How he's employed. He shall in time be ready.
Go with me to my tent, where you shall see
How hardly I was drawn into this war,
How calm and gentle I proceeded still
In all my writings. Go with me and see
What I can show in this.
paragraphs.translated: Never mind. I remember he's already occupied. He'll be done in time. Come with me. In my tent I'll show you how unwillingly I was drawn into this war. You'll see how calm and gentle my letters to Antony always were. Come and see the proof.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter CLEOPATRA, CHARMIAN, and IRAS
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA, CHARMIAN, and IRAS enter.

paragraphs.original:
My desolation does begin to make
A better life. 'Tis paltry to be Caesar.
Not being Fortune, he's but Fortune's knave,
A minister of her will. And it is great
To do that thing that ends all other deeds,
Which shackles accidents and bolts up change,
Which sleeps and never palates more the dung,
The beggar's nurse, and Caesar's.
paragraphs.translated: Being alone has helped me better understand my life. It's pathetic to be Caesar. He can't be Fortune; he's only Fortune's errand boy. It would be a great deed to commit suicide - that act which ends all other things, which makes all accidents and changes stop. Which causes you to sleep, and takes you away from earthly concerns.

paragraphs.original: Enter PROCULEIUS
paragraphs.translated: PROCULEIUS enters.

paragraphs.original:
Caesar sends greeting to the Queen of Egypt,
And bids thee study on what fair demands
Thou mean'st to have him grant thee.
paragraphs.translated: Caesar greets the Queen of Egypt and asks that you consider what you will ask from him.

paragraphs.original: What's thy name?
paragraphs.translated: What's your name?

paragraphs.original: My name is Proculeius.
paragraphs.translated: My name is Proculeius.

paragraphs.original:
Antony
Did tell me of you, bade me trust you, but
I do not greatly care to be deceived,
That have no use for trusting. If your master
Would have a queen his beggar, you must tell him,
That majesty, to keep decorum, must
No less beg than a kingdom. If he please
To give me conquered Egypt for my son,
He gives me so much of mine own as I
Will kneel to him with thanks.
paragraphs.translated:
Antony told me about you. He said you were a man I could trust. But I don't worry about being deceived because I don't need to trust. If your master wants a queen to beg from him, you should tell him that a queen will beg for no less than a kingdom.
If he will grant me conquered Egypt, so that I may give it to my son, I will kneel to him with thanks.

paragraphs.original:
Be of good cheer.
You're fall'n into a princely hand. Fear nothing.
Make your full reference freely to my lord,
Who is so full of grace that it flows over
On all that need. Let me report to him
Your sweet dependency, and you shall find
A conqueror that will pray in aid for kindness
Where he for grace is kneeled to.
paragraphs.translated: Be content. You're in the charge of an honorable man. Don't be afraid. You can ask for anything from my lord. His generosity flows to anyone in need. If I can tell him that you have submitted to him sweetly, he'll request your assistance in finding ways in which he can support you.

paragraphs.original:
Pray you, tell him
I am his fortune's vassal, and I send him
The greatness he has got. I hourly learn
A doctrine of obedience, and would gladly
Look him i' th' face.
paragraphs.translated: Please tell him I have surrendered to his fortune. I give up to him the glory he has won. I'm learning every hour how to be subservient. I'd be happy to meet with him in person.

paragraphs.original:
This I'll report, dear lady.
Have comfort, for I know your plight is pitied
Of him that caused it.
paragraphs.translated: I'll tell him all of this, dear lady. Be at ease. I know he's sorry for your situation, especially since he caused it.

paragraphs.original: GALLUS and Roman soldiers enter from behind and take CLEOPATRA prisoner
paragraphs.translated: GALLUS enters with soldiers. They seize CLEOPATRA.

paragraphs.original:
You see how easily she may be surprised.
(to the soldiers) Guard her till Caesar come.
(to the soldiers)
paragraphs.translated:
(to PROCULEIUS ) See how easy it was to capture her? (to soldiers) Guard her until Caesar arrives.
(to

)
(to soldiers)

paragraphs.original: Royal Queen!
paragraphs.translated: Your majesty!

paragraphs.original: O Cleopatra! Thou art taken, Queen.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, Cleopatra! You've been betrayed, my Queen!

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA draws a dagger
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA pulls out a knife.

paragraphs.original: Quick, quick, good hands.
paragraphs.translated: Quick, quick good hands!

paragraphs.original: PROCULEIUS seizes the dagger
paragraphs.translated: She tries to stab herself, but PROCULEIUS seizes the dagger.

paragraphs.original:
Hold, worthy lady, hold!
Do not yourself such wrong, who are in this
Relieved but not betrayed.
paragraphs.translated: Stop, brave lady, stop! Don't do such a shameful thing to yourself. We've rescued you from yourself. We have not betrayed you.

paragraphs.original:
What, of death too,
That rids our dogs of languish?
paragraphs.translated: What, am I being denied death, as well? The thing which even dogs are given, to rid them of their suffering?

paragraphs.original:
Cleopatra,
Do not abuse my master's bounty by
Th' undoing of yourself. Let the world see
His nobleness well acted, which your death
Will never let come forth.
paragraphs.translated: Don't insult my master's generosity by killing yourself. The world will see how noble he is by the way he treats you. Your death would prevent that.

paragraphs.original:
Where art thou, Death?
Come hither, come! Come, come and take a queen
Worth many babes and beggars!
paragraphs.translated: Where are you, Death? Come here. Come, and you can have a queen. One queen is worth more than a whole number of babies and beggars, your cheapest conquests.

paragraphs.original: Oh, temperance, lady!
paragraphs.translated: Oh, control yourself, lady!

paragraphs.original:
Sir, I will eat no meat, I'll not drink, sir.
If idle talk will once be necessary,
I'll not sleep neither. This mortal house I'll ruin,
Do Caesar what he can. Know, sir, that I
Will not wait pinioned at your master's court,
Nor once be chastised with the sober eye
Of dull Octavia. Shall they hoist me up
And show me to the shouting varletry
Of censuring Rome? Rather a ditch in Egypt
Be gentle grave unto me. Rather on Nilus' mud
Lay me stark naked and let the waterflies
Blow me into abhorring. Rather make
My country's high pyramides my gibbet
And hang me up in chains!
paragraphs.translated:
Sir, I won't eat. I won't drink. And don't expect me to talk. I won't sleep either. I'll destroy my body. Let Caesar do whatever he wants. You'd better understand that I won't wait till I'm chained up in your master's court, and I won't let myself be scolded even once by dull Octavia. Shall I let them exhibit me to the shouting mobs of Rome?
I'd rather die in a ditch in Egypt, and make it my gentle grave. I'd rather lie in the Nile mud with flies laying their eggs in me, making me disgusting. I'd rather be hung in chains from one of our pyramids!

paragraphs.original:
You do extend
These thoughts of horror further than you shall
Find cause in Caesar.
paragraphs.translated: You're letting yourself get carried away with these horrible thoughts. You'll see that Caesar is giving you no reason to do so.

paragraphs.original: Enter DOLABELLA
paragraphs.translated: DOLABELLA enters.

paragraphs.original:
Proculeius,
What thou hast done thy master Caesar knows,
And he hath sent for thee. For the Queen,
I'll take her to my guard.
paragraphs.translated: Proculeius, Caesar has heard about what you've done here and has sent for you. I'll take the Queen into my custody.

paragraphs.original:
So, Dolabella,
It shall content me best. Be gentle to her.
(to CLEOPATRA ) To Caesar I will speak what you shall please,
(to

)
If you'll employ me to him.
Say I would die.
paragraphs.translated: Tell him I'd like to die.

paragraphs.original: Exit PROCULEIUS
paragraphs.translated: PROCULEIUS exits.

paragraphs.original: Most noble Empress, you have heard of me?
paragraphs.translated: Have you heard of me, most noble Empress?

paragraphs.original: I cannot tell.
paragraphs.translated: I don't remember.

paragraphs.original: Assuredly you know me.
paragraphs.translated: I'm sure you've heard of me.

paragraphs.original:
No matter, sir, what I have heard or known.
You laugh when boys or women tell their dreams.
Is 't not your trick?
paragraphs.translated: It doesn't matter what I've heard or known. You must be the one who laughs when boys or women tell you their dreams. Isn't that your habit?

paragraphs.original: I understand not, madam.
paragraphs.translated: I don't know what you mean, madam.

paragraphs.original:
I dreamt there was an emperor Antony.
Oh, such another sleep, that I might see
But such another man!
paragraphs.translated: I dreamed about an emperor called Antony. Oh, I wish I could sleep again, so I could have another dream like that!

paragraphs.original: If it might please ye -
paragraphs.translated: If you'd like -

paragraphs.original:
His face was as the heavens, and therein stuck
A sun and moon, which kept their course and lighted
The little "O," the earth.
paragraphs.translated: Authority radiated from his face, and his presence brought knowledge and order to the people of earth.

paragraphs.original: Most sovereign creature -
paragraphs.translated: Your majesty -

paragraphs.original:
His legs bestrid the ocean. His reared arm
Crested the world. His voice was propertied
As all the tunèd spheres, and that to friends.
But when he meant to quail and shake the orb,
He was as rattling thunder. For his bounty,
There was no winter in 't, an autumn 'twas
That grew the more by reaping. His delights
Were dolphinlike; they showed his back above
The element they lived in. In his livery
Walked crowns and crownets. Realms and islands were
As plates dropped from his pocket.
paragraphs.translated: His power extended from one shore to the other, as if he straddled the ocean with his legs. When he raised his arm in command, the world trembled. He spoke exquisitely to his friends, but when he wanted to terrify the world, his voice was like thunder. There was no end to his generosity. The more he gave, the more he wanted to give. His amusements showed another side of him, one detached from his world of responsibility and duty. Kings and noblemen served him. Kingdoms and provinces dropped from his pockets like loose change.

paragraphs.original: Cleopatra -
paragraphs.translated: Cleopatra -

paragraphs.original:
Think you there was or might be such a man
As this I dreamt of?
paragraphs.translated: Do you think there ever was, or could there ever be, a man such as the one I dreamed about?

paragraphs.original: Gentle madam, no.
paragraphs.translated: No, gentle madam.

paragraphs.original:
You lie up to the hearing of the gods.
But if there be nor ever were one such,
It's past the size of dreaming. Nature wants stuff
To vie strange forms with fancy, yet t' imagine
An Antony were nature's piece 'gainst fancy,
Condemning shadows quite.
paragraphs.translated: The gods can hear you lying! But if there ever were such a man, simple dreams could never contain his greatness. When it comes to creating fantastical things, the natural world cannot compete with imagination. And yet, if the natural world could create something like Antony, it would have a masterpiece to rival anything fantasy might construct. Antony would easily outshine all imaginary beings.

paragraphs.original:
Hear me, good madam.
Your loss is as yourself, great, and you bear it
As answering to the weight. Would I might never
O'ertake pursued success, but I do feel,
By the rebound of yours, a grief that smites
My very heart at root.
paragraphs.translated: Listen to me, madam. You are a remarkable person and your loss is equally remarkable. You are responding appropriately to the greatness of that loss. I hope I never achieve success if I don't feel some of your heartbroken grief right now.

paragraphs.original:
I thank you, sir.
Know you what Caesar means to do with me?
paragraphs.translated: Thank you, sir. Do you know what Caesar intends to do with me?

paragraphs.original: I am loath to tell you what I would you knew.
paragraphs.translated: I'm reluctant to tell you what I wish you knew.

paragraphs.original: Nay, pray you, sir.
paragraphs.translated: Please, sir -

paragraphs.original: Though he be honorable -
paragraphs.translated: Though he is honorable -

paragraphs.original: He'll lead me, then, in triumph.
paragraphs.translated: He'll still parade me through Rome as a trophy of war.

paragraphs.original: Madam, he will. I know 't.
paragraphs.translated: I know he will, madam.

paragraphs.original: Flourish. Enter CAESAR, PROCULEIUS, GALLUS, MAECENAS, and other ATTENDANTS
paragraphs.translated: Trumpets sound a royal fanfare. CAESAR, PROCULEIUS, GALLUS, MAECENAS, and other ATTENDANTS enter.

paragraphs.original: Make way there! Caesar!
paragraphs.translated: Stand aside for Caesar.

paragraphs.original: Which is the Queen of Egypt?
paragraphs.translated: Which of these ladies is the Queen of Egypt?

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA kneels
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA kneels.

paragraphs.original:
Arise, you shall not kneel.
I pray you, rise. Rise, Egypt.
paragraphs.translated: Arise. You need not kneel to me. Please rise, Queen.

paragraphs.original:
Sir, the gods
Will have it thus. My master and my lord
I must obey.
paragraphs.translated: The gods have ordained it to be like this, sir. You are my lord and master. I must obey.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA stands
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA stands up.

paragraphs.original:
Take to you no hard thoughts.
The record of what injuries you did us,
Though written in our flesh, we shall remember
As things but done by chance.
paragraphs.translated: Don't think I blame you. Whatever injuries I received in the war, I put down to the fortunes of war.

paragraphs.original:
Sole sir o' th' world,
I cannot project mine own cause so well
To make it clear, but do confess I have
Been laden with like frailties which before
Have often shamed our sex.
paragraphs.translated: You are now the sole lord of the entire world. I can't explain my cause very clearly. I must admit to having the weaknesses that all women are accused of.

paragraphs.original:
Cleopatra, know
We will extenuate rather than enforce.
If you apply yourself to our intents,
Which towards you are most gentle, you shall find
A benefit in this change, but if you seek
To lay on me a cruelty by taking
Antony's course, you shall bereave yourself
Of my good purposes and put your children
To that destruction which I'll guard them from
If thereon you rely. I'll take my leave.
paragraphs.translated:
Cleopatra, understand that, rather than emphasize our power over you, we will soften if you accept our intentions, which are very compassionate toward you. Your acceptance will benefit you, but if you try to make me look cruel by committing suicide as Antony did, I won't be so generous.
Your children will be destroyed, a fate your submission will save them from. I'll leave you now.

paragraphs.original:
And may, through all the world! 'Tis yours, and we,
Your scutcheons and your signs of conquest, shall
Hang in what place you please. Here, my good lord.
paragraphs.translated: You may do whatever you want in the world. It's yours, and you may hang us, your trophies of war, anywhere you like. Here, my good lord.

paragraphs.original: She gives him a scroll
paragraphs.translated: She hands him a list.

paragraphs.original: You shall advise me in all for Cleopatra.
paragraphs.translated: You shall advise me in everything having to do with Cleopatra.

paragraphs.original:
This is the brief of money, plate, and jewels
I am possessed of. 'Tis exactly valued,
Not petty things admitted. Where's Seleucus?
paragraphs.translated: This is the inventory of the money, silverware, dishes, and jewels that are still in my possession. It's an exact list. Not even trivial things were left out. Where's Seleucus?

paragraphs.original: Enter SELEUCUS
paragraphs.translated: SELEUCUS enters.

paragraphs.original: Here, madam.
paragraphs.translated: Here, madam.

paragraphs.original:
This is my treasurer. Let him speak, my lord,
Upon his peril, that I have reserved
To myself nothing. - Speak the truth, Seleucus.
 -
paragraphs.translated: This is my treasurer. My lord, he will swear on his life that I haven't kept a thing. - Tell the truth, Seleucus.

paragraphs.original:
Madam, I had rather seal my lips
Than to my peril speak that which is not.
paragraphs.translated: Madam, I'd rather sew my lips shut than tell a lie when my life depends upon it.

paragraphs.original: What have I kept back?
paragraphs.translated: What did I keep for myself?

paragraphs.original: Enough to purchase what you have made known.
paragraphs.translated: Enough to buy everything you have declared.

paragraphs.original:
Nay, blush not, Cleopatra. I approve
Your wisdom in the deed.
paragraphs.translated: No, don't be ashamed, Cleopatra. You're very prudent to set a little aside.

paragraphs.original:
See, Caesar! Oh, behold
How pomp is followed! Mine will now be yours,
And, should we shift estates, yours would be mine.
The ingratitude of this Seleucus does
Even make me wild. (to SELEUCUS ) O slave, of no more trust
(to

)
Than love that's hired!
                                             What, goest thou back? Thou shalt
Go back, I warrant thee! But I'll catch thine eyes,
Though they had wings. Slave, soulless villain, dog!
Oh, rarely base!
paragraphs.translated:
Look around you, Caesar. Oh, just see what happens after the pageantry is over! What is mine will be yours now. If we were to change places, what is yours would be mine. Seleucus' ingratitude makes me wild. (to SELEUCUS ) Oh, you slave! I can't trust you any more than a prostitute.
(to

)
What are you doing? Cringing away? I'll give you a good reason to cringe, I promise you. I'll scratch out your eyes, even if they could fly. You slave! Soulless villain! Dog! Oh, that was unbelievably low!

paragraphs.original: Good Queen, let us entreat you -
paragraphs.translated: Good Queen, let me implore you -

paragraphs.original:
O Caesar, what a wounding shame is this,
That thou, vouchsafing here to visit me,
Doing the honor of thy lordliness
