To one so meek, that mine own servant should
Parcel the sum of my disgraces by
Addition of his envy! Say, good Caesar,
That I some lady trifles have reserved,
Immoment toys, things of such dignity
As we greet modern friends withal, and say
Some nobler token I have kept apart
For Livia and Octavia, to induce
Their mediation, must I be unfolded
With one that I have bred? The gods! It smites me
Beneath the fall I have. (to SELEUCUS ) Prithee, go hence,
(to

)
Or I shall show the cinders of my spirit
Through th' ashes of my chance. Wert thou a man,
Thou wouldst have mercy on me.
paragraphs.translated:
Oh, Caesar, I am so ashamed. You condescended to visit me here, honoring my humble self with your lordly presence. And one of my own servants increases my disgrace by adding his envy! Suppose, good Caesar, that I have saved a few feminine trifles, some unimportant trinkets. These have worth only as gifts to friends. And suppose I have kept a few more expensive gifts aside for
Livia and Octavia, to solicit their good wishes. Must I then be exposed by a person I've supported? By the gods! It adds another blow to the many I have already. (to SELEUCUS ) Please leave, or I'll show you what's left of my spirit since my fortune was ruined. If you were a real man, you would have had mercy on me.
Livia



(to

)

paragraphs.original: Forbear, Seleucus.
paragraphs.translated: Leave, Seleucus.

paragraphs.original: Exit SELEUCUS
paragraphs.translated: SELEUCUS exits.

paragraphs.original:
Be it known that we, the greatest, are misthought
For things that others do, and when we fall
We answer others' merits in our name,
Are therefore to be pitied.
paragraphs.translated: You should also know that as head of state, we are often blamed for the crimes of others. And though we may fall, we are still responsible for their offenses. I am therefore to be pitied.

paragraphs.original:
Cleopatra,
Not what you have reserved nor what acknowledged
Put we i' th' roll of conquest. Still be 't yours.
Bestow it at your pleasure, and believe
Caesar's no merchant, to make prize with you
Of things that merchants sold. Therefore be cheered.
Make not your thoughts your prison. No, dear Queen,
For we intend so to dispose you as
Yourself shall give us counsel. Feed and sleep.
Our care and pity is so much upon you
That we remain your friend. And so, adieu.
paragraphs.translated: Cleopatra, our conquest won't include either the things you kept back or the ones you listed. It's all still yours. Do whatever you like with it. You can trust that Caesar is not a merchant to haggle with you over your property. So cheer up. Don't be captured by your depressed thoughts. No, dear Queen. We want to follow your own counsel when making arrangements for you. Eat and sleep. I have so much care and pity for you that you could call me friend. And so, good-bye.

paragraphs.original: My master, and my lord!
paragraphs.translated: My master and my lord!

paragraphs.original: Not so. Adieu.
paragraphs.translated: Not true. Good-bye.

paragraphs.original: Flourish. Exeunt CAESAR and his train
paragraphs.translated: Trumpet flourish. CAESAR and his entourage exit.

paragraphs.original:
He words me, girls, he words me, that I should not
Be noble to myself. But, hark thee, Charmian.
paragraphs.translated: He's trying to talk me into forgetting my nobility, girls. But listen, Charmian.

paragraphs.original: She whispers to CHARMIAN
paragraphs.translated: She whispers to CHARMIAN.

paragraphs.original:
Finish, good lady. The bright day is done,
And we are for the dark.
paragraphs.translated: It's time to end it, good lady. The bright day of our lives is over, and now there will only be darkness.

paragraphs.original:
(to CHARMIAN )        Hie thee again.
         (to

)        
I have spoke already, and it is provided.
Go put it to the haste.
Madam, I will.
paragraphs.translated: I will, madam.

paragraphs.original: Enter DOLABELLA
paragraphs.translated: DOLABELLA enters.

paragraphs.original: Where's the Queen?
paragraphs.translated: Where's the Queen?

paragraphs.original: Behold, sir.
paragraphs.translated: Look, sir.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: She exits.

paragraphs.original: Dolabella!
paragraphs.translated: Dolabella.

paragraphs.original:
Madam, as thereto sworn by your command,
Which my love makes religion to obey,
I tell you this: Caesar through Syria
Intends his journey, and within three days
You with your children will he send before.
Make your best use of this. I have performed
Your pleasure and my promise.
paragraphs.translated: Madam, according to my promise - which my love to you has made a religious vow - I tell you that Caesar intends to travel through Syria. Within three days you and your children will be sent ahead. Make the best use of this information you can. I have done your bidding and fulfilled my promise.

paragraphs.original:
Dolabella,
I shall remain your debtor.
paragraphs.translated: Dolabella, I will always be in debt to you.

paragraphs.original:
I your servant.
Adieu, good Queen. I must attend on Caesar.
paragraphs.translated: And I your servant. Good-bye, good Queen. I must go attend Caesar.

paragraphs.original: Farewell, and thanks.
paragraphs.translated: Farewell, and thanks.

paragraphs.original: Exit DOLABELLA
paragraphs.translated: DOLABELLA exits.

paragraphs.original:
Now, Iras, what think'st thou?
Thou an Egyptian puppet shalt be shown
In Rome, as well as I. Mechanic slaves
With greasy aprons, rules, and hammers shall
Uplift us to the view. In their thick breaths,
Rank of gross diet, shall be enclouded,
And forced to drink their vapor.
paragraphs.translated: Now, Iras, what do you think? You will be exhibited in Rome along with me, like Egyptian puppets. Crude slaves with greasy aprons, rulers, and hammers shall lift us up so everyone can see. Their stinking breath will form a cloud around us, and we'll be forced to inhale it.

paragraphs.original: The gods forbid!
paragraphs.translated: The gods forbid!

paragraphs.original:
Nay, 'tis most certain, Iras. Saucy lictors
Will catch at us like strumpets, and scald rhymers
Ballad us out o' tune. The quick comedians
Extemporally will stage us and present
Our Alexandrian revels. Antony
Shall be brought drunken forth, and I shall see
Some squeaking Cleopatra boy my greatness
I' th' posture of a whore.
paragraphs.translated:
No, it's certain, Iras. Insolent
lictors will paw us as if we were streetwalkers. Disreputable minstrels will write bawdy songs about us. Hotheaded comedians will stage impromptu impersonations of us and depict the celebrations we had in Alexandria. Antony will be portrayed as a drunk, and I'll see some boy with a squeaking voice play Cleopatra as if I were a whore.
lictors

paragraphs.original: Oh, the good gods!
paragraphs.translated: Oh, the good gods!

paragraphs.original: Nay, that's certain.
paragraphs.translated: No, that's the truth.

paragraphs.original:
I'll never see 't! For I am sure mine nails
Are stronger than mine eyes.
paragraphs.translated: I'll never see it. I know my nails are stronger than my eyes; I'll scratch them out.

paragraphs.original:
Why, that's the way
To fool their preparation and to conquer
Their most absurd intents.
paragraphs.translated: Why, that's just the way to frustrate their plans and defeat their absurd intentions.

paragraphs.original: Enter CHARMIAN
paragraphs.translated: CHARMIAN enters.

paragraphs.original:
Now, Charmian!
Show me, my women, like a queen. Go fetch
My best attires. I am again for Cydnus,
To meet Mark Antony. - Sirrah Iras, go. - 
Now, noble Charmian, we'll dispatch indeed,
And when thou hast done this chare I'll give thee leave
To play till doomsday. (to IRAS ) Bring our crown and all.
(to

)
Exit IRAS. A noise within
paragraphs.translated: IRAS exits. A noise offstage.

paragraphs.original: Wherefore's this noise?
paragraphs.translated: What's that noise?

paragraphs.original: Enter a GUARDSMAN
paragraphs.translated: A GUARDSMAN enters.

paragraphs.original:
Here is a rural fellow
That will not be denied your Highness' presence.
He brings you figs.
paragraphs.translated: There's a farmer here who won't leave without seeing your Highness. He has brought you figs.

paragraphs.original: Let him come in.
paragraphs.translated: Let him come in.

paragraphs.original: Exit GUARDSMAN
paragraphs.translated: The GUARDSMAN exits.

paragraphs.original:
What poor an instrument
May do a noble deed! He brings me liberty.
My resolution's placed, and I have nothing
Of woman in me. Now from head to foot
I am marble-constant. Now the fleeting moon
No planet is of mine.
paragraphs.translated: What a poor instrument, that can do such a noble deed! He brings me freedom. My mind is made up. There's nothing of the weak woman left in me. Now from head to foot I'm as firm as marble. Now the inconstant moon has nothing to do with me.

paragraphs.original: Enter GUARDSMAN, and COUNTRYMAN bringing in a basket
paragraphs.translated: The GUARDSMAN enters with a COUNTRYMAN, who carries a basket.

paragraphs.original: This is the man.
paragraphs.translated: This is the man.

paragraphs.original: Avoid, and leave him.
paragraphs.translated: Leave us.

paragraphs.original: Exit GUARDSMAN
paragraphs.translated: The GUARDSMAN exits.

paragraphs.original:
Hast thou the pretty worm of Nilus there,
That kills and pains not?
paragraphs.translated: Do you have in there the pretty snake of the Nile that kills without pain?

paragraphs.original: Truly, I have him, but I would not be the party that should desire you to touch him, for his biting is immortal. Those that do die of it do seldom or never recover.
paragraphs.translated: I certainly do have him, but I wouldn't advise you to touch him. His bite is fatal. People who die of it seldom or never recover.

paragraphs.original: Remember'st thou any that have died on 't?
paragraphs.translated: Do you remember anyone who died of it?

paragraphs.original: Very many, men and women too. I heard of one of them no longer than yesterday - a very honest woman, but something given to lie, as a woman should not do but in the way of honesty - how she died of the biting of it, what pain she felt. Truly, she makes a very good report o' th' worm. But he that will believe all that they say shall never be saved by half that they do. But this is most falliable, the worm's an odd worm.
paragraphs.translated: Many people, men and women alike. I heard of one just yesterday. She was a very honest woman but rather inclined to lie - which a woman shouldn't do unless she's protecting her reputation. I heard how she died of its bite, how much pain she felt. Indeed, she gives a very good testimony of the snake's power. But if you believe everything they say, you won't be saved by half of what they do. But this is a sure thing: the snake's an odd snake.

paragraphs.original: Get thee hence, farewell.
paragraphs.translated: You may leave now. Farewell.

paragraphs.original: I wish you all joy of the worm.
paragraphs.translated: I hope you are pleased with the snake.

paragraphs.original: He sets down his basket
paragraphs.translated: He sets down the basket.

paragraphs.original: Farewell.
paragraphs.translated: Farewell.

paragraphs.original: You must think this, look you, that the worm will do his kind.
paragraphs.translated: You must know that the snake will act according to his nature.

paragraphs.original: Ay, ay. Farewell.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, yes. Farewell.

paragraphs.original: Look you, the worm is not to be trusted but in the keeping of wise people, for indeed there is no goodness in the worm.
paragraphs.translated: Listen, the snake is dangerous unless handled by people who are used to him. There isn't any kindness in the snake.

paragraphs.original: Take thou no care. It shall be heeded.
paragraphs.translated: Don't worry; we'll remember your warnings.

paragraphs.original: Very good. Give it nothing, I pray you, for it is not worth the feeding.
paragraphs.translated: Good. Don't feed it, I beg you. It's not worth feeding.

paragraphs.original: Will it eat me?
paragraphs.translated: Will it eat me?

paragraphs.original: You must not think I am so simple but I know the devil himself will not eat a woman. I know that a woman is a dish for the gods, if the devil dress her not. But, truly, these same whoreson devils do the gods great harm in their women, for in every ten that they make, the devils mar five.
paragraphs.translated: Don't think I'm so dumb that I don't know that the devil himself won't eat a woman. I know that a woman is a dish fit only for the gods, as long as the devil hasn't prepared the meal. But devils cause a lot of trouble for the gods regarding their women. For every ten women the gods make, the devils ruin five.

paragraphs.original: Well, get thee gone. Farewell.
paragraphs.translated: Well, you can go now. Farewell.

paragraphs.original: Yes, forsooth. I wish you joy o' th' worm.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, truly, I wish you good luck with the snake.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: Enter IRAS with royal attire
paragraphs.translated: IRAS enters, carrying CLEOPATRA's royal regalia.

paragraphs.original:
Give me my robe. Put on my crown. I have
Immortal longings in me. Now no more
The juice of Egypt's grape shall moist this lip.
paragraphs.translated: Give me my robe. Put on my crown. I long to be immortal. I won't drink Egyptian wine again.

paragraphs.original: The women dress her
paragraphs.translated: CHARMIAN and IRAS begin to dress her.

paragraphs.original:
Yare, yare, good Iras, quick. Methinks I hear
Antony call. I see him rouse himself
To praise my noble act. I hear him mock
The luck of Caesar, which the gods give men
To excuse their after wrath. - Husband, I come!
Now to that name my courage prove my title!
I am fire and air, my other elements
I give to baser life. - So, have you done?
Come then and take the last warmth of my lips.
Farewell, kind Charmian. Iras, long farewell.
paragraphs.translated: Quickly, quickly, good Iras, quickly. I think I hear Antony call me. I see him revive himself to praise my noble act. I hear him mock Caesar's luck, which the gods give to men in order to balance out their subsequent wrath. Husband, I'm coming! Now let my courage prove my title as wife. I am now made of fire and air, and I leave the other elements, earth and water, to this mortal life. So, are you done? Come then, kiss me and take the last bit of warmth from my lips. Good-bye, kind Charmian. Iras, I won't see you again for a long time.

paragraphs.original: She kisses them. IRAS falls and dies
paragraphs.translated: She kisses them. IRAS collapses and dies.

paragraphs.original:
Have I the aspic in my lips? Dost fall?
If thou and nature can so gently part,
The stroke of death is as a lover's pinch,
Which hurts, and is desired. Dost thou lie still?
If thus thou vanishest, thou tell'st the world
It is not worth leave-taking.
paragraphs.translated: Do I have the asp's poison on my lips? Did you fall? If you can leave your body so easily, then the touch of death is like a lover's pinch, which hurts but is desired. Do you lie still? If you leave like that, you tell the world that it's not worthy of a good-bye.

paragraphs.original:
Dissolve, thick cloud, and rain, that I may say
The gods themselves do weep!
paragraphs.translated: Clouds, dissolve into rain, so that I could say the gods themselves are weeping!

paragraphs.original:
This proves me base.
If she first meet the curlèd Antony,
He'll make demand of her and spend that kiss
Which is my heaven to have.  - Come, thou mortal wretch,
paragraphs.translated:
This proves that I'm petty: if Iras meets Antony before me, he'll want her first and give her the kiss that is my bliss to have.
Come, you deadly villain.

paragraphs.original: She places an asp on her breast
paragraphs.translated: She puts the snake on her breast.

paragraphs.original:
With thy sharp teeth this knot intrinsicate
Of life at once untie. Poor venomous fool
Be angry and dispatch. Oh, couldst thou speak,
That I might hear thee call great Caesar ass
Unpolicied!
paragraphs.translated: Separate me from life with your sharp teeth. Poor poisonous fool, be angry and bite. Oh, if you could speak, I might hear you call Caesar an ass who's been outsmarted!

paragraphs.original: O eastern star!
paragraphs.translated: Oh, eastern star!

paragraphs.original:
Peace, peace!
Dost thou not see my baby at my breast,
That sucks the nurse asleep?
paragraphs.translated: Quiet, quiet! Don't you see my baby suckling at my breast so that its nurse will fall asleep?

paragraphs.original: Oh, break! Oh, break!
paragraphs.translated: Oh, if my heart would only break!

paragraphs.original:
As sweet as balm, as soft as air, as gentle - 
O Antony! - Nay, I will take thee too.
paragraphs.translated: The poison is as sweet as balm, as soft as air, as gentle - Oh, Antony! - No, I'll take you too.

paragraphs.original: Applying another asp to her arm
paragraphs.translated: She puts another snake on her arm.

paragraphs.original: What should I stay -
paragraphs.translated: Why should I stay -

paragraphs.original: Dies
paragraphs.translated: She dies.

paragraphs.original:
In this wild world? So, fare thee well.
Now boast thee, Death, in thy possession lies
A lass unparalleled. Downy windows, close,
paragraphs.translated: In this vile world? So, good-bye. Now, Death, you can boast that you have an incomparable girl in your possession. Close, soft eyes.

paragraphs.original: She closes CLEOPATRA's eyes
paragraphs.translated: She closes CLEOPATRA's eyes.

paragraphs.original:
And golden Phoebus never be beheld
Of eyes again so royal! Your crown's awry.
I'll mend it and then play -
paragraphs.translated: The sun will never be seen by such royal eyes again. Your crown is crooked. I'll straighten it, then play -

paragraphs.original: Enter the GUARD, rustling in
paragraphs.translated: The GUARDS rush in noisily.

paragraphs.original: Where's the Queen?
paragraphs.translated: Where's the Queen?

paragraphs.original: Speak softly. Wake her not.
paragraphs.translated: Speak softly. Don't wake her.

paragraphs.original: Caesar hath sent -
paragraphs.translated: Caesar has sent -

paragraphs.original: Too slow a messenger.
paragraphs.translated: Too slow a messenger.

paragraphs.original: She applies an asp to herself.
paragraphs.translated: She applies an asp to herself.

paragraphs.original: Oh, come apace, dispatch! I partly feel thee.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, come quickly! I almost feel you.

paragraphs.original:
(calling) Approach, ho! All's not well. Caesar's beguiled.
(calling)
paragraphs.translated:
(calling) Come in. Ho! All's not well. Caesar's been deceived.
(calling)

paragraphs.original: There's Dolabella sent from Caesar. Call him.
paragraphs.translated: There's Dolabella, who was sent from Caesar. Call him.

paragraphs.original:
Exit SECOND GUARD
Exit
paragraphs.translated: The SECOND GUARD exits.

paragraphs.original: What work is here, Charmian? Is this well done?
paragraphs.translated: What kind of work is this, Charmian? Is this well done?

paragraphs.original:
It is well done and fitting for a princess
Descended of so many royal kings.
Ah, soldier!
paragraphs.translated: It is well done, and appropriate for a princess who has descended from so many royal kings. Ah, soldier!

paragraphs.original: CHARMIAN dies
paragraphs.translated: She dies.

paragraphs.original: Enter DOLABELLA
paragraphs.translated: DOLABELLA enters.

paragraphs.original: How goes it here?
paragraphs.translated: What's going on in here?

paragraphs.original: All dead.
paragraphs.translated: They're all dead.

paragraphs.original:
Caesar, thy thoughts
Touch their effects in this. Thyself art coming
To see performed the dreaded act which thou
So sought'st to hinder.
paragraphs.translated: Caesar, you thought this would happen. You're coming here yourself to see the dreaded act you had tried to stop.

paragraphs.original: Enter CAESAR and all his train, marching
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR and his entourage enter, marching.

paragraphs.original: A way there, a way for Caesar!
paragraphs.translated: Step aside, step aside for Caesar!

paragraphs.original:
O sir, you are too sure an augurer.
That you did fear is done.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, sir, you are too good at predicting the future. What you were afraid of has happened.

paragraphs.original:
Bravest at the last,
She leveled at our purposes and, being royal,
Took her own way. The manner of their deaths?
I do not see them bleed.
paragraphs.translated: She was bravest at the end. She knew what I intended to do with her and, being royal, she took her own way out. How did they die? I don't see any blood.

paragraphs.original: Who was last with them?
paragraphs.translated: Who was with them last?

paragraphs.original:
A simple countryman that brought her figs.
This was his basket.
paragraphs.translated: A simple country farmer who brought her figs. This was the basket.

paragraphs.original: Poisoned, then.
paragraphs.translated: They were poisoned, then.

paragraphs.original:
Oh, Caesar,
This Charmian lived but now. She stood and spake.
I found her trimming up the diadem
On her dead mistress. Tremblingly she stood
And on the sudden dropped.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, Caesar, this Charmian lived until a moment ago. She stood and spoke. I found her adjusting the crown on her dead mistress. She stood trembling, then suddenly dropped dead.

paragraphs.original:
Oh, noble weakness!
If they had swallowed poison, 'twould appear
By external swelling, but she looks like sleep,
As she would catch another Antony
In her strong toil of grace.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, noble weakness! If they had swallowed poison, it would be evident by external swelling. But she looks like she's asleep, as if she would charm another Antony.

paragraphs.original:
Here on her breast
There is a vent of blood, and something blown.
The like is on her arm.
paragraphs.translated: Here on her breast there's a little bloody mark. There's a similar mark on her arm.

paragraphs.original:
This is an aspic's trail, and these fig leaves
Have slime upon them, such as th' aspic leaves
Upon the caves of Nile.
paragraphs.translated: This is an asp's trail, and these fig leaves have slime on them, just like the kind that asps deposit on the caves by the Nile.

paragraphs.original:
Most probable
That so she died, for her physician tells me
She hath pursued conclusions infinite
Of easy ways to die. Take up her bed
And bear her women from the monument.
She shall be buried by her Antony.
No grave upon the earth shall clip in it
A pair so famous. High events as these
Strike those that make them, and their story is
No less in pity than his glory which
Brought them to be lamented. Our army shall
In solemn show attend this funeral,
And then to Rome. Come, Dolabella, see
High order in this great solemnity.
paragraphs.translated: That's probably how she died. Her doctor told me she had searched for an infinite number of easy ways to die. Pick up her bed and carry her ladies out of the tomb. She shall be buried next to her Antony. No other grave on earth shall hold a pair this famous. Momentous events like these strike those that cause them. Antony and Cleopatra's story is as pitiable as my military exploits are glorious. Our army shall somberly attend this funeral and then depart for Rome. Come, Dolabella. See that there is a dignified splendor to this great solemnity.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt, bearing the dead bodies
paragraphs.translated: They exit, with the GUARDS carrying CLEOPATRA's bed and the two ladies.
